narrative: Pestdisplace uses novel visualization tools to share, track and communicate the distribution of crop pests and diseases over time and space (longituinal & spatial). A great part of this data was passive (stored in old reports and lab-books) and could not be used for decision making. By facilitating data collation from research and official sources the platforms is intended to accelerate decision making by stakeholders thus reducing risk and/or the impact of pests and diseases on crop yield.

title: A framework for priority-setting in climate smart agriculture (CSA) research
narrative: A flexible framework for assessing and comparing different interventions and investments that addresses the key elements of CSA. The framework describes some features of CSA that make prioritisation a challenge and proposes a framework for prioritization based on a brief review of existing tools and methods for priority setting in agriculture and some case-study examples.

title: High-Throughput Yam Anthracnose Phenotyping Using Detached Leaf Assay and Digital Imaging
narrative: Conventional field phenotyping is unreliable as infection rate is influenced by weather, and the disease severity assessed using a 1 to 5 rating scale is subjected to “rater” bias. Therefore, a new phenotyping method was developed by combining in vitro detached leaf assay (DLA) and accurate measurement of YAD symptomatic area using the “Leaf Doctor” App (Pethybridge & Nelson, Plant Dis 99, 1310, 2015).

title: Multi-stakeholder framework for intervening in RTB seed systems
narrative: The tool is designed to better understand RTB seed systems or to improve seed system interventions (e.g., projects or programs) It helps in identifying key stakeholders and in assessing availability, access, and quality of seed as well as in  identifying bottlenecks and in designing key actions for the upcoming intervention.

title: Seed Tracker: online application for real-time tracking of cassava seed production that supports communication and networking of cassava producers
narrative: The Cassava Seed Tracker™ is a fully featured program for real-time tracking of cassava seed production, including pre-planting planning, registration of seed fields, crop management, harvesting, quality assessment and quality assertion. The Cassava Seed Tracker is also a digital platform for communication and networking of cassava seed producers and service providers for common good.

title: Impact network analysis (INA) to understand and describe RTB seed systems
narrative: Impact Network Analysis (INA) is a multilayer network analysis that looks at the effects of a technology – such as a new variety, a management strategy, or other types of information – as it influences the outcomes of linked socioeconomic networks and biophysical networks.

title: Integrated seed health approach to help decision-making on RTB seed management
narrative: This model provides estimates of seed degeneration risk at a location, as a function of factors such as weather conduciveness, crop disease resistance, and success rates for interventions such as positive selection and roguing.  It also provides estimates of optimal timing for purchase of quality-declared seed to maintain yield within acceptable bounds.

title: Positive selection to improve on-farm seed potato management
narrative: Positive selection (or “Select the best”) is an efficient and simple technique for improving on-farm seed potato management. The best plants (robust and not showing symptoms of key diseases) are marked before and after flowering. These plants are harvested and only those with good yield are selected to provide tubers for the next growing season. This technique is complemented with integrated pest and disease management, and postharvest techniques.

title: Method based on a combination of tissue culture, chemotherapy and thermotherapy to produce  cassava plants clean from viral infections
narrative: Using a combination of tissue culture, chemotherapy and thermotherapy and after 3 cycles of cleaning it was possible to obtain virus-free planting material for 31 varieties of five countries (Kenya, Malawi, Mozambique, Tanzania and Uganda). The cleaning process was performed in United Kingdom, this first cross-boundary effort provides important lessons for mitigating the two-major cassava viral diseases in Africa.

title: Landscape IMAGES modeling framework for multi scale spatially explicit analysis of tradeoffs and synergies among ecosystem services provisioning across agricultural landscapes
narrative: The LandscapeIMAGES is a modeling framework for multi-scale spatially explicit analysis of trade-offs and synergies among ecosystem services provisioning across agricultural landscapes. It generates large sets of spatially explicit land-use and management scenarios to inform discussions among stakeholders involved in landscape planning processes.

title: Rapid multiplication of planting material through rooted apical cuttings for seed potato systems
narrative: Rapid multiplication technique for potato planting material. It consists in producing rooted cuttings from tissue culture plantlets grown in screenhouses. Once planted in the field, each cutting produces 7 to 10, and up to 15+, tubers which are multiplied a further season or two, then the harvest is sold as seed.

title: Varieties for mid altitude, humid subtropical agro-ecologies in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), focusing on heat tolerance, late blight and virus resistance - Climate smart mid altitude potato
narrative: CIP has developed a new population of late blight resistant and heat tolerant potatoes designated LBHT.  These clones have been sent to several countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America for variety development and use in breeding.

title: Direct RT-RPA : a robust, accurate, sensitive and quick method for detection of potyviruses from recalcitrant plant species based on reverse transcription-recombinase polymerase amplification (RT-RPA)
narrative: Potyviruses (genus Potyvirus; family Potyviridae) are widely distributed and represent one of the most economically important genera of plant viruses. The developed method detects each target virus directly from plant leaf extracts prepared with a simple and inexpensive extraction method avoiding laborious extraction of high-quality RNA. This assay coupled with direct detection make it a suitable for the detection of viruses in seed yams as well as plants.

title: High-yielding and late blight resistant potato clones ready to be released as new varieties or as parents in crossing plans
narrative: Starting in 2011, 30,000 genotypes have been assessed to select those with high yields and good agronomic and commercial characters such as skin color, flesh color, tuber shape and eyes depth, plant vigor, uniformity of tubers. After seven years of evaluation and selection, 18 clones that showed phenotypic stability for selected traits have been identified.

title: Two potato varieties biofortified with iron and zinc, resistant to late blight and PVY virus adapted for tropical highland and mid elevation ecologies
narrative: A breeding strategy initiated in 2012 resulted in new tetraploid cultivars with resistance to the most important diseases such as late blight and viruses and tolerance to abiotic stresses (heat and drought) while maintaining the nutritional quality of the tuber with high levels of iron and zinc.

title: Ground penetrating radar for estimating root bulking rate in cassava
narrative: The ability to image and quantify subsurface root structure would allow breeders to classify root traits for rapid selection and allow agronomists  to derive effective cultivation practices, without using destructive root harvesting approaches. The capability of ground penetrating radar (GPR) to predict root-bulking rates (formation of cassava storage roots during the growth season) was shown.  Using current modeling methods,one can estimate root bulking rates for selection of early maturing cassava varieties.

title: High-yielding and black Sigatoka resistant banana hybrids (NABIO ) for East Africa
narrative: New banana genotypes developed by the Uganda National Agricultural Research Organization in collaboration with Bioversity International.

title: Framework for multidimensional analysis of sustainability of intensification options in RTB-based systems
narrative: The framework proposes transparent and well described procedures to select sustainability indicators to assess and monitor progress in SI of agricultural systems

title: Qualitative data collection tool for gender analysis to understand local perceptions of agency and decision making
narrative: The ladder of power and freedom is a qualitative data collection tool to understand local perceptions of agency and decision making.

title: Gender checklist for introducing new Root and Tuber Crops technologies to men and women
narrative: This checklist is intended to help ensure that gender is adequately addressed in  workplans and interventions. Considering gender dimensions of farming activities helps us to identify context-specific social factors that support/hinder uptake of new technologies. The checklist has two sections; understanding gendered interests and preferences; and understanding gendered decision-making power.

title: Gender-responsive participatory videos: a guide for facilitators
narrative: Participatory-video is a research technique in which farmers film and publicly screen interviews with their peers. It is a powerful tool to build relationships between researchers and farmers and collect the real voices of the different social groups in the community. This guide has been prepared for researchers and development practitioners who are interested in applying this technique.

title: Gender in Agricultural Mechanization: Key guiding questions.
narrative: The tool presents guiding questions to stimulate researchers to think about the gender implications of actual or possible interventions involving machinery or that may depend on existing machinery.

title: The Banana Breeding Tracking System (BTracT)
narrative: The system tracks all stages in breeding, beginning with the automatic decision making of crosses in the field based on flowering plants, followed by all stages of hybrid production (from seed to embryo culture to nursery). Plants are barcoded and the data management system implemented and integrated directly with MusaBase.  In this manner it is possible to monitor progress of crosses by pollination, thru seed set and eventual distribution, all captured in a database.

title: Multi-model systems analysis to identify Low Emissions Development Pathways – exploring synergies and trade-offs in Mahbubnagar District, Telangana, India
narrative: Triple-win solutions with positive contributions to productivity, adaptation and mitigation are the key to achieve sustainable agricultural systems. Quantifying synergies and trade-offs among these we employed simulation modelling- crop, livestock and whole-farm models, and Cool Farm Tool to estimate net GHG emissions. Multi-model systems analysis using participatory design and tools could be a decision support for policymakers guiding investments towards synergistic climate smart agriculture strategies.

title: A co-management strategy for Lake Fisheries
narrative: Lake fisheries provide an important source of micro nutrients, animal protein and livelihoods.  Lake Nasser in Upper Egypt provides a case of a critical yet under performing fishery i.e., stocks are overfished and catches are decreasing. Building on earlier recommendations, WorldFish  conducted a further assessment in 2017 to design and formalize an ecosystem-based, co-management approach to manage and rebuild the fishery (including using restocking techniques).

title: Co-management of community fish refuges (CFRs) to enhance fish production, water security and adaptive capacity to climate change
narrative: A CFR is a form of stock enhancement or a fish conservation measure to improve the productivity of rice-field fisheries. The CFR is a refuge, or sanctuary, for brood fish that is protected from fishing year-round and is especially important as fish habitat during the dry season in seasonally inundated rice fields. During the dry season fish seek deeper pools that become disconnected, during the flood season the fish emerge from the refuge ponds to spawn and feed throughout the rice field

title: Hilsa fisheries co-management and livelihood buffering strategies
narrative: Co-management strategies (an innovative combination of local social innovations, women’s community saving’s groups, area management strategies and national policy adjustments) were applied to restore the hilsa shad fishery.  In 2018 research outputs illustrate the process and outcomes including substantial increases in hilsa landings.

title: A framework for assessing and building adaptive capacity to climate change in small-scale fisheries communities
narrative: We developed an analytical framework comprised of five dimensions that allows analysts to identify obstacles and options for building capacities to adapt and to innovate. The research applies and examines the framework in coastal fishing communities.   The 'agency' dimension of the framework is informed by earlier WorldFish-led research on gender and agency.

title: Solar-social innovations to reduce waste and loss, increase incomes and improve equity in capture fisheries systems
narrative: The use of solar technology offers opportunities to reduce value and quality losses experienced in fisheries value chains. FISH research illustrates when solar-based initiatives are developed through action research and combined with social innovations (particularly gender transformative or gender sensitive approaches) complementary outcomes ranging from increased gender equity, reduction of fish quality loss and increased likelihood of sustainability.

title: Design of tilapia single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) chip
narrative: A SNP chip optimized for genomic selection of GIFT and Abbassa tilapia strains was designed in collaboration with the Roslin institute for manufacture and application to Nile Tilapia genetic improvement programs in 2019.

title: Generation 17 GIFT Nile tilapia strain
narrative: Generation 17 of the GIFT tilapia strain was spawned, grown out and assessed (168 families).

title: Generation 15 of the Abbassa Nile Tilapia strain
narrative: Generation 15 of the Abbassa tilapia strain was produced –spawned and grown out (125 families).

title: Generation 2 of Rohu Carp
narrative: Generation 2 of Rohu Carp was produced – grown out and assessed (240 families)

title: DArTseq genetic marker developed for Catla
narrative: Analysis of DArTseq genetic marker data successfully identified and characterized single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and silicoDArT markers in catla. The analysis identified an unexpectedly high level of sibship among breeding population founders and found no or low levels of divergence in SNPs among the three river populations studied.

title: A way to breed for a new trait of robustness in GIFT identified
narrative: The analysis revealed the presence of genetic heterogeneity of both body weight and its environmental variance in all environments. The presence of genetic variation in residual variance of body weight implies that the residual variance can be modified by selection. Incorporating both genotype-by-environment interaction and micro-environmental sensitivity information may help in selecting robust genotypes with high performance across environments and resilience to environmental fluctuations.

title: A way to breed for feed efficiency in GIFT
narrative: Video assessment of feed intake on individual fish reared in groups was used to estimate the genetic parameters of six growth traits, feed intake, feed conversion ratio (FCR) and residual feed intake in 40 pedigreed families of the GIFT strain of Nile tilapia.  The FCR response to different selection criteria were estimated to assess the potential of genetics as a means of increasing FCR in tilapia.

title: A smartphone app providing aquaculture extension Information
narrative: A virtual aquaculture extension application has been co-designed with a local ICT company called Greenway. The app has been designed based on their previous agriculture and livestock App in use by 85,000 farmers. The Aquaculture App brings access to weather forecasts for the immediate area where the farmer is located. It also delivers messages about sourcing inputs (seed and feed), market prices and trends plus climate risks.

title: The use of water storage ponds and homestead irrigation channels for fish production in Myanmar
narrative: Irrigation canals are a relatively under-used water body for the culture of fish in Myanmar compared to other countries in the region. The homestead irrigation channels, called ‘chan myaung’ in Myanmar, have been successfully explored as a viable option for fish culture in specific district in Myanmar.  This has demonstrated that those water bodies can be used as productive systems for the culture of finfish. Potentially, this has important effect of poverty reduction and food and nutrition security

title: Methods for improving productivity of Aquatic Agricultural systems in Cambodia
narrative: Methods range from inclusion of Small Indigenous fish Species (SIS) in polyculture, home gardening production systems, to end of rainy season rice field ponds. Production aimed at providing additional incomes and supply nutrient rich and diversified food to households, targeting children and women of reproductive age.

title: Stimulation of natural foods production in ponds by use of low protein feeds with fibre (NSP) rich carbohydrates in Tilapia culture
narrative: Dietary requirements for fish are normally determined in absence of natural food, while the majority of fish (incl. tilapia) are cultured in ponds, in which the natural food also contributes to fish growth. The innovation revealed that low protein feeds with fibre (NSP) rich carbohydrates provide both the necessary nutrients for the fish and, via the faeces, stimulate the natural food production in the pond that also contributes to the fish growth.

title: Tools to assist farmers with low or no numeracy skills to manage their aquaculture pond
narrative: Two tools involved: Secchi disk to measure water transparency in fishponds and determine the amount of plankton; Tool to infer fish weight from their length. This consists in a laminated colour coded ruler to measure length of the fish including a guide to interpret the measured length in cm into weight in grams.

title: Better Management Practices for Carp Intensification by Women Self Help Groups
narrative: Women Self Help Groups are trained in bespoke Better Management Practices for carp farming with small indigenous fish species (Mola).

title: GIFT Tilapia introduction in Odisha State India
narrative: Production and management system set up for starting the production of GIFT on a larger scale in Odisha State.

title: Low-cost feed formulation with local ingredients in DR Congo (Bukavu and Kinshasa)
narrative: Following a feed ingredient scoping in Bukavu and Kinshasa, cost-effective tiapia feed was formulated using locally available ingredients.

title: The Crop Network Group (CNG) as a platform for crop Product design, development, testing, advancement and delivery in Africa.
narrative: The Crop Network Group (CNG) is a crop improvement network of multi-disciplinary teams from NARS, CG, Advanced Research Institutes (ARIs), NGOs, private seed sector and processing sector. CNG is a platform for product design, strategy, development, testing, advancement and delivery. The CNG will also be a knowledge-sharing platform, facilitating continuous capacity building. The CNG team will work closely with Excellence in Breeding (EiB) platform.

title: Introgression of high oleic trait in groundnut.
narrative: High oleic groundnut is preferred by food industry for shelf-life benefits, and consumer health benefits. Genotyping for selection of FAD2A and FAD2B mutant alleles, and robust-phenotyping using Near Infrared Reflectance Spectroscopy (NIRS) enabled introgression of ‘high oleic’ trait in Spanish and Virginia Bunch backgrounds. The fast track development is possible through reduced generation interval using low cost methods, and early generation and multi-location testing data enabled line advancement decisions.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 07222 (GJG 32)
narrative: Drought tolerant, resistant to rust and moderately tolerant to Peanut bud necrosis disease with medium bold (100 seed mass of 38 g), 87% sound mature kernels, tan seed coat for Zone III b for post-rainy irrigated cultivation (rabi-summer) for multiple states in India.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 93305 ( MIOU PAALE)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Moderate resistance to early leaf spot; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 91328 ( LOKRE)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Moderate resistance to early leaf spot; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 01276 ( NAFA 1)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Moderate resistance to early leaf spot; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Low altitude areas.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13806 (TOUINWARE)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Moderate resistance to early leaf spot; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13830 (BEEDA)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Moderate resistance to early leaf spot; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13912 (SOUKEBA)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Moderate resistance to early leaf spot; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 08837 (SARINUT 2)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Foliar disease; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 00350 (Baana Tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 03181 (Djigui Tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13085 (Wassaba tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13054 (Benkadi tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13079 (Sago tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13871 (Wasso tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Biotic stress tolerance: Foliar disease; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13830 (Kounadiya tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Biotic stress tolerance: Foliar disease; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 13825 (Keniana tiga)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Biotic stress tolerance: Foliar disease; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 99537 (Mwenje)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV 93437 (Nyanda)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 07999 (Samnut 27)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Rosette, Early Maturity; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Dry lowlands.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 09926 (Samnut 28)
narrative: Characterized by: Abiotic stress tolerance: Drought; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Lower humid mid-altitudes.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-IS 01276 (Samnut 29)
narrative: Characterized by: Biotic stress tolerance: Foliar disease; Nutritional Traits: Oil quality,Protein. Agro-ecology: Lower humid mid-altitudes.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 03519 (Kongwa 519)
narrative: Characterized by following traits: days to maturity, grain yield, colour of kernels, grain size, pod filling and taste.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 05650 (Kongwa650)
narrative: This cultivar is characterized by high yielding, drought resistance.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 02724 (Kongwa724)
narrative: This cultivar is characterized by a great seed size and high yielding, heat tolerance and pest resistance.

title: Groundnut cultivar: CGV SM 01514 (TANZANUT 2016)
narrative: ICGV-SM 01514 is a short duration variety that mature within 90-100 days . This variety is resistant to one of the most devastating disease in Africa, the groundnut rosette disease. Theis variety tan in color and medium seeded.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV SM 07599 (MTWARANUT-2016)
narrative: The variety ICGV -SM 07599 is high yielding and resistant to the groundnut rosette disease. It is suited to the low and mid altitude agroecologies.

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 08503 (NALIENDELE 2016)
narrative: This variety is a derivative of CG7, one of the most market preferred varieties in East and Southern Africa due to its yield potential and culinary attributes. It is resistant to one of the most devastating disease in Africa-the groundnut rosette disease. It is a medium duration variety, thus suited

title: Groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 1711 (GMGV8)
narrative: The variety is resistant to the most destructive disease in Africa, the rosette disease and has a yield potential of 2500kg/ha.It is a medium duration variety that take 110-120 days to reach maturity. It is tan in colour with medium to large seeds.

title: Sorghum cultivar: Lata//Samb-5-1-1-1 (SAMBONI)
narrative: Tolerance to drought, leaf blight, anthracnose and rust, stay green, and grain quality traits like size, boldness, colour, lustre, protein content and viscosity to suit consumer preferences and local processing.

title: Sorghum cultivar: ICSV 1360963 (SAMBONI)
narrative: High yielding improved variety (2.8 T/ha), maturity ( 115 days) adapted to Sudan zones of West Africa (700 mm to 1200 mm) with high vitreous grain.

title: Sorghum cultivar: ICSV 1361086 (NANDO)
narrative: High yielding variety with 3.2t/ha, white seeded, 120 days of maturity, adapted to Sudan zones of West Africa (700 mm to 1200 mm).

title: Sorghum cultivar: CF35.5 (SAMSORG 49)
narrative: Tolerance to drought, leaf blight, anthracnose and rust, stay green, and grain quality traits like size, boldness, colour, lustre, protein content and viscosity to suit consumer preferences and local processing.

title: Sorghum cultivar: IESV 23006 DL (Pilira 5)
narrative: Open pollinated pure line sorghum variety developed by pedigree selection from cross KAT 369 x IESV 92170 DL- l-1-1-2-2-1with an average yield of 4500kg/ha. The yield can be increased under good management in combination with good fertilizer application. It matures after 120 days. It is suitable for mid altitude.

title: Sorghum cultivar: IESV 23010 DL (Pilira 4)
narrative: Pilira 4 is a newly released open pollinated pureline sorghum variety with an average yield of 4.2 t ha-1 developed through pedigree selection and derived from cross KAT 369 x IESV 92170 DL- l-1-2-1-2-2. The yield can be increased under good management in combination with good fertilizer application.

title: Sorghum cultivar: KARI Mtama 1 (Pilira 3)
narrative: Pilira 3 is a newly released open pollinated Sorghum variety with an average yield of 4.0 t ha-1. It matures after 120 days. It is suitable for mid altitude and lowland areas of Malawi. It is tolerant to moisture stress.

title: Sorghum cultivar: ICSR 14001 (Parbhani Shakti)
narrative: ICSR 14001 is a selection from grain sorghum caudatum landrace originated from India. Over years of testing it showed an average grain Fe concentration of 45 ppm and zinc 32 ppm compared to the baseline of 30 ppm Fe and 20 ppm Zn in sorghum. Its protein content is high.

title: Lentil cultivar: ILL7723 (Khajuro Masuro 4)
narrative: Cultivar high in nutrients, especially proteins, Fe and Zn.

title: Lentil cultivar: LRIL 22-70 (Barimasur 9)
narrative: Cultivar high in nutrients, especially Fe and Zn.

title: Lentil cultivar: ILL7723 (LL1373)
narrative: Highly nutritious cultivar.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMV 167006 (ICRI-Tabi)
narrative: This variety is tolerant to the head miner because the ears are very compact. Data collected in several trials demonstrate good tillering and medium and compact ears.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMV 167005 (Mil de Siaka)
narrative: This variety is very tolerant to the head miner by its compactness. Its grain yield is determined by the good grain filling and is very resistant to lodging and tolerant to Striga hermonthica.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMV 167004 (PPBV Tera)
narrative: Created from crosses of several varieties selected by growers according to a number of criteria (yield, earliness, maturity, compactness, ear length, seed color, tillering and tolerance to Striga hermonthica during 03 rainy seasons in T√©ra in the plots of the producers in real environment. With the process of farmer participatory.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMV 167003 (PPBV Falwel)
narrative: Created from the crosses of the several varieties chosen by the producers according to a certain number of criteria (yield, precocity, maturity, compactness, spike length, the color of the seeds) during 3 rainy seasons at Falwel in the plots of producers in a real environment with the process of farmer.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMV 167002 (PPBV Serkin Haussa)
narrative: Created from the crosses of the several varieties chosen by the producers according to a certain number of criteria (yield, precocity, maturity, compactness and head length) during 3 rainy seasons at Serkin Haoussa in the farmers' plots in a real environment.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICTP 8203-Fe-2 (Chakti)
narrative: Africa's biofortified millet variety, tolerant to abiotic stress, high in Fe and Zn, growing in Sahel.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMH 1502 (AHB 1269)
narrative: Iron biofortified hybrid, average grain yield 31.68 q/ha, dry fodder yield 74 q/ha, maturity in 82 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for Zone A1, A & B of Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Punjab, Delhi, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMH 1504 (RHB 234)
narrative: Iron biofortified hybrid, average grain yield 31.69 q/ha, dry fodder yield 71 q/ha, maturity in 81 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for Zone A1, A & B of Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Punjab, Delhi, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu.

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMH 1503 (RHB 233)
narrative: Iron biofortified hybrid, average grain yield 31.57 q/ha, dry fodder yield 74 q/ha, maturity in 80 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for Zone A1, A & B of Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Punjab, Delhi, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu

title: Pearl Millet cultivar: ICMH 1501 (HHB 311)
narrative: Iron biofortified hybrid, average grain yield 31.73 q/ha, dry fodder yield 72 q/ha, maturity in 81 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for Zone A1, A & B of Haryana, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Punjab, Delhi, Maharashtra, Tamil Nadu.

title: Chickpea cultivar: ICCV 07308 (Yezin 13)
narrative: Tolerant to abiotic stress and terminal drought. High in proteins. Grows on dry mid-altitudes.

title: Chickpea cultivar: ICCX-060157-F3-BP-3P-BP (BARIChola 11)
narrative: Heat-tolerant, resistant to Botrytis Grey Mold (BGM) and high-yielding.

title: Pigeonpeat cultivar: Pusa Arhar 16
narrative: Selections of single plant progeny of superior recombinants selected from the population developed through population improvement involving genotypes ICP 85059, ICPL 390,ICPL 267, Manak, H/92/39 and ICP 85024, extra early maturing (120 days), semi-dwarf (95 cm to 120 cm tall), determinate, high yielding >1000kg/ha.

title: Pigeonpea cultivar: ICEAP 01551 MPPV-4)
narrative: It is medium maturing variety, and fits in medium to high altitude areas with rainfall between 400-900mm. Suitable for both green and dry grain with 100 seed mass of 17-19 g. Fits well in intercropping with legumes such as groundnut and soybean.

title: Pigeonpea cultivar: ICEAP 00557 (MPPV-3)
narrative: It is a medium maturing variety, fitting in medium to high altitude areas with rainfall between 400-900mm. Suitable for both green and dry grain with 100 seed mass of 14-16 g. Fits well in intercropping with cereals such as maize and sorghum and legumes such as groundnut and soybean.

title: Soybean cultivar: TGx1844-22E
narrative: TGx1844-22E with women-preferred nutritional traits released as ‘Favour’ by the Council of Scientific and Industrial Research - Savanna Agricultural Research Institute (CSIR-SARI), Ghana and distributed through IITA Soybean International Trials.

title: Cowpea cultivar: IT07K-297-13 (SAMPEA 18)
narrative: The cultivar is characterized by Early maturity, resistance to Alectra,and bacterial blight and tolerant to striga and drought. (2.5t/ha)

title: Cowpea cultivar: IT08K-150-12 (SAMPEA 19)
narrative: The cultivar is characterized by Early maturity, tolerant to striga and drought, to Alectra. (2.7t/ha).

title: An approach to promote the uptake of evidence on agricultural research using strengthened relationships with national institutes and data systems
narrative: To gain insights on how to promote the uptake of evidence on agricultural research at country level, the Agricultural Science and Technology Indicators initiative launched a pilot study in Ethiopia, Nigeria and Tanzania. The study found that strong relationships and networks are needed to increase awareness of ASTI evidence and to forge linkages with official national data systems. Greater outreach and connectivity with local institutions may be useful next steps.

title: Women Empowerment in Livestock Index (WELI)
narrative: WELI measures women’s empowerment in agriculture, focusing on key areas of livestock production (e.g. animal health, breeding and feeding) and on use of livestock products (e.g. animal-source-food processing and marketing). WELI offers the potential to: produce a large body of evidence on women’s empowerment in livestock; show what interventions can empower women and in what domain; elevate women’s empowerment to a measurable outcome of research and development interventions; and help design better livestock interventions.

title: Collective action games to strengthen resource governance in India
narrative: IFPRI, ICRISAT, IWMI and partners developed  experimental games that were shown to contribute to improved governance of shared resources through better understanding of how different decision affect resource outcomes. The games to strengthen groundwater and surface water have been adopted by Foundation for Ecological Security and implemented in several Indian states in 2019. Additional scaling up is planned to over 3,700 communities covering 259,000 households in at least six Indian states.

title: Research Collaborative on Cash Transfers and Intimate Partner Violence
narrative: Studies in Bangladesh, Ecuador and Mali showed that cash transfers can reduce intimate partner violence. Based on these findings, a Research Collaborative was created to further explore the linkages between cash transfers and intimate partner violence. The Collaborative's work has already informed strategic decisions of several organizations.

title: Novel insurance linked credit model contingent on drought risk for Kenyan smallholders
narrative: Weather-related agricultural risks and limited access to credit are serious impediments to agricultural productivity and growth in developing countries. This innovation is a novel insurance linked credit model piloted in Kenya. In this model, drought risk related perils are transferred from borrower to lender via an insurance premium paid by borrowers. A drought event triggers repayment of the loan by the insurer, thereby increasing incentives for farmers to borrow.

title: Aflasafe KE01 for Kenya
narrative: Biocontrol approach for Kenya to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: District nutrition profiles, a compiled set of indicators that can be used to dialogue with stakeholders about where to focus efforts on addressing undernutrition
narrative: District nutrition profiles draw on diverse sources of data to compile a set of indicators on the state of nutrition and its cross-sectoral determinants. The profiles for 640 districts in India are intended to be conversation starters with stakeholders about why undernutrition levels are high, and which factors might need to be addressed to improve nutrition.

title: Multi-sectoral taskforce model on food safety
narrative: The taskforce model brings together researchers working in food safety and representatives of related ministries. The members work together on prioritized topics of food safety risk assessment to conduct hands-on trainings, real-world risk assessment case studies and to develop curricula for universities. This model was successfully piloted in Vietnam where it contributed to significant scientific and policy improvements around food safety. In 2019, A4NH researchers began adapting this model for use in Cambodia.

title: Demonstrated cost-effectiveness of food-assisted maternal and child health and nutrition program on maternal and child nutritional outcomes in Guatemala and Burundi
narrative: Evidence on the cost‐effectiveness of multisectoral maternal and child health and nutrition programs is scarce. A prospective costing study by IFPRI of two programs in Burundi and Guatemala demonstrated that the relationship between program dose and nutritional outcomes is not linear and in these cases the more expensive versions of the program were the most cost-effective for reducing child stunting.

title: Woreda Participatory Land Use Planning for Pastoral Areas in Ethiopia
narrative: Woreda Participatory Land Use Planning (WPLUP) for Pastoral Areas is a process undertaken by district-level government experts working with local land users, to develop a land use plan for better managing and protecting rangelands, and for woreda development planning. WPLUP has also been used to prevent rangeland fragmentation, learning from joint village land use planning in Tanzania. A drylands-specific land capability classification is included. ILRI provided significant technical support to the development of WPLUP.

title: Evidence that Yemen’s Social Fund for Development Cash for Nutrition Program has multiple positive effects on nutrition and health of young children
narrative: The impact evaluation found that cash transfers with soft conditionality on attending nutritional training sessions increased child and maternal dietary diversity, maternal knowledge of recommended infant and young child feeding practices, rate of exclusive breastfeeding and early initiation of breastfeeding, treatment of water, and weight-for-height and height-for-age for children in the poorest tercile of treated households, whereas they decreased the rate of children being identified as malnourished.

title: Contribution of community seed banks to socio-ecological resilience
narrative: In Guatemala, a network of community seed banks supported by the local NGO ASOCUCH is preserving, multiplying and distributing threatened maize and bean varieties. The innovation corresponds to the finding that the community seed banks have contributed to socioecological resilience through private seed conservation and provision of seeds during emergency situations.

title: Computer game prototypes developed around food security and climate change
narrative: Project Leader Joost Vervoort used the Utrecht Sustainability Game Jam (university course for students to create video game prototypes, with specific aims to try and educate, engage, and imagine on the topic of sustainable, creative futures) to create games related to ag and climate change for use in broader CCAFS engagements. In 2019, 17 computer game prototypes were developed by Utrecht University and Utrecht School of the Arts students for use by CCAFS, other users.

title: Agrobiodiversity Index, tool to measure agrobiodiversity and identify concrete actions to achieve diverse and sustainable food systems
narrative: The Agrobiodiversity Index (ABDI) is the first standard way of measuring agrobiodiversity and helps identify concrete actions to achieve diverse, sustainable and resilient food systems. The ABDI has 22 indicators, comprising three commitment indicators, four action indicators and 15 status indicators across three pillars, which are aligned with nine of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The ABDI aims to assess performance yearly and help companies/countries track their progress towards fostering sustainable food systems.

title: Methodology to analyse national food systems based on secondary reports and data
narrative:
Using a participatory process, stakeholders and researchers identify research streams to support the operationalizing of food systems
approaches in a particular country. The published product provides a summary review of the literature, applies a food systems framework to research priorities in that national or sub-national context, develops an initial food systems profile, and identifies priority research questions.

title: New policy baseline assessment methodology to conduct food policy analysis
narrative: This methodology provides a way for researchers to take a "snapshot" of the current policy context around food systems. The methodology itself comprises three components: (1) face-to-face  (F2F) open-ended interviews with 20-25 key informant national-level policy stakeholders  on relevant actors, narratives and politics/interests , (2) online semi-quantitative survey of 100 key informants and (3) F2F in-depth interviews with selected policymakers.

title: Agricultural Investment for Development Analyzer tool designed to help governments and analysts in Northern Africa draw agricultural investment plans
narrative: The (Arab) Agricultural Investment for Development Analyzer (AIDA) is an agricultural and rural economic planning toolkit designed to help governments and analysts draw agricultural investment plans and ensure that levels of investment in the agricultural and rural sectors is sufficient for achieving the desired outcomes. AIDA has been built using an economywide and minimalistic investment data approach.

title: Ethiopian Digital Agro-climate Advisory Platform (EDACaP)
narrative: Ethiopia’s smallholder farmers are increasingly vulnerable to food insecurity due to increased variability in seasonal rainfall, rising temperatures, floods, frequent drought, pests and diseases. EDACaP harnesses the power of digital agriculture ntegrating climate, soil, crop and agronomic data into a crop model to establish an agro-climate advisory decision support system that increases climate resilience and adaptive capacity of 18 million smallholders. Delivery to development agents and farmers in local languages through SMS, interactive-voice-response systems, radio.

title: Gendered Feed Assessment Tool (G-FEAST)
narrative: G-FEAST is a gendered version of the Feed Assessment Tool (FEAST) which uses the same data application as FEAST and aims to identify: which aspects of gender relations in households affect animal feeding practices and the uptake of feeding interventions, and; differences in opportunities and constraints in animal feeding between different household types

title: Mobile, handheld and affordable Near Infra-Red Spectrometry (NIRS) instruments for feed quality analysis
narrative: Mobile NIRS instruments developed to generate feed quality information for least cost ration design, feed supply and demand scenarios, prediction of livestock performance and selection in crop and forage improvement programs.

title: Global Foresight for Food and Agriculture Tool
narrative: The Global Foresight for Food and Agriculture (web)Tool allows users to explore the impacts of alternative investment options on agricultural productivity and food security in the context of changes in population, income, technology, and climate using the International Model for Policy Analysis of Agricultural Commodities and Trade (IMPACT). It is hosted on the Food Security Portal funded primarily by the European Commission.

title: Development of Solar Bubble Dryer Mark II for rice
narrative: This is the energetic optimisation of the previously developed Solar Bubble Dryer (Version 1). The SBD consists of a drying tunnel inflated by ventilators that are powered by a photovoltaic system. The objective was optimise the drying process and minimise energy reduction to reduce the investment cost of the dryer by 50%.

title: GrainSafe Dryer and hermetic rice storage system
narrative: The	GrainSafe Dryer facilitates drying in a hermetic storage container before it is closed for safe storage. It has the potential of reducing combined cost for drying and storage by half.  The air distribution system is solar powered making it suitable for rural settings.

title: Hermetic Super bag for rice grain and seed storage
narrative: Bags to hermetically and safely store rice grains and seeds after harvest by individual farmers, groups of farmers and processors and for storing seeds by farmers and seed producers. The reduction of water oxygen inside the bag is around 4 times and that minimizes (almost to negligible) the pest growing inside the bag without pesticides and helps maintain seeds in better condition, and the head rice recovery is higher at milling.

title: Adaptation of flatbed dryer for paddy drying in the Southeast Asian countries
narrative: A dryer is a machine that removes the water from wet grains. Two types of FBDs were developed. The conventional FBD operates with its drying air moving only in one direction. The reversible airflow FBD operates with its drying air to move in two directions, upward and downward. The dryers was already proven its benefits for paddy drying such as it can be used for very wet paddy and with low drying cost.

title: SMART-Valleys: a new participatory approach for land and water management in Benin and Togo
narrative: Smart-Valleys is a participatory approach used by smallholder farmers for land and water management for rice-based systems in inland valleys. The approach enables farmers to improve, at low cost, water control by using simple means to design and construct drainage axes for siting of irrigation canals and create bunded and levelled fields according to the topological conditions.

title: Rice Advice: an android based decision support tools for Nigeria
narrative: Android based decision support tools for providing farmers with field-specific management guidelines for rice production systems in Africa

title: Cropping calendar construction model
narrative: Excel-based decision support tool that can generate, compare and visualise opportunities for single/double/triple cropping systems consisting of irrigated rice and optionally a vegetable/legumes

title: Alternate wetting and drying (AWD) in Africa
narrative: Alternate wetting and drying is a water saving technology that enables irrigated rice cultivation with less water than the conventional practice of maintaining the field continuously flooded. Under AWD, ﬁelds are subjected to intermittent ﬂooding where irrigation is interrupted, and water is allowed to subside until the soil reaches a certain moisture level, after which the field is re-flooded. It has been reported that this technology can reduce water input and GHG without yield penalty.

title: Field Calculator for sustainable rice production
narrative: Field Calculator (FC) is a decision support tool for sustainable rice production. The Field Calculator is a web-based application for data collection and impact assessment of inputs and practices in rice production with the aim to provide insights and options for optimization towards sustainability. Functionality of FC: (1) collect day-to-day farmer rice crop management information and (2) calculate SRP standard scores and performance indicators for use by CORIGAP NARES partners and SRP adopters

title: Rice Doctor Odisha
narrative: Rice Doctor is a mid season diagnostic tool that aims to help  extension advisors, farmers and others have accurate and timely diagnosis of nearly 80 crop problems, which includes insect pests, diseases, nutrient deficiencies, toxicities and other abiotic problems. It also  offers information on these problems as well as recommendations  in  order to  address the  crop problems it  was able to diagnose.

title: AutoMonPH- a decision tool for system level water management using Alternate Wetting and Drying (water-saving technology) principle
narrative: An automated decision tool for catalyzing the adoption of water-saving technologies such as Alternate Wetting and Drying by improving access to information, effective coordination among stakeholders, and transparency in water governance.

title: Improved community-led water governance approach in Bangladesh
narrative: Engaging with communities to employ more pragmatic land-use planning and scheduling of sluice gate operations has shown the potential to intensify and diversify cropping systems, and increasing production by 2-3 fold. This was achieved using improved rice varieties and non-rice crops, enabled by strategic management of the sluice gates to drain the lands as needed during the wet season and to facilitate timely establishment of non-rice crops after rice harvest.
evidence_link: https://pubag.nal.usda.gov/catalog/6872221. Yadav, M. Mondal, A. Shew, S.V.K. Jagadish, Z.H. Khan, A. Sutradhar, H. Bhandari, E. Humphreys, J. Bhattacharya, R. Parvin, M. Rahman, P. Chandna. Making inroads to intensify agricultural productivity in the polders of the coastal zone of Bangladesh. Paper submitted to Water Resource Management on Jan 4, 2019.

title: EasyHarvest: App for optimized combine harvester scheduling
narrative: App for linking farmers with harvesting contract service providers / combine harvester operators for scheduling harvesting operations, matching field conditions with available machine types and optimizing the scheduling.  http://easyharvest.irri.org/

title: Laser land leveling in Cambodia and Vietnam
narrative: Precision land leveling using a stationary laser plane at the side of the field, a 4-wheel tractor pulled drag bucket equipped with a laser-guided and hydraulic controlled and system. Laser leveling allows field leveling with +/-1cm accuracy and leads to water savings (20-40%), increased yields 10-20%, better weed control and can also be used for field consolidation for improved mechanization. The technology was adapted and verified in Cambodia and Vietnam

title: Laser land leveling in Indonesia, Philippines, Myanmar, Sri Lanka
narrative: Precision land leveling using a stationary laser plane at the side of the field, a 4-wheel tractor pulled drag bucket equipped with a receiver, control box and hydraulics to keep the drag bucket at the same height with reference to the laser plane. Laser leveling allows field leveling with +/-1cm accuracy and leads to water savings (40-60%), increased yields 10-20%, better weed control and can also be used for field consolidation for improved mechanization.

title: Diversification options with cassava, maize, and pulses in upland rice based cropping systems in highlands in Madagascar
narrative: We are conducting field experiments for developing crop diversification options that can improve soil fertility and reduce damage from pest in upland rice based cropping systems in Madagascar.

title: Optimized downdraft rice husk furnace for paddy drying
narrative: This furnace was developed for paddy drying that resulted in an improved air-cooled grate with optimal operation to generate sufficient heat for a paddy flatbed dryer of 4 t/batch, attaining an efficiency of 80%. The furnace principle has potential to overcome the problems of existing small-scale rice husk furnaces, i.e., high labor requirements, uneven temperatures, low energy efficiency, and high levels of pollution. About 200 units were already used for paddy drying in the Philippines.

title: Novel training for rice farmers on postproduction and market access
narrative: The 2-week course Rice: Post-production to Market introduces participants from all sectors, including research, extension, NGOs and private sector representatives, to critical issues and challenges in reducing postproduction losses. The course includes practical and theoretical exams and a certification, and is innovative in that it links postproduction processes all the way up to markets. Training course was provided to 18 participants from several Asian countries at IRRI Headquarters.

title: A new technology for rice straw pelleting in Vietnam
narrative: Technology to produce rice straw pellets, which are later used for bioenergy production and animal feed.

title: Technology for out-door rice straw mushroom production
narrative: Technology for using rice straw to safely grow mushrooms out-door in the tropical countries. It was adapted from an existing practice in Vietnam and verified. The technological steps and parameters for rice straw mushroom growing were established.

title: Household batch system for Anaerobic digestion of rice straw
narrative: This technology was developed by IRRI using a hermetic bag (so called IRRI super bag) to make the digesters.  Rice straw and animal manure are arranged in layers in the digester. Rice straw is spread on the first layer then covered by a manure layer. It has advantages: low investment cost; avoiding rice straw floating; portable; and the digestate can use as a good organic compost.

title: Training Module: Life Cycle Assessment for Rice Production including new approach for identify best management practices
narrative: This training module was developed for sustainability analysis and best practice identification based on Life Cycle Assessment. It includes the new approach for establishing boundary and input - output flows of rice production, postharvest management, and by-product management. It was applied for several case studies in The Philippines, Myanmar, and Vietnam.

title: Vocational training program for Agricultural Machinery Mechanics
narrative: Various institutions from the Government and development projects are providing technical innovations like rice seeders, fertilizer spreaders, land leveling equipment, mechanical weeding, and equipment for grain and seed cleaning but often lack capacity for integration and 'delivery'. Value chain support services like after sales service provision or financing are only rudimentarily developed.   To increase Cambodia’s innovation system capacity IRRI and Don Bosco in Battambang developed a vocational training program for Agricultural Machinery Mechanics.

title: A Novel Rice Quality Assessment Kit
narrative: The IRRI Rice Quality Assessment Kit consists of a set of various tools that help measuring one or several paddy, milled rice or seed quality traits. It is intended to be used in postharvest and other quality related training courses but several of the kits have already been purchased by millers and other value chain actors to help them in their daily tasks too. It is used globally by millers, extension workers, etc.

title: m-Health application, a mobile/web-based application making real-time information on service delivery and beneficiary nutrition status available to community-based health workers
narrative: A mobile/web-based application designed to help Anganwadi workers  (community based front line workers in India's Integrated Child Development Services program) deliver services effectively and efficiently. At the supervisory level, it makes real-time information available on service delivery and beneficiary nutrition status at sector, block, district, state and national level.

title: Protocol for developing sub-national nutrition scorecards, a tool to advance accountability for nutrition
narrative: Scorecards are an increasingly popular instrument aiming to advance accountability for nutrition. Often devised at national level, growing interest is now emerging in subnational application. A 2019 paper, authored by A4NH strategic partner in Flagship 4, the Institute of Development Studies (IDS), describes a protocol for how a subnational scorecard may be developed in a participatory manner, summarizing the experience of doing so in two districts of Tanzania: Morogoro and Kigoma.

title: Suite of resources for implementers on how to mainstream nutrition behavior change communication into agricultural projects in Uganda
narrative: Building on prior recommendations to incorporate social and behavior change communications (SBCC) into the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD)'s nutrition-sensitive projects, Bioversity researchers co-developed practical guidance for determining entry points, key target audiences, or exactly what projects should do.

title: Relevance of child stunting as an outcome of interest in programs targeting undernutrition
narrative: Stunting in nontechnical terms means children being too short for their age. A 2019 review by IFPRI researchers suggested how stunting should and should not be used as an outcome of interest in addressing undernutrition. In many cases a focus on linear growth retardation and stunting isn't necessary to improve well-being; in other cases, it's not sufficient; and for some outcomes, it's not the most cost-efficient strategy.

title: Methods for measuring the cost of the most affordable nutritionally adequate diet in a country
narrative: In 2018, IFPRI researchers began applying a methodology for measuring and analyzing food affordability and constraints, including relative price measures, price decompositions and economy-wide simulation analyses. The most high-profile application to date has resulted in a finding that the universal diet recommended by the EAT-Lancet Commission on Food Planet, Health meant to improve human and planetary health would be unaffordable for at least 1.58 billion people, mostly in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia (https://www.ifpri.org/news-release/new-study-intended-help-human-planetary-health-eat-lancet-diet-too-costly-158-billion).

title: Framework on how to leverage neglected and underutilized species (NUS) to improve nutrition
narrative: Operational framework for the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD) . This builds on prior evidence from Bioversity (and others) that demonstrated how effective conservation and use of NUS improves food and nutrition security, strengthens adaptation to climate change, and supports empowerment of poor and vulnerable groups to come out of poverty and social marginalization.

title: MINCER micrometerological station used to improve spikelet sterility estimations in crop models
narrative: Tools were developed for the adaptation of crop models to improve rice spikelet sterility induced by extreme temperatures.  A radiation-shielded, solar-powered, force-ventilated system that is designed to facilitate its use by researchers to  accurately measure the thermal environment within the canopy.

title: Multiline variety for blast resistance
narrative: Near isogeneic lines set for blast resistance genes with IR 64 genetic background, for irrigated lowlands in Africa and Asia

title: Digital platform for video-based agricultural extension in Ethiopia
narrative: A PIM-supported impact evaluation provided key evidence on the benefits of the video-mediated extension approach in Ethiopia. In 2019, The Government of Ethiopia launched a project aimed at developing a digital platform for video-mediated advisory services for smallholder farmers throughout Ethiopia. This platform will deliver location- and time-specific advice to farmers across multiple channels (video, SMS, radio, etc.), with the aim of boosting agricultural productivity.

title: Aflasafe MWMZ01 and Aflasafe MZ02 for Mozambique
narrative: Biocontrol approach to preventing aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Map Yemen: An online database for improving food and nutrition security in Yemen
narrative: MAP Yemen is an online database which provides an overview of the state of food and nutrition security in Yemen at the aggregate and project level in order to effectively allocate funds, build synergies and evaluate future proposals. For example, users can search development projects by governorate, category and international partner and relate these projects to the prevalence of hunger and stunting.

title: Aflasafe BF01 for Burkina Faso
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts in Burkina Faso with potential use in 10 other countries in the Sahel.

title: Aflasafe GH01 and Aflasafe GH02 for Ghana
narrative: Biocontrol approach to preventing aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe TZ01 and Aflasafe TZ02 for Tanzania
narrative: Biocontrol approach to preventing aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe MWMZ01 and Aflasafe MW02 for Malawi
narrative: Biocontrol approach to preventing aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Infrastructure mapping and strategy engagements
narrative: The Platform conducted co-design workshops on building a unified information vision cutting across 6 CGIAR centers, research domains, and partners that is being used to inform IT investment decisions and is becoming a critical input to Big Data efforts to develop a pan-CGIAR digital strategy. The effort informed the design and deployment of a pan-CGIAR data analytic environment.

title: Demonstrated economic benefits of community forest concessions make the case for continued community stewardship of 400,000 hectares of tropical forests in Guatemala
narrative: PIM research highlighted the socioeconomic benefits of 12 community forest concessions in the Maya Biosphere Reserve in Peten, Guatemala. These findings provided the National Council for Protected Areas, in charge of the concessions, with the evidence needed for revising the norms for forest concessions and renewing a first concession contract (Cooperative Carmelita).

title: AfricaRice weather: a free web-database
narrative: Web-based database for sharing weather data collected by AfricaRice and its partners for free

title: Development of improved wet-milled rice flour product (Rice flakes)
narrative: Traditional wet-rice milled products are common in Southeast Asia. We are investigating the various properties and production process of the traditional system to explore opportunities for the development of improved or novel rice products.

title: Pop-rice is a novel product made from rice, a product analogous to popcorn made from corn.
narrative: Pop-rice is a novel product made from rice. Rough rice heated with certain high temperature (around 200 deg C) is popped to result into 'pop-rice' - a product analogous to popcorn made from corn.

title: Weather-rice-nutrient integrated decision support system (WeRise) in Indonesia
narrative: WeRise is a seasonal climate prediction-based decision support system for rainfed rice farmers through integration of statistical downscaling model of GCM (global climate model) and crop growth model. WeRise provides an optimum variety, and timing for sowing and fertilizer application which are key information to deal with yield increase in rainfed.

title: Identification of a high-Zinc IRRI-Genebank accession and associated chromosomal positions
narrative: Zinc (Zn) content in the grain is a critical micronutrient for human development and nutrition. Current levels in the grain are far below daily recommendations for consumption. This study identified accessions (Jamir, UCP222) from the aus types that have much higher levels of zinc and increased iron in the grain. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) identified peaks on Chromosomes 5, 7, and 9. Populations have been developed and quantitaive trait loci (QTL) validated.
evidence_link: link to paper to be done

title: Weather-rice-nutrient integrated decision support system (WeRise) in Philippines
narrative: WeRise is a seasonal climate prediction-based decision support system for rainfed rice farmers through integration of statistical downscaling model of GCM and crop growth model. WeRise provides an optimum variety, and timing for sowing and fertilizer application which are key information to deal with yield increase in rainfed rice.

title: Rice Crop Manager - Odisha
narrative: Rice Crop Manager (RCM), which works on the principles of Site-Specific-Nutrient Management, is an application that could be accessed via a smartphone or a computer with net connectivity. It allows extension officers to give farmers a specific recommendation on nutrient management, depending on the specific variety they use, their yield from the previous season, and the site-specific conditions of their field.  RCM derives the nutrient management recommendations from Oryza Version3, an eco-physiological crop growth model.

title: Rice Crop Manager - Philippines
narrative: Rice Crop Manager (RCM) is a decision-making tool designed for use by extension workers, crop advisors, agricultural service providers, and farmer leaders who use RCM through the web browser of a personal computer, tablet, or smartphone. After the interview, collected information can be stored on the computer, tablet, or smartphone until the device is connected to the Internet through a web browser. Each guideline provides an actionable recommendation, with location-specific cropping practices.

title: Rice Crop Manager - Myanmar
narrative: Rice Crop Manager (RCM) is a decision-making tool designed for use by extension workers, crop advisors, agricultural service providers, and farmer leaders who use the internet to access RCM through the web browser of a personal computer, tablet, or smartphone. Currently, focus group discussions and key informant interviews are being conducted to understand farmer practices and fertilizer use.

title: Weather-rice-nutrient integrated decision support system (WeRise) in Madagascar
narrative: WeRise is a seasonal climate prediction-based decision support system for rainfed rice farmers through integration of statistical downscaling model of GCM and crop growth model. WeRise provides an optimum variety, and timing for sowing and fertilizer application which are key information to deal with yield increase in rainfed rice.

title: Enhanced P-cycling with stylosanthes (Stylosanthes guianensis) in upland rice-based cropping systems
narrative: Soils in the lowland and upland rice fields were found to be mostly P deficient with high P-fixation by Al- and Fe- oxides in the central highland of Madagascar. Introducing stylosanthes (Stylosanthes guianensis) having its high Fe-P solubilizing capacity as a cover/relay crop can enhance phosphorus cycling in upland rice-based cropping systems.

title: Toolkit to capture diversity and drivers of food choice of a target population to identify entry points for novel food products and nutritional interventions
narrative: The toolkit aims at capturing diversity and drivers of food choice of a target population to identify entry points for novel food products and nutritional interventions. It proposes a novel framework of "gastronomic systems research" (GSR) and a research protocol with six components: (1) expert elicitation workshop; (2) standardization of food dishes in nutritional laboratory; (3) consumer survey, (4) use of an interactive tablet application; (5) behavioral change communication strategy; and (6) behavioral experiments.

title: Validation of genes that control stomate number affecting rice photosynthesis
narrative: Stomate number is an important trait affecting photosynthesis through gas exchange and transpiration. The innovation concerns the identification of  OsEPFL9 which was validated by knock out.
evidence_link: Publication planned; reported in prior meetings

title: GEM and Mini GEM: two novel parboiling technologies for West-Africa
narrative: An artisanal parboiling technology called Grain quality-enhancer, Energy efficient and durable Material (GEM) combines better soaking, steaming and drying to improve grain quality, reduce energy use and drudgery at the benefit of women who dominate the parboiling industry in Africa. The specificity of the Mini-GEM system is its ability to use rice husk, an underutilized biomass as parboiling fuel in place of wood, thus cutting parboiling cost and blackening of parboiling vessels.

title: Sheath blight tolerance, phenotyping, Genome-Wide Association Study, and validation
narrative: Sheath blight is an important problem affecting yield in the humid tropics under closed canopy, irrigated conditions. Relatively few donors are available and little is known about the genetics of the interaction. This study has identified donors and a putative effector that can be targeted for improved tolerance.
evidence_link: Publication planned; reported in prior meetings.

title: Training on investment in upgraded milling technologies in West Africa
narrative: The innovation consists of a training 'architecture' directed to private actors planning to invest/having invested in upgraded milling technologies in West Africa, and to development organizations supporting them. The training addresses the socio-economic management of milling technologies in order to maximize the volumes of quality rice processed: market opportunities in West Africa; Options for location; Options for milling technologies; Options for paddy collection models; Main risks for milling investments and how to address them

title: TOGGLe, a flexible framework for easily building complex workflows and performing robust large-scale NGS analyses
narrative: TOGGLe (Toolbox for Generic NGS Analyses), a simple and highly flexible framework to easily and quickly generate pipelines for large-scale second-and third-generation sequencing analyses, including multi-threading support. TOGGLe comprises a workflow manager designed to be as effortless as possible to use for biologists, so the focus can remain on the analyses. Embedded pipelines are easily customizable and supported analyses are reproducible and shareable.

title: Food Choice Application (FCA): An interactive tablet application for capturing diversity of food choice
narrative: The FCA maps the weekly food portfolio of a household by featuring all dish options that can be consumed during a set of eating occasions over seven days of the week. Respondents can specify the number of servings of the dishes their household are planning to consume using up/down buttons in half steps of servings. As the servings increase, a budget bar indicates the available percent budget left for the household to invest.

title: Identification of non-commonly shared specific genes in wild and cultivated African rices and identification of its cradle of its domestication to be in the Inner Niger Delta
narrative: Pan/core genomics in O. glaberrima and O. barthii. The analysis of unmapped sequences from the genomic resource of the IRIGIN (International RIce Genomics INitiative) project led to the identification of 330 Mb for wild, 225 Mb for cultivated of dispensable genome (~ 300 putative genes per individual). Using 246 new whole-genome sequences, we inferred the cradle of its domestication to be in the Inner Niger Delta.

title: Identification of common genes in cultivated and wild Asian rice (core genome)
narrative: Determination of core-genome/genes for 50 O. rufipogon and 490 O. sativa accessions. Gene loss during domestication under investigation

title: Low glycemic rice variety
narrative: Variety of rice that shows both low glycemic index and slow digesting properties after consumption.

title: Two blast-resistant elite rice lines with Pi9 introgressed
narrative: Blast resistance is highly important globally, CIAT developed two elite breeding  lines with Pi9 introgressed trough the development of Molecular markers for Pi9 and the back crossing assisted selection.

title: ASI and Mini-ASI Thresher to separate rice grains from the panicle
narrative: The ASI thresher mechanically separates the rice grains from the panicle without damaging the grains. The ASI is adapted to the conditions of manual harvesting. It has a capacity 2.5 ton/h, low operating costs, drudgery and can be manufactured locally. When ASI-threshing is combined with optimum harvesting time, grain loss can be reduced by 23%. The Mini-ASI thresher is the smaller model of the ASI-Thresher (0.6 tons/h) that can be trailed by a motorcycle.

title: Development and out-scaling of ISRIZ09, an aromatic hybrid rice variety for Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: There is a strong demand for aromatic rice in Africa such as in Ghana, Senegal, Tanzania, Mozambique and Uganda. However, many aromatic rice varieties often yield lower than non-aromatic varieties. AfricaRice has developed several hybrids that combined aroma with high yield potential. One of these hybrids, ISRIZ09, has been released in Senegal in 2017 and many African private companies have expressed strong interest in the hybrid

title: Development and out-scaling of Sub1-introgressed submergence tolerant rice in Madagascar
narrative: In Madagascar, tropical storms (cyclones) can be very devastating to the rice crop. AfricaRice introgressed Sub-1 gene in 5 popular varieties which are widely grown in Madagascar, namely, BOTRY, B453-F-SR-6-3, FOFIFA160, FOFIFA162, IR15579-24-52 for use in flood-prone rainfed lowland areas and poorly-drained irrigated lowlands.

title: Increased sustainability of rice-based systems through use of beneficial rice-microbe associations
narrative: In order to meet the ever-increasing demand for rice, huge quantities of fertilizers are used especially in irrigated lowlands, often with negative impacts on the environment. AfricaRice and its partners have identified a combination of a mycorrhiza and plant growth-promoting bacteria which can increase yields of certain rice varieties significantly under irrigated lowland conditions at half the recommended fertilizer rate.

title: Red rice improvement for human nutrition and abiotic stress tolerance in Madagascar
narrative: Red rice is important for Madagascar in terms of food and nutritional value. However, traditional red rice varieties are low yielding and susceptible to several biotic and abiotic stresses. AfricaRice has introduced advance lines of red rice lines from its breeding program to Madagascar

title: Development of transgressive Tongil varieties to increase yield potentials in irrigated and rainfed lowlands
narrative: Generally, African rice farmers prefer early maturing rice varieties. However, early maturing varieties yield less than late maturing varieties due to short growth duration. To increase yield potential of early-maturing varieties, KAFACI rice breeding program of AfricaRice used Korean germplasm with transgressive segregation for high biomass and earliness and created breeding populations combining high biomass and early maturity. These lines are found to have high yield potential with longer panicle, strong culms and more grains.
evidence_link: KH Kang, 2019. Globalization of Domestic Agricultural technology and Cooperation with AfricaRice: Tongil-type Rice Development for 2nd Green Revolution in Africa. Presented at NICS, Symposium, 4th Sept. 2019, Seoul, S. Korea.

title: Validation of the interdisciplinary construct of rice quality in Asia
narrative: We conduct an expert-based literature review and "stacked" value chain survey comprising of large-scale consumer surveys and key informant interviews with industry stakeholders to assess (1) how rice quality is defined by consumers, industry, food scientists, and geneticists; and (2) geographic heterogeneity of consumer preferences and the drivers of demand for quality traits. These insights highlight the need to standardize international quality indicators for rice and can assist market-driven and gender-responsive rice breeding programs.
evidence_link: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gfs.2016.05.005; https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0150345; https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tifs.2019.07.039; https://doi.org/10.1108/JADEE-09-2017-0092; British Food Journal article is forthcoming

title: Policy sequencing framework for rice value chain upgrading
narrative: A three-stage policy sequence required to upgrade rice value chains is developed for import-biased countries. The first stage focuses on enhancing rice quality though contracts, the improvement of post-harvest practices, and investment in modern milling technologies. The second stage consists of scaling through investment in irrigation infrastructure, productivity enhancement and storage infrastructure as well as of supporting the working capital of millers. The third stage involves advertising to increase consumer demand for domestic rice.

title: SENACA FL-09: a new improved rice variety for Ecuador
narrative:
Rice variety with improved yield from CIAT/FLAR germplasm (VIOFLAR 2003 nursery) released in 2009 in Ecuador by the seeds company PRONACA. Rice variety with improved yield widely used in irrigated rice producing systems in Ecuador. The variety has been used by 3,851 farmers between 2014 and 2019. 
http://sipa.agricultura.gob.ec/index.php/informe-de-rendimientos-objetivos/rendimiento-de-arroz https://www.researchgate.net/publication/305701237_Estudio_de_adopcion_de_variedades_modernas_y_practicas_agronomicas_mejoradas_de_Arroz_en_Ecuador 
https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2352340918303706

title: New method and indicator for measuring women's empowerment through gamification
narrative: We developed a novel indicator of women’s intrahousehold decision-making power (WIDMP). The indicator is based on the relative Euclidean distances between the women's and men's individual and joint varietal trait improvements portfolios elicited through the Investment Game Application (IGA). IGA is an interactive tablet application for digital product profiling (featured separately as an innovation).

title: Rice straw downdraft furnace for paddy drying
narrative: The downdraft rice straw furnace was newly developed by IRRI for a 4-ton paddy flatbed dryer in 2019. This was adapted from the downdraft rice husk furnace which was also developed by a consortium led by IRRI.
