Factorial and optimization combustion experiments on the furnace connected to a paddy flatbed dryer simulator were performed to maximize drying air efficiency and minimize cost. Its heating efficiency from straw combustion is 50-60%.

title: Eight (8) rice varieties from CIAT/FLAR origin, available for farmers in Costa Rica, adapted to direct seeding planting system
narrative: Since 2012 Eight rice varieties have been released in Costa Rica by the seed company "Semillas del Nuevo Milienio", well adapted to the direct seeding planting system. Rice varieties and year of releasing are: Sierpe FL 250 (2010); Garabito FL 163 (2012); Lazarroz FL (2016); Nayudel FL (2016); Nayureb FL (2016); ; Sibu FL (2016); SENUMISA 20 FL (2018); Cuenca FL (2018).

title: Paddy drying simulation models
narrative: The simulation models for paddy drying with flatbed dryers and recirculating cross-flow columnar dryer were developed by IRRI in collaboration with PhilMech in the Philippines and Nong Lam University in Vietnam. The models can be used to predict the optimized performance and simulating the paddy drying process.

title: SENACA FL11: a new improved rice variety for Ecuador
narrative: Rice variety from CIAT/FLAR origin (VIOFLAR 2006 nursery)  widely used in irrigated rice producing systems in Ecuador, with good yield and cooking quality

title: New method and indicators for measuring inclusiveness of value chain upgrading
narrative: Devising correct and targeted policies for fostering inclusiveness in value chain upgrading crucially hinges on deploying correct econometric specification of the decision to participate in value chain upgrading. To illustrate this, we model participation in and intensity of value chain upgrading in four different ways along the vertical coordination continuum: as a discrete, categorical, ordered, and continuous choice.  The method evaluates and juxtaposes several indicators of inclusiveness of value chain upgrading.

title: L23: a new rice line for the colombian uplands
narrative: Promising lines identified for different regions in rainfed lowland and mega deltas ecosystems and superior lines with disease resistance, improved yield and grain quality nominated and release for upland environment in Latin America

title: Village level value chain upgrading for linking farmers to markets in Myanmar
narrative: This innovation consists of a bundle of technologies and methodologies which are combined on demand including mechanized harvesting, mechanical drying, hermetic storage, the quality kit, and the Learning alliances as multi stakeholder platforms to embrace the different stakeholders and link the farmers to markets. It can also include strengthening of value chain support services for local manufacturing or making available technologies.

title: Rice straw processing for ruminant feeding supplement
narrative: The technology improves rice straw based fodder through pre-treatment (optimization process) and enrichment of rice straw with urea or molasses.

title: Pacific FL15 and Golfo FL 16: two (2) high-yielding and long-grained rice varieties available for seeds production and commercialization in Mexico
narrative: During 2012-2015 these varieties were selected, from advanced inbred lines delivered by CIAT/FLAR: FL07562-7P-3-3P-2P-M-150pZa-250pZa0Za and FL08224-3P-2-1P-3P-M-150pZa-250pZa-0Za. They have stable yield potential, both in the Pacific and the Gulf of Mexico regions. In 2016 these varieties were released by the National Institute of Forestry, Agricultural and Livestock Research (INIFAP, by its acronym in Spanish) and registered by the National Seed Inspection and Certification Service, named as Pacific FL15 and Golfo FL 16

title: Investment Game Application (IGA): A new interactive tablet application for digital product profiling for rice breeding
narrative: The Investment Game Application (IGA) is an interactive tablet application that can help value chain actors (farmers, seed suppliers, traders and processors) design their optimal product profiles for rice breeding. IGA features 11 trait improvement bars with risk diagrams visualizing the probability of success of each improvement. Traits can be improved from a baseline to a target value while costs are deduced from the budget bar and expected stochastic returns are returned in real time.

title: CIAT BIO-44, a new rice line with 25 ppm Zinc considered for release by Colombia
narrative: The CIAT BIO-44 + zinc variety contains 38 percent more zinc than traditional rice. It was launched in Bolivia, in February 2019 with more than 600 attendees present

title: Indicators and protocol to identify sustainable post harvest management practices
narrative: The indicators and protocol to identify sustainable post harvest management practices were developed by using Life-Cycle Assessment approach. These were used to identify best drying practices and sustainable post harvest management in Vietnam and Myanmar.

title: Herramientas de Costo de Produccion del Arroz CIAT-FLAR v3.3; Tool to compute cost of rice production
narrative: This tool can register the production cost and generate analysis charts. La herramienta es un Libro de Microsoft Excel 2016 ®, el cual consiste de 11 hojas de cálculo que colectan información de costos de producción para el cultivo del arroz a nivel de cada finca o unidad productiva, además de un menú principal y una hoja para recolectar información básica del usuario e instrucciones para completar la herramienta con la información necesaria.

title: GRDB 14 FL: rice variety available for seeds production and commercialization in Guyana
narrative: Guyana has one of the highest per capita rice consumption in America and is one the of major rice exporters in the region. CIAT/FLAR has provided improved germplasm over the last 15 years. From this germplasm collection, a rice varieties was released in 2014 by the Guyana Rice Development Board (GRDB), named GRDB 14 FL.

title: Technology and Business model for mechanized rice straw collection
narrative: Technology and business model for mechanized rice straw collection were developed by IRRI in collaboration with Nong Lam University and PhilRice. The business model includes the key information on its establishment, operation, marketing, and sustainable promotion such as business model canvas, finance, feedstock potential, markets, energy efficiency, and greenhouse gas emission balance.

title: Market-based incentive mechanism for adoption of sustainable production standards throughout rice value chains
narrative: We develop and pilot a market-based incentive mechanism for the adoption of sustainable production standards throughout rice value chains. We elicit consumers’ willingness-to-pay (WTP) for rice produced and labeled under a national sustainable production standard through experimental auctions under gradually-increasing levels of information on certification and traceability. Findings suggest that sustainable production labels for rice should be accompanied by supplementary information on certification and traceability to increase consumers’ awareness and appreciation of sustainably-produced rice.

title: MAC 18 FL: a widely grown rice variety in Bolivia with preferred grain appearance and cooking quality
narrative: Variety planted in more than 30% of the rice growing area in Bolivia, with extra-long grain and good cooking quality. This variety was released from a CIAT/FLAR line. Variety planted in more than 30% of the rice growing area in Bolivia, with extra-long grain and good cooking quality. This variety was released from a CIAT/FLAR line. A total of 254,071 farmers used the variety in 2019

title: Optimized mechanised rice harvesting in Southeast Asia
narrative: We developed the guideline and standard which is included in the Sustainable Rice Platform standard for optimizing mechanized harvesting management based on harvesting time, minimized losses, and maximized operation efficiency and effectiveness. The standard and guideline has been applied in several countries such as Vietnam, Cambodia, and Myanmar.

title: Improvement of African rice (O. glaberrima) collection to enhance its nutritional profile
narrative: The high starch content of rice has raised concerns that its high consumption can increase risks of diabetes and other debilitating diseases associated with high sugar content. AfricaRice has thus started to screen its African rice (O. glaberrima) collection and also some released varieties in order to identify accessions with good nutritional profiles such as slow digesting starch which will then be integrated into its varietal improvement program.
evidence_link: Wambugu et al. 2018, Plant Biotechnol J. 16:100–110: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5785344/

title: An automated approach for mapping inland valleys
narrative: We developed an automated approach for mapping inland valleys from digital elevation models (DEM), which utilizes three main attributes of inland valleys, namely lowness in the local landscape, wetness in the local landscape and lower stream order. The approach is a fuzzy-based morphometric approach that allows for broad-scale inland valley morphometry as well as smaller valleys to be delineated without unnecessary detail.

title: 3-D printing of spare parts for agricultural machinery in developing countries
narrative: The lack of spare parts and low quality parts of locally made parts are a major bottleneck in mechanisation of agriculture in developing countries.  This proof-of-concept pilot project, based in the Philippines and Cambodia, demonstrated the exciting benefits of using three-dimensional (3D) printing technology, also called additive manufacturing (AM), for supplying needed parts for agricultural equipment in a timely manner. This included technologies for printing, scanning, economic competitiveness, IPR and business models for service provision.

title: Precision fertiliser application in Asia
narrative: Fertilizer and agrochemical application is mostly done manually in Asia with negative effects on health, yields and environment. We tested a battery operated granule applicator that can be mounted on different tool carrier platforms and allows very precise and even application. It was complemented by a sprayer unit for multi purpose use of the hardware. Modification of rice transplanter machines into general tool carriers was discussed with transplanter suppliers.

title: Consortium for direct seeded rice for Asia
narrative: The Direct Seeded Rice Consortium (DSRC) is a public-private multi-stakeholder research for development (R4D) platform on direct-seeded rice. The DSRC has the overall goal of improving the environmental and economic sustainability of rice production systems in Asia by developing and scaling science-based comprehensive mechanized and precise DSR practices. Currently, there are 26 members of the consortium, 8 are from private sectors, three are international Foundation/NGO/Association, and 15 are public sector national and international institutions.

title: Three simple recipes for bio fortified rice/wheat biscuits in Africa
narrative: Three types of biscuits made from 50 % rice-wheat composite flours and fortified with safou (Dacryodes edulis) or vitamins [Rice Powder Premix (WE-26446), The WrightGroup, USA].  These biscuits are simple rice-wheat, safou-fortified rice-wheat and vitamin-fortified rice-wheat. A safou-fortified biscuit provides mainly minerals (Mg, K, Fe, Zn) and essential fatty acid (linoleic acid) while a vitamin-fortified biscuit provides vitamins (Folic acid, Thiamin, Niacin, Cobalamin, Vitamin E) and minerals (Selenium and Zinc).

title: Multipurpose grinder
narrative: The multipurpose grinder is a modified hammer mill with interchangeable sieves for the grinding of cereals, rice husk and other dry agricultural residues. The grinder blades are made from stainless to increase depreciation time and the grinding capacity depends on the hardness of the material being powdered.

title: Multi-Piston briquetting technology
narrative: The AfricaRice Multi-Piston briquetter is a manual briquetting machine that can produce 45—144kg briquettes/day (11% moisture content) depending on the type hydraulic system (Stargold® or Yale® jack). The biomass to be briquetted is grinded and mixed with water and appropriate binder and introduced into the system. The material is compressed, removed and sun-dried.

title: Gasifier cookstove technology for households and artisanal processing
narrative: The biomass gasification technologies adapted at AfricaRice employs top-lit updraft (TLUD) solar or non-solar powered 12-volt fan-assisted gasification process to convert different types of biomass - rice husk, palm kernel shell, groundnut shell, cashew nut shell, shear butter shell, wood chips, cowdung cake or their pellets into clean heat energy. Two types of gasifiers are available; low output gasifiers for outdoor cooking in rural areas and high output gasifier for artisanal processing industries e.g. parboiling.

title: Husk fuelled flatbed dryer
narrative: The husk fuelled flatbed dryer is a reversible cereal and vegetable dryer enhanced by sand-silica gel columns. The dryer can use wood or other biomass fuel such as rice husk. The dryer has a capacity of 2 tons, and it made of steel sheets that are properly sealed to reduce air exchange with environment except at the heating point.

title: Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP) Standard and Performance Indicators in Africa
narrative:
SRP Performance Indicators are designed to assess sustainability improvements resulting from changes in farm practice, and include profitability, labor and land productivity, food safety, resource use efficiency, climate change mitigation, labor conditions, and
women empowerment. The Standard defines a set of key requirements with different levels of performance allowing for a stepwise improvement and compliance process.

title: Global Yield Gap and Water Productivity Atlas (GYGA) for rice in Africa
narrative: The GYGA provides robust estimates of untapped crop production potential on existing farmland. The Atlas provides a range of information related yield gap, nutrient gap, and water productivity, offering relevant data to policy makers, researchers and industry.

title: Upland rice-based cropping systems with conservation agriculture in Ivory Coast
narrative: Alternative cropping systems for improving soil quality, system productivity, and climate resilience, as well as reducing weed and pest pressure. This include rice and maize together with forage legumes such as stylosanthes.

title: RiceAdvice-WeedManager
narrative: Andorid application for generating farm-specific advices for weed management to smallholder rice farmers for Android based smartphones and e-tablets

title: Maps of abiotic stresses for rice in Africa
narrative: Maps showing hotspots of the stresses, the countries most affected and total potentially affected area are developed. This can be useful for (1) prioritizing research and (2) identifying stress hotspots, for directing technologies and varieties to those areas where they are most needed.

title: ORYZA200 v2 : a new rice crop growth simulation model for climate change studies in Africa
narrative: ORYZA2000 was improved for assessing impact of climate change study and climate risk assessment in Africa.

title: RiceAdvice: an android-based application for rice crop management in Burkina Faso, Mali and Senegal
narrative: Android based decision support tools for providing farmers with field-specific management guidelines for rice production systems in Africa

title: RiceVideo: a web- based platform for good practices
narrative: RiceVideo is Web-based information-education-communication platform for promoting good practices for rice-based agri-food systems. Target users are extension workers, farmers and students. English and French videos are included. Topics includes rice-related activities ranging from seed to cooking.

title: Rice management options for salinity in Senegal River Valley
narrative: We are developing rice management options that combine nutrient management options with salt tolerant varieties for mitigation of negative impact of salinity in the Senegal River Valley.

title: Maps of rice area in Senegal River Valley based on MODIS time-series and the PhenoRice algorithm
narrative: We use the PhenoRice algorithm to track recent variations of rice cultivation practices along the Senegal River Valley over a 14-year period (2003–2016). Time series of MODIS imagery with 250 m spatial resolution and a nominal 8-days frequency were used as inputs for the algorithm. The spatial and temporal variations of rice cultivated area, crop establishment and harvesting dates, length of season, and cropping intensity were mapped for both the dry and the wet seasons.

title: RiceAdvice Voucher System: a new business approach to test the scaling of RiceAdvice with farmers paying service providers in Nigeria
narrative: The RiceAdvice Voucher System is a business approach to test the scaling of RiceAdvice among youth service providers, input dealers, and farmers. The system aims to have the farmers request and pay for services of service providers, as opposed to the project paying the service providers.

title: Smart-Valleys approach in Burkina Faso, Liberia and Sierra Leone
narrative: Smart-Valleys is a participatory approach used by smallholder farmers for land and water management for rice-based systems in inland valleys. The approach enables farmers to improve, at low cost, water control by using simple means to design and construct drainage axes for siting of irrigation canals and create bunded and leveled fields according to the topological conditions.

title: e-resilient-lowland: an e-learning toolkit to improve water control in West African rice producing countries
narrative: e-resilient-lowland is an e-learning toolkit to improve water control in lowland and the climate resilience of small-scale farmers.

title: Forced drainage water management technology in Côte d’Ivoire
narrative: Forced drainage is a water management technology that consists of intentionally draining the rice field for 1-2 weeks between later tillering and panicle differentiation stages. It is associated with opening the water outlet for forced drainage of surface water. Forced drainage is used to reduce non-productive tillers, to avoid lodging and enhance weather-resistance and to reduce methane emission from rice field.

title: Drought prediction in inland valleys rice-based production systems in the Sudan-Sahel Zone
narrative: An automated approach for predicting drought in inland valleys rice-based production systems that utilizes two main attributes: annual standardized precipitation evapotranspiration index (SPEI; an index that includes a comprehensive water balance) and duration of groundwater availability.

title: Optimal irrigation scheduling for off-season vegetable crops in Côte d'Ivoire
narrative: There is no recommendation on water management for off-season vegetable crops. We want to develop an optimal irrigation scheduling in the dry season to increase the yield of vegetable crops and water productivity

title: Ecological niche modelling approach for mapping potential irrigated rice area in West Africa
narrative: We are developing an ecological niche modelling approach for identifying potential areas for irrigated systems development based on freely available satellite imagery and spatial datasets on topography, soil, climate, and land use.

title: Water management options for malaria and climate change mitigation in intensified rice production
narrative: The water management options could reduce malaria transmission potential and greenhouse gas emission while increasing water productivity and rice yield. We are testing different water management options to identify suitable water management practices for the above targets.

title: Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) for improving rice productivity in Senegal
narrative: GAP is integration of management practices that encompasses land preparation options (bunding, puddling and leveling), crop establishment method, variety choice, weed  and nutrient management along with crop calendar and record-keeping for improved rice productivity.

title: Inland valley maps for potential for intensification in Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana
Good agricultural practices for enhancing rice productivity in Ghana
narrative: Country, ecology and production system-specific GAP practices are required for closing the rice yield and profit gaps with sustainability. Five component practices for Ghana (improved variety/seed; recommended fertilizer; good weed control; good land preparation (bunding, leveling and terracing); and good crop establishment (timely planting and in line using healthy seedling) have been identified as promising.

title: Good agricultural practices for enhancing rice productivity in Cote d'Ivoire
narrative: The recommended rate of fertilizer application; use of high yielding variety and quality seed; leveling and bunding the field; timely planting in line using healthy seedling; and good weed control are the five MUST DO GAP practices for rice in Cote d'Ivoire which can increase rice yield significantly and contribute the mission of self-sufficiency in rice.

title: Flash flood and submergence management with Sub-1 variety with direct seeding in Côte d'Ivoire
narrative: Flash flooding and submergence are the common problems in many Inland Valleys (IVs) in West African countries causing either land fallow (farmers are unable to transplant rice) or delayed transplanting with old seedling or submergence of the transplanted field causing significant yield loss to complete crop failure. FARO-66 9 (Wita-4 with Sub-1) and FARO-67 (NERICA-L19 with Sub-1) varieties combined with wet-direct method of crop establishment are able to cope with such flooding and submergence.

title: Integrated Weed Management (IWM) in Rice in Côte d'Ivoire
narrative: Weed control in rice is a major challenge and causing >20% yield reduction. Increasing production and profitability with reduction of labor use is possible through the integrated weed management (IWM) consisting of use of selective and efficient herbicide molecules, the use of manual weeders (push and motorized), proper water management practices with good crop establishment.

title: Direct seeded rice using Drum Seeder
narrative: Using drum seeder to sow pre-germinated seed directly in the rice fields is alternative approach to puddled transplanted rice that is predominant method of rice establishment in many West-African countries. Transplanting requires large amount of water, costs, labor, and energy. In this method, rice will be seeded using drum seeder after puddling, leveling and drainage.

title: Rice-legume and vegetables rotation systems in lowlands in Côte d'Ivoire
narrative: Development of locally adapted rice-legume and vegetables rotation systems could increase food and nutritional security. Furthermore, the systems could boost soil carbon and nitrogen, provide nutritional support to the small-holder farmers, increase the system productivity, and reduce the weed pressure due to its smothering effect, driving the rice-based system towards the sustainable intensification.

title: Radio messaging on good agricultural practices in Côte d'Ivoire
narrative: Only science-based knowledge can bring a change in food and nutritional security in the 21st century. Reaching millions with such knowledge requires a lot of resources and efforts. Several types of mass-media are available to reach millions and radion messaging is one of them. We developed script based on our expert knowledge and results from field experiments on good agricultural practices and used it to develop radio message.

title: Mechanical seeders for direct seeded rice
narrative: Three different types of mechanical seeders were developed to save labor in direct seeded rice. The seeders were tested in lowland and upland conditions in Madagascar. The three manual seeders reduced the labour requirement by 60-70% compared to manual seeding. Received feedback from 222 farmers for further improvement and are being improved considering the farmers feedback.

title: Fertiseeder, a manual seeder cum fertilizer micro-dose applicator
narrative: A manual seeder cum fertilizer micro-dose applicator (Fertiseeder) developed to save labor in direct seeding and micro-dose placement. The fertiseeder was tested in lowland and upland conditions in Madagascar. Fertiseeder reduced the labour requirement by 74% compared to manual seeding and micro-dose placement. Received feedback from 222 farmers for further improvement and the fertiseeder is being improved considering the farmers feedback.

title: Two Adapted Motorized Weeder (AMW) for irrigated and rainfed lowland systems in sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: Locally adapted two-row Motorized Paddy Weeder (AMW) developed in collaboration with private fabricators. The weeder can be used in irrigated and rainfed lowland systems and can save labour for weeding up to 80%.

title: Two-row Motorized Paddy Weeder for Irrigated and Rainfed Lowland Systems
narrative: The locally adapted two-row Motorized Paddy Weeder is being developed in collaboration with private fabricators in Kenya, Uganda and Madagascar. The weeder can be used in irrigated and rainfed lowland systems and can save labour for weeding up to 80%.

title: Crop diversification options to improve farmers' livelihoods in Madagascar lowlands
narrative: Testing of crop diversification options by introducing different vegetables and legumes options lowland conditions before and after rice cultivation in wet season in highlands of Madagascar to improve rice productivity and increase profitability.

title: Mechanical weeders for rice production in Sub Saharan Africa
narrative:
Mechanical weeders could reduce labour requirements for weeding as well as the use of herbicides and be
instrumental in downsizing overall production costs. There are different types such as 1) ring hoe; 2) twisted-spike ﬂoating weeder; 3) curved-spike ﬂoating weeder; 4) straight-spike ﬂoating weeder; 5) straight spike weeder; 6) simple rotary weeder. 1 and 6 are new types for testing in Africa. Others existed before, but we tested in new sites.

title: Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) - Tanzania
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability.

title: Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) - Madagascar
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices (GAP) that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability. GAP components were modern cultivar, line planting, fertilizer application and rotary weeding.

title: Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) - Uganda
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices (GAP) that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability. GAP components were Variety Wita9, Line planting, 15-24day old seedlings, fertilizer application and timely harvesting.

title: Development of micronutrient fertilizer strategies for rice
narrative: Deficiency of micronutrients from soils is thought to be one of limiting factors for rice production in SSA. A combination of different micronutrients (Mg, S, Zn, B, Cu) increased the rice yields by 0.6 t/ha under irrigated lowland and by 1.8 t/ha under rainfed lowland conditions in Tanzania, when applied as a basal application, together with NPK fertilizers.

title: Release of Urochloa forage “Camello Blend (GP 3025 + GP 3207)” forage seeds in Bolivia, Ecuador and Paraguay
narrative: A blend of the Urochloa Camello hybrid and other forage varieties (GP3025 and GP3207) was released in Bolivia, Ecuador and Paraguay by our private sector partner, Papalotla. [Blend = a mixed bag of two Urochloa forage hybrids (corresponding to the CIAT hybrid codes CIAT BR04/3025 and CIAT BR04/3207), both from the same population of promising hybrids created in 2004.]
evidence_link: not yet available (evidence will be provided by private sector partner by mid-2020)

title: New forage variety (Panicum maximum cv. “Sabanera”) released in Colombia
narrative: Under the Colombian Forage Network, a new forage variety  (Panicum maximum cv. “Sabanera”) was released in Colombia by our Colombian NARS partner AGROSAVIA. The traits of interest for this material are: 1. Forage production; 2. Forage quality; and 3. Animal productivity.

title: New barley genotypes identified with superior forage, grain and biomass production after cutting
narrative: 9 barley Genotypes selected for 2nd year field trials. 28 new barley genotypes identified with superior early vigor and fodder and grain production for first year field trials.

title: Guidelines for cactus pear establishment and maintenance in India
narrative: Cactus pear as an alternative fodder reserve is a new concept for most farmers in India.  In addition to changing perceptions, promotion of best agronomic practices is needed to facilitate wider adoption.

title: Business model for pellet producing enterprises in Tunisia
narrative: Business model explaining how pellet production using a specified formula and locally produced pellet machine (stationary and mobile) can generate income for an entrepreneur.

title: Resilient seed systems approach and methodology
narrative: The innovation is a participatory approach that includes multiple methodological options to work towards (more) resilient seed systems that meet the needs of tomorrow and help farmers adapt to climate change effects, based on an assessment of local conditions, needs and interests. It brings together Bioversity’s work of several decades on the different components of seed systems (conservation, crop improvement, seed production and distribution, climate and crop modeling and crowdsourcing/citizen science, policies and laws).

title: Methods for county spatial planning in pastoral rangelands in Kenya for strengthened land rights and improved management of natural resources
narrative: Kenya's framework for land use planning requires each county government to develop a county spatial plan. County spatial planning has great potential for incorporating the rangeland management practices of pastoral communities into a government-recognized framework, protecting key components of pastoral livestock production systems such as migration corridors, and developing the livestock sector in dryland areas.  However, existing guidelines for doing this lacked detail.  ILRI collaborated with the Kenya National Land Commission to develop these materials.

title: Holistic and dynamic approach and methodology to establish and support multifunctional community seedbanks
narrative: Community seedbanks are repositories of local genetic diversity that is often adapted to prevailing climate conditions, with good nutritional/health characteristics. They can contribute to community-based strategies for adaptation to climate change by 1) securing improved access to and availability of diverse, locally adapted crops and varieties through the use of multiple germplasm sources; 2) enhancement of related local knowledge and skills in plant management including seed selection, treatment, storage, multiplication and distribution.

title: The Kaleidoscope Model, a practical framework for analyzing food security policy change
narrative: The Kaleidoscope Mode is a practical framework which can be used to assess when and where investments in policy reforms are most feasible given a country’s underlying political, economic, and institutional characteristics. It has been integrated into several training events for USAID's Bureau for Resilience and Food Security staff and IFPRI researchers are regularly invited to present the tool and engage in interactive exercises with USAID's mission staff.

title: Three new barley varieties released in India (PL891) and Jordan (Ramtha1 and Ghweir1)
narrative: Three new varieties released (PL891 in India and Ramtha1 and Ghweir1 in Jordan). They are characterized by superior grain and biomass production and drought tolerance. The three new varieties are registered in the respective national variety catalog and are ready to be transferred to farmers.

title: Mobile grinder for chopping livestock feed in Tunisia
narrative: New model mobile grinder for use with power takeoff clutch (tractor attachment) or 380V electricity. Chopping allows feed to be mixed in specific proportions to increase nutritional value. Chopping straw, olive leaves and tiny branches of fodder trees like Acacia into small pieces also reduces feed loss; when given unchopped straw, goats will not eat it all because they don’t like the nodes (hard parts).

title: Integrated package for sustainable restoration of silvopasture production systems in Tunisia
narrative: Researchers conducted diagnostics of the silvopasture production systems, identified weak links (gaps) and, together with the community, addressed these deficiencies in an integrated package for sustainable restoration of silvopasture in Tunisia. The package includes: cultivating trust among all stakeholders to work together; re-introducing indigenous species familiar to the local community; and facilitating access to inputs (seeds/seedlings) for the local community to cultivate forage crops on their own land.

title: SECTOR: Source-selective and Emission-adjusted Greenhouse Gas Calculator for Cropland
narrative: In response to increasing interest in mitigation studies in cropland, particularly rice production, IRRI developed SECTOR - a Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Calculator for cropland. The tool provides a streamlined framework for accelerated data input that will facilitate rapid assessments of multiple scenarios for domains with many spatial units.

title: Integrating Rice Crop Manager with ICT based tool for scaling out climate-smart agriculture interventions
narrative: In 2019, 75,000 farmers received rice crop manager recommendations through different dissemination partners. Different channels were used for interviewing farmers and generating recommendations. Apart from the regular channels of the department of agriculture and NGOs, two new extension channels, Common Service Centers (CSC) and Precision Agriculture for Development, India Foundation (PAD-IF), were co-opted to reach the farmers.

title: New approach to targeting feed options at scale in East Africa using global data sets
narrative: A new approach to combining global data layers to predict likely uptake of a range of feed options has been developed. Maps of livestock feed constraints in East Africa have been generated as the first stage of developing adoption maps for different feed interventions.

title: Spectra standardization to ILRI master Near Infra-Red Spectrometry (NIRS) instruments
narrative: ILRI has developed more than 90 NIRS equations for predicting a wide range of feed and fodder quality traits in forages, roughages, feed ingredients and compound feed. Through spectra standardization these equations were made accessible to labs in Burkina Faso, Ethiopia and India, which act as regional hubs (Burkina Faso gets  samples from Niger and Mali, Ethiopia from Malawi and Zimbabwe, and India from Nepal and several countries in East and Southern Africa).

title: High performing Napier grass genotypes for improved biomass yield and nutritional quality
narrative: List of top performing Napier grass genotypes under limited water and irrigated conditions identified for broader testing across systems and agroecologies. Napier grass varieties will provide new forage options for improved productivity in a variety of livestock production systems.

title: Guide to the production of High-Quality Cassava Peel® mash as a livestock feed
narrative: This novel feed product was developed by ILRI as a way of converting waste cassava peel into high quality livestock feed. If is registered through the Trademarks, Patents and Designs Registry, Commercial Law Department of the Federal Ministry of Industry, Trade and Investment in Nigeria as a feed ingredient: ‘High Quality Cassava Peel® mash’ (HQCP®). It has been scaled through private sector collaboration, including training and guidance on design of processing plants.

title: Enhanced policy recommendations for sustainable rangeland improvement in Tunisia
narrative: The current rigid procedure for implementing resting technique in Tunisia has become a handicap to sustainable restoration and adoption by the local community. Farmers cannot access their land for 3 years, since it must be either under total protection or livestock exclusion. The new recommendations by ICARDA are flexible and ecologically sound, making them a more attractive option for agro-pastoral communities.

title: 8 Guide steps for setting up a Climate-Smart Village  in South east Asia (Multi-language)
narrative: Based on the experience of implementing the CSV approach, CCAFS SEA developed a guide in establishing CSVs in Southeast Asian context(in multi-language). The eight steps are: determining the purpose and scope of CSV; identifying the climate risk in the target area/s; locating the CSV in a small landscape; consulting the stakeholders; evaluating the CSA options; developing portfolio; scaling-up; and monitoring and evaluating uptake and outcome.

title: School-on-the-air on Climate-Smart Agriculture (SOA-CSA) in Cagayan Valley (The Philippines)
narrative: The Philippine Federation of Rural Broadcasters, with support from CCAFS, developed a school-on-the-air program on climate smart agriculture (SOA-CSA) with modules focusing on rice production, post-production and marketing. The program, with 68 modules airing for over five months, was implemented in the region’s major rice producing provinces through live radio broadcast by Department of Agriculture-owned controlled radio stations, Philippine Broadcasting Service, other government stations in Cagayan Valley, and member stations of PFRB.

title: Agronomy Ontology (AgrO)
narrative: The Agronomy Ontology (AgrO) provides terms from the agronomy domain that are semantically organized and can facilitate the collection, storage and use of agronomic data, enabling easy interpretation and reuse of the data by humans and machines alike. It supports the creation of fieldbooks that improve the collect fo data across multiple trials.

title: Toolbox for sustainable rehabilitation of rangelands in arid environments
narrative: New rangeland management toolbox based on an integrated and multidisciplinary approach to achieve sustainable practices. The toolbox takes into account the spatial and temporal variability of the complexity of rangeland ecosystems. A combination of sustainable rangeland management tools are available ranging from simple soil surface scarification to deep ripping to livestock grazing management.

title: Global Foresight for Food and Agriculture Tool
narrative: Tool hosted on the IFPRI Food Security portal presenting various results from the International Model for Policy Analysis of Agricultural Commodities and Trade  (IMPACT model). It explores policies that can help feed the world, reduce poverty, and protect the natural resource base. It examines how alternative investment scenarios affect agricultural production, productivity, and food security for the period 2010-2050 compared to a reference scenario. Available data from different studies and the Global Food Security Report.

title: Evidence for Resilient Agriculture (ERA): a meta-data based tool for technology-shift decision in Agriculture in Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: ERA is a meta-dataset and analytical engine that uses the last 30 years of agricultural research in Sub-Saharan Africa to ask and answer questions about the effects of shifting from one technology to another on indicators of productivity, resilience, and climate change mitigation outcomes. ERA includes approximately 75,000 observations from 1,400 journal articles. ERA is designed to democratize data, making available information on questions next users are asking when they need it.

title: Extension of SDG Interface Ontology with the indicators of the CGIAR Strategic Research Framework
narrative: This innovation creates the necessary semantic for meaningfully mapping CGIAR Outcome Stories and Innovation, as well as data,  to the SDG targets within the SDG Interface Ontology.

title: Socio!: Agricultural Household Survey Ontology
narrative: CGIAR and partners produces a great amount of household surveys. A community-agreed set of well defined and semantically organized concepts was missing for FAIR data annotation. Therefore, the socio-economic ontology is developed under the leadership of IFPRI, CIMMYT and Bioversity. After the development of a core set of  the 'must have' 100 questions for surveys, based on the RhoMIS tool, an ontology module has been drafted to include concepts and variables.

title: Grazing management innovation to improve animal production and reduce GHG emissions
narrative: This innovation is based on the optimization of dry matter intake by cattle and improving nutrient consumption per unit eating time. At certain grass heights (20 cm) the cows consumed larger bites and of better quality. The result was more propionate (precursor of milk) and less methane emissions. Delivering the farmer an instruction as simple as controlling grass height may impact improving milk productivity and reducing emissions. This innovation was awarded as outstanding PhD thesis.

title: Climate Smart Cocoa: a mobile application for climate smart cocoa cultivation
narrative:
As part of making our results applicable by our target companies (e.g Olam Sustainability - Jakarta, Ecom SMS Vietnam-HCMC
Neumann Kaffee Gruppe BLOOM– Hamburg, Solidaridad, COSA, Root Capital,Rainforest Alliance), a CSC implementer mobile-Application has been developed and soon to be available on google app stores for free downloads. This App combines farmer Segmentation and suggest a Stepwise investment pathway to climate smart cocoa cultivation. This App is currently being reviewed by our partners for feedback.

title: GEM parboiling methods
narrative: The GEM (Grain quality-enhancer, Energy efficient and durable Material) parboiling method allows for the production of parboiled rice that is appealing to different categories of rice consumers. This GEM methods uses either rough rice parboiling or brown rice parboiling. The methods can also use the parboiled rice as a vehicle for large-scale fortification programs.

title: Aflasafe RW01 for Rwanda
narrative: Biocontrol approach to preventing aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for Mali
narrative: Biocontrol approach for Mali to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts. IITA is testing two existing Aflasafe products designed for contiguous countries, Aflasafe BF01 for Burkina Faso and Aflasafe SN01 for Senegal and The Gambia, in order to determine which one works best for different regions in Mali or if a new 'blend' of ingredients drawn from the two products could be worth testing in future.

title: Dry inoculum (active ingredient in Aflasafe): reduces manufacturing costs for Aflasafe and addresses barrier to commercialization
narrative: IITA researchers developed a process to dry out large quantities of spores by vacuuming the liquid inoculum through a special membrane and drying it in an oven. The dry inoculum is not heavy or fragile like the liquid version, making it last longer and easier to transport. From Ibadan, IITA can send enough for a whole season’s Aflasafe production to factories anywhere in Africa using an ordinary courier service, after obtaining appropriate phytosanitary certificates.

title: Field-based aflatoxin sampling and testing protocol
narrative: Normally, crops have to be sampled and then taken back to the lab to test for aflatoxin. This new protocol allows for live testing of sampled crops for aflatoxin. The field-based testing requires a generator and a clean, disinfected work area, but the protocol could be carried out by Aflasafe manufacturing and distribution partners or farmers themselves. Aflasafe is a biocontrol product for reducing aflatoxin in crops like maize and groundnuts.

title: A new protocol for rice postharvest loss assessment in Sub Saharan African countries
narrative: This protocol developed by the Africa-wide rice Processing and Value Addition Taskforce is composed of six sections; introduction, methods for the quantification of physical grain loss and grain quality loss at eight different points along the rice value chain, data collection on paddy and milled rice production volumes in different sub-Sahara Africa countries, data analysis, conclusion and acknowledgement.

title: Methods to measure and classify employment in the agri-food system in Africa south of the Sahara
narrative: Innovative techniques are being piloted for more accurately measuring employment in the agri-food system, with particular focus on accurately classifying off-farm activities as related to the agri-food system or not. In addition, these methods allow to precisely classify on-farm activities as adding value or not - as opposed to standard methods which only include broad descriptions of production.

title: Method for Screening low glycemic rice in the germplasm
narrative: This method is based on estimating partially gelatinized starch in severely parboiled rice. This method is innovative because it combines the intrinsic properties of a variety and its processing to determine its glycemic index and digestive properties.

title: Method for screening rice with high popping capacity
narrative: This innovation describes the methods for the screening of rice varieties grown in Africa and methods for the production of fully gelatinized carbohydrates source for infant formulas.  These method evaluate the popping capacity of the paddy and the ability for the rice flour to form quality crackers.

title: Carbon Footprint Assessment Model for Chinese Dairy Sector
narrative: Carbon footprint model based on life cycle assessment (LCA) software was developed to assess greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions associated with the whole process of dairy production. The functions of the software include: (1) assess the carbon footprint of the individual farm, (2) provide GHG emission mitigation options for farms through scenario analysis; (3) provide a report to farms to show their farm's carbon footprint performance, and give recommendation to reduce their carbon footprint.

title: AClimateColombia: a new platform for climate services
narrative: We developed a user-centered digital agro-climatic forecast system filling a gap for the continuous provision of climate information for agriculture in tropical developing countries (mainly extension agents, farmer organization staff, and sometimes also farmers themselves). The system allows for crop-specific decision making (rice and maize at present, and being extended to beans). A clear innovation has been the automation of met agency workflows (otherwise not automated) and their connection to state-of-the-art crop modeling tools.

title: Participatory Rangeland Management (PRM) in Tanzania and Kenya
narrative: Participatory Rangeland Management (PRM) is a defined step-by-step process for improving local level rangeland management. It follows three stages of investigation (including participatory mapping), negotiation and implementation. It supports establishment and/or strengthening of rangelands management institutions, and supports the production of a rangeland management plan and an agreement with local government to improve access of communities to natural resources and land. M&E and capacity building are also important steps.

title: Digital platform (Application Processing Interface or API) for interaction with, and data capture from, smallholder dairy cattle farmers
narrative: Digital tools for longitudinal data capture on smallholder dairy cattle performance have been developed and used to register 128,567 farms and 303,087 animals (59,963 of which provide milk production data) in Tanzania, Ethiopia and Kenya. The platform includes one main master tool that collates data from all countries, plus individual country based tools for interaction, querying and feedback with farmers. The collated data is stored on a server (not open source) and at country level.

title: Methodological framework for upscaling community based breeding programs
narrative: Community-based breeding programs (CBBPs) for small ruminants have successfully been piloted in Ethiopia, Tanzania, Sudan and Iran since 2009. To achieve impact they need to go to scale and the framework is supporting ongoing scaling initiatives.

title: Identification of a candidate gene for prolificacy in Bonga sheep
narrative: Bonga sheep are prolific in sub-Saharan Africa. Genome-wide scans identified a region on the X-chromosome and a candidate gene (BMP15) associated with prolificacy and reproduction traits in Bonga sheep. This can now be used to develop a breeding program for the introgression of this gene to other populations.

title: Best practices for FAIR, ethical, and open data assets
narrative: This is a five-module course structure around the data life cycle, and intended to provide data, information, IT, IP/legal specialists, and researchers with background knowledge on the importance of FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable), ethical, and open data assets -- and the tools to enable them to operationalize easily. Course participants will need to sign in (free) to view or take the course.

title: CGIAR Expert Finder: an ontology-based web tool for scouting expertise and partners
narrative: The CGIAR Expert Finder is based on the VIVO semantic web tool, and enables users to easily find and discover expertise (by geographic location, subject, research topic and more) and partnerships/key collaborating entities across the CGIAR System, showcasing its research and achievments. Its ontology-based underpinnings allow interoperability and linking with other data assets, and links to GARDIAN are already planned.

title: Agronomy Field Information Management System (AgroFIMS)
narrative: AgroFIMS is based on the Agronomy Ontology and aligns with the CG Core metadata schema, and therefore enables the generation of standard-compliant data at the data collection stage. AgroFIMS allows users to easily create fieldbooks, collect data digitally, check data quality and validate it, and generate statistical analyses and reports.

title: Case studies to illustrate data wrangling approaches and share R scripts
narrative: This set of case studies attempt to reproduce published research using open data, and offer well-documented methodologies and R scripts for doing so. The cases cover a range of geographies, crops, agricultural disciplines (management, modeling, soil science etc.) and topics.

title: Collaborative GARDIAN (CG) Labs, an open-access service to enable researchers to collaborate and share data and analytic approaches and tools
narrative: CG Labs advances research by allowing users to collaborate via private or public virtual spaces that they can create and access via a Single Sign-On (SSO). It also enables users to search GARDIAN's data resources, and download and save datasets in CG Labs; securely upload and share data via Globus; and to collaboratively write and run analytics in Python and R. CG Labs requires user to log in, but is openly accessible.

title: GARDIAN PII checker to minimze risk of personally-identifiable information in datasets
narrative: The PII checker is available as a containerized system for easy deployment by CGIAR Centers and others. It is a servie built on state-of-the-art algorithms from Stanford University to flag the presence of personally-identifiable information (currently only names), and intended to minimize risk for the CGIAR System and other entities using it.

title: 51 new pre-breeding wheat lines with high yield potential and climate resilience for Mexico
narrative: 51 lines suitable for pre-breeding have been developed for use in conditions suited to Mexico's growing regions. The lines show high yield potential and resilience to heat and drought impacted conditions.

title: 17 new, more productive wheat varieties multiplied in collaboration with seed producers located in strategic growing areas of Mexico.
narrative: 17 new, more productive wheat varieties multiplied in collaboration with Mexican seed producers located in strategic growing areas. The multiplied seed (more than 95 tons) was distributed to farmers of different regions of Mexico.

title: Two wheat lines selected in collaboration with INIFAP proposed as variety release candidates, for increased productivity
narrative: Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Forestales, Agricolas y Pecuaries (INIFAP), the national agricultural research institute in Mexico has collaborated with WHEAT in the selection of two wheat lines to be proposed for release as varieties in Mexico for increased productivity.

title: 24 CIMMYT advanced wheat lines with high yield potential, good grain quality and disease resistance.
narrative: CIMMYT advanced wheat lines were assessed for their yield potential, disease resistance and milling potential, from which 24 lines were identified as good candidates meeting all criteria and conditions in the selected growing region of Mexico.

title: Re-designing irrigated intensive cereal systems through bundling precision agronomic innovations for transitioning towards agricultural sustainability in North-West India
narrative: Appropriate agronomic management alternatives have been developed to address agricultural sustainability in NW India. However, their application in isolation have not been able to deliver the potential benefits. Systems which are 11.2-29.2% more productive, 29.2-48.9% more profitable and use 20-85% less irrigation water use with better nitrogen and energy use efficiency and lower carbon foot prints. This package of innovations is ready for piloting by local government authorities.

title: Rice Functional and Genomic Breeding (RFGB) v2.0 database to link genotypic and phenotypic datasets, facilitates access and uploading of genomic data
narrative: Rice Functional and Genomic Breeding (RFGB) v2.0 is a database developed to bridge gaps between phenotypic and genotypic data sets of sequenced genome.  RFGB  was developed for breeding applications in 2015 based on SNP and InDel data from the 3000 rice genome (3K‐RG) project. This latest version has a ‘Seed request’ function to help users to access the 3K‐RG seeds and ‘contribute your data to RFGB’ to upload their own phenotypic data.

title: Participatory process for developing system dynamics models to guide interventions in the context of agri-food and livestock value chains
narrative: The innovation is a participatory process for conducting assessment of interventions (technologies, practices, policies). Value chains are inherently complex and current methods are insufficient to provide strong justification for proposed interventions. System dynamics (SD) models are methodologies based around the broader field of systems thinking, which views social and natural world systems as interconnected. ILRI has pioneered the use of SD models in the context of agri-food and livestock value chains.

title: Controlled vocabulary dictionary for UAV, phenotyping and image data annotation
narrative: Controlled vocabulary dictionary for UAV, phenotyping and image data annotation have been created to build a trait dictionary. Drone data variables and metadata have been identified for standardization using ontology.

title: Pilot database for management of drone (UAV) image data with basic functionality developed.
narrative: Pilot database management system for drone images and metadata has been developed and work is in progress for automated high-throughput phenotyping. Potential utilization of new CG group license with Pix4D with the database.

title: New protocol developed to measure spike photosynthetic rates of bread wheat in France
narrative: Protocol developed to measure spike photosynthetic rates of bread wheat. Protocol enabled detection of differences among genotypes for spikes and flag leaf at specific phenological stages. This was a public private partnership with BASF. Higher spike photosynthesis rates are more desirable.

title: Livestock and fish value chain assessment toolkit
narrative: In the past, CGIAR research typically focused on production or farming systems. Moreover, given the unique features of fish and livestock products, existing tools developed for crops are not well adapted. The purpose of this toolkit is therefore to provide a set of tools to analyse livestock and fish value chains and to provide a process and associated tools to identify, monitor and evaluate best bet interventions toward improved value chain performance and gender inclusiveness.

title: Public private partnership in delivery of artificial insemination services
narrative: Fixed Time Artificial Insemination (FTAI) involves synchronizing the herd through hormonal treatments (eliminating the need for heat detection) to be artificially mated over a controlled time frame, allowing farmers to plan for when to expect calving and milk production. Over time, the project has increasingly engaged private AI providers, coordinating supplies and delivery of services in collaboration with producer organizations. The county government maintains an oversight role and sub-county veterinarian lead in animal selection.

title: Social and behavioural change communication strategy for improving consumption of animal source foods in Rwanda
narrative:
The innovation is a strategy aimed at increasing consumption of animal-source food (ASF) by children aged 12-42
months and pregnant and lactating women. Behavior change messaging on the benefits of milk and ASF consumption is targeted to mothers and caregivers, through multiple media including: posters, community meetings, interpersonal household level communication by community health workers. Advocacy is also carried out targeting the National Nutrition and WASH Working Group and the National Early Childhood Development Program.

title: Meghdoot App to support the digitalization of agroadvisories in India
narrative: This is an SMS based app that improves farmers decisions around climate risk management. Launched by the Minister for Earth Science, Science and Technology in August 2019, it disseminates context and location specific high-resolution weather forecast based agro-advisories to farmers in local language. It was developed by ICRISAT and its ag-tech startup partners to supports the digitalisation of agroadvisories put out by the India Meteorological Department and Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology.

title: Survey-based approaches for measuring gendered freedom of movement
narrative: This innovation consists of a conceptual framework to help understand freedom of movement and frame the factors that limit women’s freedom of movement as well as survey-based approaches for measuring men's and women's freedom of movement. These tools can be particularly useful for value chain analysis.

title: Methodological guide for participatory collection of gender indicators in agriculture in Latin America
narrative: This guide describes participatory methods to collect data to understand gender dynamics in agricultural settings - including value chains - with a specific focus on collecting information related to empowerment in agriculture. This tool is designed to collect qualitative information/data to help contextualize each domain of the Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index (WEAI). As such, the guide presents activities to collect qualitative data about each of the 5 domains of the WEAI.

title: 44 new improved high-yielding rice breeding lines for Madagascar (14) and Nepal (30
narrative: Development of new improved high-yielding breeding lines for Madagascar and Nepal

title: Contour bunding has been a useful technology, preferred by farmers, to improve agricultural productivity and socio-economic gains
narrative: Contour Bunding Technology (CBT) has been practiced over two decades in Mali mainly to improve crop productivity. The findings in the paper highlighted the positive gains in environmental and socio-economic aspects and these are helpful for landscape wide scaling of CBT. For successful implementation and landscape wide scaling, awareness programs need to be facilitated through existing government extension systems and/or through innovations platforms that are created by multiple development actors in west Africa.

title: Epidemiology and Control of Peste des Petits Ruminants (ECO-PPR) toolbox
narrative: The ECO-PPR toolbox is a comprehensive compilation of gender sensitive survey tools to collect data on epidemiology and socio-economic impact of disease, combining household survey, focus group discussions, biological sampling, disease search strategies and market network data.

title: Disease risk mapping based on existing surveillance data
narrative: Risk maps for two key livestock diseases were produced based on existing surveillance data received from the veterinary service department in Vietnam. The innovation clearly demonstrates how official surveillance data not normally being used after the surveillance activity can be useful in facilitating policy interactions.

title: Modelling approach to assess control scenarios for key livestock diseases
narrative: This innovation is a cost-efficient evaluation of different control scenarios and thus is a useful tool in policy dialogue. We used the example of Porcine Reproductive and Respiratory Syndrome (PRRS) in Vietnam and modeled efficacy of different vaccination strategies

title: Animal health resource centers (AHRCs) in Ethiopia
narrative: Animal health resource centers were established through a bilateral project (Health of Ethiopian Animals for Rural Development or HEARD) with the aim to provide an alternative source of animal health management knowledge for livestock keepers, animal health service providers and other value chain actors.  The centers are located in woreda or kebele livestock offices and resources include computers with internet access, books, leaflets and extension training materials.

title: Goat Annual Reproductive Performance Index (G-ARPI)
narrative: Measuring goat reproductive performance is an important productivity indicator, but cannot be done using a single parameter, hence comparison across projects or impact evaluation of interventions is difficult. We developed a new index that builds on different reproductive parameters (including age at first kidding, kidding interval, number of pregnancies, number of kids born, number of kids survived to wean, number of abortions, number of defective births) to give a more objective performance measure.

title: Community Conversation training module on animal welfare in Ethiopia
narrative: This training module is a step-by-step guide for facilitators (researchers, veterinarians and extension agents) to run community conversation sessions on animal welfare. It explains the concepts of animal welfare as applicable to the context in Ethiopia, outlines the goals and specific objectives of the session, and includes all the necessary training materials to engage communities, including discussion prompts and guidance on how to define actions to lead to behaviour change regarding animal welfare.

title: Smart-Valleys approach in Burkina Faso for land and water management for rice-based systems
narrative: Smart-Valleys is a participatory approach used by smallholder farmers for land and water management for rice-based systems in inland valleys. The approach enables farmers to improve, at low cost, water control by using simple means to design and construct drainage axes for siting of irrigation canals and create bunded and levelled fields according to the topological conditions.

title: e-learning training material for dairy cattle keepers in Kenya
narrative: A training manual previously developed for dairy farmers was converted into an electronic form for trainers, as an innovative way to reach farmers with agricultural information in the absence of extension staff in government departments. It covers topics including selecting a breed, feeding, health, welfare, hygiene, and milk marketing. The material can now be shared through social media and other channels thus increasing the reach tremendously.

title: Antimicrobial use in livestock production systems (AMUSE Livestock) tool version 2
narrative: AMUSE Livestock is a tool covering knowledge, attitudes and practices related to antimicrobial use in livestock production systems. It asks questions at household level about: numbers and species of animals; types, costs and doses of drugs used; and animal health actions/behaviours carried out by farmers.

title: Community conversation training module on antimicrobial use and resistance in Ethiopia
narrative: Community conversations are facilitated dialogues among community members to explore and analyse their perceptions on specific topics such as knowledge, attitudes and practices (KAP) about antimicrobial use and resistance. They create space for community members to freely share their views and discuss issues. This community conversation training module facilitates the creation of awareness around responsible use of antibiotics in livestock production.

title: Establishment of Innovation Platforms (IPs) to facilitate the participation of livestock farmers in vaccination in Mali
narrative: Integrated participatory approach using Innovation Platforms (IPs) to facilitate participation of livestock farmers in vaccination. IPs were created in 24 communes in three regions: 15 in Sikasso, four in Mopti and five in Timbuktu; and monitored for 4 years (2015-2019). They significantly increased vaccination coverage against Peste des Petits Ruminants (PPR), Contagious Bovine Pleuro-Pneumonia (CBPP) and bovine Pasteurellosis. IPs were comprised of stakeholders involved in livestock vaccine delivery, farmer support and the livestock value chain.

title: Public-Private Partnership model to link mobile clinical veterinary services with woreda (county) veterinary offices in Ethiopia
narrative: The public sector dominates all aspects of animal health delivery in Ethiopia but is inadequate. ILRI took the initiative to convene task forces to discuss how to improve veterinary service delivery including both public and private sector stakeholders. This innovation will increase access of livestock keepers to animal health services by developing a model where the private sector could provide mobile services.

title: Empirical assessment of the effects of investments in mechanization technologies on economies of scope (economies of diversification) at farm-level
narrative: This paper assesses how the adoption of technologies affects economies of scope (increased efficiency of input use from spread them over different enterprises) in crop production at farm level. Using panel data from farm households and crop-specific production costs in Nigeria, the authors find that animal traction/tractors increase economies of scope between rice and non-rice crops, facilitating diversification of production within those households.

title: Evidence that school feeding reduces anemia prevalence in adolescent girls and other vulnerable household members in Uganda
narrative: Food for education programs that include school meals are widely used to improve school participation and performance, but evidence on their nutritional benefits is limited. This paper provides evidence that micro-fortified food provided as part of an incentivized transfer program to encourage school attendance for girls in camps for internally displaced people in Northern Uganda reduced anemia prevalence in adolescent girls, adult women, and preschool children.

title: Climate-Smart Agriculture Investment Plans
narrative: CIAT and CCAFS working with the World Bank and partners have released 30 ‘Climate Smart Agriculture Profiles’, which have helped countries understand the climate challenges in their food systems. These partners are now developping Climate-Smart Agriculture Investment Plans building on the CSA profiles. They identify concrete actions governments can take to boost climate-smart agriculture, both in the form of investment opportunities and policy design and implementation.

title: Two improved durum wheat and bread wheat varieties released in Spain
narrative: One durum wheat and one bread wheat variety released via WHEAT partner Agrovegetal in Spain. The varieties are called Setenil (bread wheat) and Don Fernando (durum wheat). Improved traits include grain yield advantage, disease resistance and market quality.

title: Rice husk fuelled pop rice maker
narrative: This equipment is a rotatory roaster adapted to a rice husk gasifier stove for popping rice. The innovative aspect is the use of rice husk to power a popping machine

title: Rice variety with high popping capacity
narrative: Rice with high popping capacity is being sought as a fully gelatinized gluten free carbohydrate source for infant formulas. The innovation are rice varieties with high popping capacity that can be used for large-scale production of pop rice

title: Variety for rice cracker production
narrative: Rice cracker is an intermediary step for the production of fully gelatinized gluten free carbohydrate source for infant formulas. The innovation are varieties grown in Africa that are suitable for large-scale cracker production.

title: Method for screening rice for cracker production
narrative: This innovation allows for the screening of varieties for rice cracker production which is subsequently used for the production of carbohydrate source for infant formulas. The screening is based on hardness, puffiness and degree of starch gelatinization.

title: Participatory development of scaling plan as a part of low emission roadmap in rice production of Mekong River Delta
narrative: IRRI paper provides insights -a model roadmap- for LET (low-emission technologies) adoption and implementation potential in rice production in An Giang province. It also implies LET scaling orientation for other rice production provinces in the Mekong River Delta.

title: Best-fit contract farming models in Benin
narrative: Contract farming, defined as “a sales arrangement between a farmer and a firm, agreed before production begins, which provides the farmer with resources or services. Best-fit contract farming models are schemes that take into account the perception of smallholder farmers and have positive impact on their livelihoods".

title: Investissement Policy for Cameroon (CIPRiSSA-Cameroon)
narrative: CIPRiSSA conveys the seriousness of governments and establish the credibility of the business concept. It will also help investors and citizens who are not familiar with the investment requirements in each segment of the rice value chain as well as the benefits derivable from such investments. In addition, it will help to attract established businesses and start-up of new lines of activity.

title: Investment Policy for Cote d'Ivoire (CIPRiSSA-Cote d'Ivoire)
narrative: CIPRiSSA conveys the seriousness of governments and establish the credibility of the business concept. It will also help investors and citizens who are not familiar with the investment requirements in each segment of the rice value chain as well as the benefits derivable from such investments. In addition, it will help to attract established businesses and start-up of new lines of activity.

title: Investment Policy for Ghana (CIPRiSSA-Ghana)
narrative: CIPRiSSA conveys the seriousness of governments and establish the credibility of the business concept. It will also help investors and citizens who are not familiar with the investment requirements in each segment of the rice value chain as well as the benefits derivable from such investments. In addition, it will help to attract established businesses and start-up of new lines of activity.

title: Investment Policy for Madagascar (CIPRiSSA-Madagascar)
narrative: CIPRiSSA conveys the seriousness of governments and establish the credibility of the business concept. It will also help investors and citizens who are not familiar with the investment requirements in each segment of the rice value chain as well as the benefits derivable from such investments. In addition, it will help to attract established businesses and start-up of new lines of activity.

title: Investment Policy for Mali (CIPRiSSA-Mali)
narrative: CIPRiSSA conveys the seriousness of governments and establish the credibility of the business concept. It will also help investors and citizens who are not familiar with the investment requirements in each segment of the rice value chain as well as the benefits derivable from such investments. In addition, it will help to attract established businesses and start-up of new lines of activity.

title: Investment Policy for Nigeria (CIPRiSSA-Nigeria)
narrative: CIPRiSSA conveys the seriousness of governments and establish the credibility of the business concept. It will also help investors and citizens who are not familiar with the investment requirements in each segment of the rice value chain as well as the benefits derivable from such investments. In addition, it will help to attract established businesses and start-up of new lines of activity.
