Tree foods are nutritious edible foods from trees and shrubs including fruits, vegetables, seeds, nuts and edible oils. Next to these foods, pulses, cereals and starchy roots and tubers are included. The database includes scores of the presence of selected micronutrients iron, vitamin A, folate and vitamin C. The current version (version 1) contains 132 foods (out of 99 species) and 30 components.

title: New tools for crop wild relative conservation planning
narrative: Tools to guide and facilitate countries in the national conservation planning of Crop wild relatives (CWR) and National Strategic Action Plans (NSAP) development have been prepared, namely: an ‘Interactive Toolkit for CWR Conservation Planning’, a ‘Template for the Preparation of a NSAP for the Conservation and Sustainable Use of CWR’, a ‘Template for the Preparation of a Technical Background Document for a NSAP for the Conservation and Sustainable Use of CWR’, a ‘CWR Checklist and Inventory Data Template’ and an ‘Occurrence Data Collation Template’.

title: Model Species Distributions by Estimating the Probability of Occurrence Using Presence-Only Data
narrative: A species’ distribution can be characterized by the probability that it occurs at some location in space. Estimating occurrence probability can be easily accomplished using presence-absence data, but often researchers only have presence locations and environmental data for the study area. MAXENT is a popular software program for modeling species distributions, but it does not estimate the probability of occurrence. Rather, it returns various indices that are not easy to interpret . The package "maxlike" provides a simple likelihood-based alternative.
evidence_link: Richard Chandler, Andy Royle and Roeland Kindt. maxlike: Model Species Distributions by Estimating the Probability of Occurrence Using Presence-Only Data. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=maxlike

title: Milan Urban Food Policy Pact (MUFPP) Indicator Framework with gender lens, field tested in Nairobi
narrative: A methodology to assess food system resilience through a gender lens as a basis for identifying ways to strengthen resilience as a means to implement the “Milan Urban Food Policy Pact". With FAO support RUAF Is pilot testing the framework with three cities.

title: Payment for Forest Environmental Services policy learning tool
narrative: This policy learning tool is primarily designed for policy makers and government officers who need to carry out M&E and report on the progress and impact of payment for forest environmental services (PFES) policies.  The tool enables learning processes in which information and experience are used to acquire new knowledge on the impacts of a PFES program and opportunities and challenges for PFES implementation.

title: Ecosystem-based adaptation monitoring platform in the Gambia
narrative: The EbA project M&E information platform will serve as the go-to place to acquire details about the progress of activities linked to the  Large-scale Ecosystem-based Adaptation Project in The Gambia. The platform is based on the key performance indicators for the project and the sub-indicators.

title: Newly released variety Rabba1 in Jordan
narrative: based on Jori/Haurani pedigree (released in Morocco, 1989)

title: An innovative approach for the comparative study of landscape-scale multi-stakeholder forums
narrative: This Methods training manual and tools for in-depth field research sets out the rationale and method for CIFOR’s research on multi-stakeholder forums (MSFs). It was specifically designed to examine MSFs set up to address land use and land-use change at the subnational level in Brazil, Ethiopia, Indonesia, and Peru.The research is innovative for three main reasons. First, participatory processes are seldom approached comparatively; this method allows for in-country comparisons, as well as across country, type of forum and type of actor. Second, research design aims at collecting data through 10 different tools (quantitative and qualitative) that included MSF participants, organizers, and local experts, as well as non-participants, and examines their perceptions of both effectiveness and equity outcomes. This allows for the exploration of the transformative potential of these platforms by looking both inside and outside the forum at a wider scale. Third, the innovative method includes innovative tools. One important innovation is a questionnaire on the theory of change with the MSF organizers and another is  Q methodology.

title: The Economics of Ecosystem Restoration (TEER): Database of costs and benefits of restoration.
narrative: Global database that could serve as a reference point for decision-makers and restoration practitioners, for the ex-ante estimation of costs and benefits of future restoration projects in all major biomes and across a wide range of contexts worldwide, based on information from comparable projects on which data has been collected through a standardized framework.

title: A model for Joint Venture amongst community forest enterprises (CFEs)
narrative: The development of community forest enterprises (CFEs) has emerged as a key tool in sustainable forest management and rural livelihood improvement. In general, the development of viable business models for CFEs follows the same procedure as that of standard enterprises. However, due to the specificity of the context and laws governing CFEs, development of these business models requires some specific considerations. The tool developed by ICRAF underscores technical specificities that make designing viable CFEs different, and to highlight special considerations and options to ensure sustainability of CFEs.

title: An interface for integrated modelling capacity to incorporate Agricultural Production Systems sIMulator crop model predictions in Simile livelihood trajectory models
narrative: An interface has been developed to allow, for the first time, sophisticated and globally calibrated APSIM crop models to be integrated in participatory modelling of impacts of innovations on livelihood trajectories using the intuitive Simile modelling environment. Previously agroforestry and livelihood trajectory models have suffered from lack of credibility in food security predictions because the crop models they have used have not been globally validated. The APSIM crop models have been globally validated and the interface allows them to be called from a simple livelihood trajectory model made in Simile. This adds credibility to livelihood trajectory models that can be intuitively created in a participatory modelling process with farmers, extension staff and/or researchers. It is a general capability that can now be used in any new modelling effort.

title: Local adaptation of planting basins through options by context (OxC) co-learning and gender-sensitive methods
narrative: Planting basins capture and conserve water for growing trees and crops in low rainfall conditions but take more labour the larger and deeper they are and may shift effort for land preparation from men to women. Using options by context (OxC) co-learning methods to adapt basins to individual farmer circumstances increases adoptability and supports local innovation
evidence_link: Impacts on adoption of planting basins in relation to gender documented here: http://www.worldagroforestry.org/sites/default/files/Gender%20land%20restoration%20brief%20IFAD%20EC_V1_MC_0.pdf Third party evaluation of the effectiveness of planned comparisons in scaling up planting basins usinh the OxC approach in the IFAD/EU dryland restoration project available here:  http://www.adansonia-consulting.ch/document/restoration_of_degraded_land.pdf

title: Options by context (OxC) approach to agronomic innovation
narrative: Agricultural research has been largely based on estimating average effects of new technology on narrow performance measures, OxC measures variation in  broad performance metrics across contexts to identify what works where and for whom with profound implications for how research and development are configured.

title: Four high-yielding and black Sigatoka resistant banana hybrids (NABIO ) for East Africa
narrative: New banana genotypes developed by the Uganda National Agricultural Research Organization in collaboration with Bioversity International.

title: Seed Tracker: online application for real-time tracking of cassava seed production that supports communication and networking of cassava producers
narrative: The Cassava Seed Tracker™ is a fully featured program for real-time tracking of cassava seed production, including pre-planting planning, registration of seed fields, crop management, harvesting, quality assessment and quality assertion. The Cassava Seed Tracker is also a digital platform for communication and networking of cassava seed producers and service providers for common good.

title: Recipe for the production of nutritious cassava-based snacks
narrative: Fritters are flour-based snacks made from wheat flour. A cheaper and nutritious alternative produced using different mixes of cassava and soy flours was developed in Zambia. The analysis of consumer preferences showed that these snacks can be suitable for the national market.

title: Stage Selection Gain 1to3 (SSG1to3): a simple programme to help breeders in accurately determining the response to selection after up to 3 stages of selection
narrative: The “Stage Selection Gain 1to3” (SSG1to3) in R (SSG1to3_R) or SAS (SSG1to3_SAS) is a simple program to determine the response to selection in standardized units (R) after 1-stage selection with up to three seasons of testing, 2-stage selection with two seasons of testing, and 3-stage selection with three seasons of testing.

title: Sweetpotato silage-based diet for animal feeding
narrative: Sweetpotato silage making, marketing and use for animal feeding has proven to be technically and economically viable. Initially tested for pig production, the latest experiences shown that is also suitable for dairy feeding

title: Three orange-fleshed sweetpotato varieties released in Burkina Faso
narrative: The three orange-fleshed sweetpotato varieties were obtained using accelerated breeding schemes. Local name / CIP number are:  KbOr-3 / CIP444209; Heere / CIP444189; Nooma / CIP444173

title: Four dual purpose sweetpotato varieties moderately resistant to sweet potato virus disease (SPVD) released in Kenya
narrative: The four sweetpotato varieties were introduced in Kenya from Uganda and Mozambique. Local names are:  Irene; Schock 5; Silklow6; Kyebandula6.

title: Four high-yielding sweetpotato varieties moderately resistant to sweet potato virus disease (SPVD) and weevil released in Ghana
narrative: The four sweetpotato varieties were obtained using accelerated breeding schemes. Local names are:  CRI-AGRA SP 09; CRI-Vern Gracen; CRI-Kofi Annan; CRI-AGRA SP13

title: Five potato varieties with high yield potential and tolerance to biotic stresses (i.e. late blight and bacterial wilt) released in Rwanda
narrative: Since 2013 CIP and RAB evaluated 42 introduced potato clones of which five clones: CIP398190.615 (Ndeze), CIP393280.64 (Nkunganire), CIP396018.241 (Izihirwe), and CIP393077.159 (Kazeneza), and CIP393371.58 (Twihaze) were identified to have desirable traits such as high yield potential, tolerance to biotic stresses such as late blight and bacterial wilt. These were released in in February 2019. Further screenings revealed six additional clones CIP378699.2, Shangi, CIP392657.8, CIP398190.89, CIP392797.22, and CIP394611.112 to be released in February 2020.

title: Nuru: a smartphone application that helps farmers diagnose crop diseases in their fields
narrative: PlantVillage Nuru, which means ‘light’ in Swahili, is a smartphone application that helps in accurately diagnosing cassava diseases. The app works both online and offline and is using artificial intelligence to analyse and classify images taken in the field to detect four major cassava diseases. PlantVillage Nuru is a publicly supported, and publicly developed application.

title: Low-cost and energy-efficient small-scale flash dryer for cassava
narrative: Drying of cassava starch and flour is essential to ensure longer shelf life. Low-cost and energy-efficient pneumatic flash dryers represent a viable alternative to sun-drying for small processing units.

title: Farmer Business school
narrative: Farmer Business school is a participatory action learning approach to support farmer groups’ participation to and benefit from agricultural value chains guided by a market-chain curricular framework, through a series of learning activities over a production-marketing cycle, including interaction with other chain actors and stakeholders. It is a modular/ step-wise platform for developing or upgrading value chains especially fit for small farmer-entrepreneurs.

title: Recipes for healthy snacks and other plantain-based food products
narrative: Recipes for the formulation of healthy snacks and other plantain-based food products that could be acceptable by consumers have been tested. The use of plantain flour as alternative to wheat flour and the addition of other ingredients, as groundnut and cinnamon, improved the nutritional contents of the products. For their characteristics these products may not only be consumed by children and youths but even by people with special dietary needs.

title: BrAPI - Application programming interface (API) used by RTB breeding community to exchange data
narrative: The Breeding API specifies a standard interface for plant phenotype/genotype databases to serve their data to crop breeding applications. It is a shared, open API, to be used by all data providers and data consumers who wish to participate Breeding API allows data exchange between databases as well as third party tools.  Being implemented in RTBbases, BMS, drupal, etc.

title: Positive selection to improve on-farm seed potato management
narrative: Positive selection (or “Select the best”) is an efficient and simple technique for improving on-farm seed potato management. The best plants (robust and not showing symptoms of key diseases) are marked before and after flowering. These plants are harvested and only those with good yield are selected to provide tubers for the next growing season. This technique is complemented with integrated pest and disease management, and postharvest techniques.

title: Multi-stakeholder framework for intervening in RTB seed systems
narrative: The tool is designed to better understand RTB seed systems or to improve seed system interventions (e.g., projects or programs). It helps in identifying key stakeholders and in assessing availability, access, and quality of seed as well as in identifying bottlenecks and in designing key actions for the upcoming intervention.

title: Low-cost net tunnels for producing virus-free sweetpotato planting material
narrative: The innovation consists in using a simple tunnel, that can be constructed at the farm level using insect proof nets, to protect the planting material. The tunnel reduces the exposure of sweetpotato plants to aphids and whiteflies which transmit various viruses. The planting material produced using the net tunnel has higher quality with little or no virus infection and may be used as starting material by vines multipliers.

title: Hand-Held Decision Support System for Potato Late Blight Management (HH-DSS)
narrative: The hand - held decision support system (HH - DSS) is an affordable and practical tool to improve management of potato late blight disease (LB). HH - DSS helps farmers make better decisions about timing of fungicide sprays and selection of fungicides. Using the tool farmers can reduce fungicide costs and environmental impact without risking disease outbreak and crop loss.

title: Tumaini: an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-powered banana diseases and pest detection App
narrative: Tumaini is an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-powered banana disease detection app. The app can be used to diagnose 5 banana diseases (Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW), Banana Bunchy Top Disease (BBTD), Fusarium wilt, Black Leaf Streak and Yellow Sigatoka) and one pest (weevil).

title: TIPCIP V1.0: a new android mobile app to calculate the average temperature of the plant canopy
narrative: This mobile Android application allows to calculate the average temperature of the potato plant canopy based on  (1) visible image that helps to determine the presence of plants in the image scene, and (2) the thermal image that provides the estimated temperature per pixel using an infrared image sensor. This may help smallholder farmers in evaluating their crop status.  The App works along with the FLIR one thermal camera (https://www.flir.com/).

title: Scaling Readiness: a stepwise process to generate evidence for more effective scaling of innovation
narrative: Scaling Readiness offers structured, science-based analyses and recommendations for bringing innovations to larger audiences and markets. Scaling Readiness aims to support organizations, projects, and programs in achieving their ambitions to scale innovations. It encourages critical reflection on how ‘ready’ innovations are for scaling and what appropriate actions could accelerate or enhance scaling.

title: Organic practices including the use of Bacillus thuringiensis for the management of Potato Tuber Moth (PTM) in traditional country stores
narrative: Phthorimaea operculella (PTM) is a serious pest in potato fields and traditional storage in the Kush Himalayan region of India, Nepal, Bhutan and Afghanistan. Due to lack of refrigerated storage facilities, farmers store their seed potato in low cost, non-refrigerated stores, which provide an excellent environment for PTM development. Innovation package includes store management, PTM management and treatment with Bacillus thuringiensis.

title: A simple and rapid protocol for the genetic transformation of Ensete ventricosum
narrative: Genetic transformation and subsequent regeneration of transgenic enset has never been reported mainly due to challenges in developing transformation protocols for this tropical species. A simple Agrobacterium-mediated transformation system for generating transgenic events of enset is developed. The transformation system established in this study can be used for the generation of transgenic enset with important traits such as disease resistance.

title: Potato varieties Tigoni & Shangi with extreme resistance to late blight disease  transformed with 3 R genes from wild relatives
narrative: 3 R (three resistance genes to Late Blight) genes was introduced as a stack made of genes from wild relatives of S. tuberosum (RB and Rpi-blb2 from S. bulbocastanum and Rpi-vnt1.1 from S. venturii) into African farmer-preferred potato varieties ‘Tigoni’ and Shangi.   The resistance of 3R transgenic events of both varieties was characterized by a total absence of symptoms of Late Blight disease after detached-leaf and whole-plant assays indicating a successful defense response.

title: Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) assay protocol for field detection of Ralstonia solanacearum spp
narrative: Seed potato certification standards have zero tolerance for bacterial wilt (caused by Ralstonia  solanacearum) leading to rejection of entire potato seed fields. Current seed potato certification process involves costly and time consuming  diagnosis protocols.  This molecular method is a validated cost-effective LAMP assay for the detection of Ralstonia from potato stem, leaf, tuber and soil also in the field.

title: Two new yam varieties for Nigeria with strong yield stability and high tuber yields and improved cooking and nutritional qualities
narrative: These two candidates were passed through many evaluation stages including the the early clonal stages, preliminary yield trials, advanced yield trials, uniform yield trials. The criteria used for early clonal evaluation selection was based on vigour, pest and disease resistance, tuber shape, tuber flesh colour and non-oxidization. Both candidates had strong yield stability and high tuber yields, outperforming the checks. Based on cooking qualities and nutritional qualities the candidates performed well compared to checks.

title: MLVA-19-XVM : A Multi Locus Variable Number of Tandem Repeat Analysis (MLVA) scheme for the genotyping of Xanthomonas vasicola pv. musacearum (Xvm) isolates
narrative: This multiplex analysis scheme aims at assessing the genetic diversity and structure of the Xvm populations, inducing Xanthomonas wilt on banana and enset. It is composed of 19 Variable Number of Tandem Repeat (VNTR) locus-specific polymerase chain reaction (PCR) primers, gathered in 5 multiplex primer mixes. It is highly specific to the pathovar musacearum of the species X.vasicola, highly resolutive and reproducible.

title: Improved pathogen detection protocol for Ralstonia solanacearum (Rs) phylotype II, the causal agent of Moko disease
narrative: We used complete genome data from all available isolates of the pathogen Ralstonia solanacearum (Rs), to identify and target specific genes in Rs isolates of the phylotype II (causing Moko disease). This allowed the development of an efficient detection protocol. The protocol developed together with the availability of improved inoculation methods will be of great use in Musa breeding programs to detect genetic resistance/tolerance to Moko disease.

title: Banana genotypes with resistance to Xanthomonas vasicola pv. musacearum (Xvm)
narrative: Thirteen genotypes, including Buitenzorg and Monyet, were found resistant to Xanthomonas vasicola pv. musacearum (Xvm). They belong to the banana A genome group. This is the group where most edible bananas belong. This finding opens opportunities for using breeding as a tool to manage this devastating disease.

title: Management practice based on Single Diseased Stem Removal (SDSR) for quick and effective banana recovery in  Xanthomonas wilt (XW) affected regions
narrative: Single diseased stem removal is a disease management practice involving cutting a plant showing Xanthomonas wilt symptoms at soil level, sterilizing cutting tools using fire, and early male bud removal using a forked stick. It's very effective in reducing the incidence of the disease and easy to apply. It requires less labour than alternative practices.

title: Management practice for prevention and control of banana wilt disease (Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense tropical race 4 (Foc TR4)) based on different combinations of fertilization treatments and banana varieties
narrative: The combination of selected banana varieties with specific fertilization treatments (shrimp peptide organic fertilizer, microbial preparation, conventional organic fertilizer)  is showing promising effects on the prevention and control of the disease incidence of Fusarium wilt in China.

title: Banana Musa balbisiana high quality B-genome sequence
narrative: The majority of edible cultivated bananas originated from intraspecific or interspecific hybridization between wild diploid M. acuminata (A-genome) and M. balbisiana (B-genome) species. A high-quality B-genome sequence is required for germplasm characterization and molecular breeding of banana. This high quality sequence has been completed and used to analyze evolution, genetic diversity and functional divergence of subgenomes of banana, providing insights into the evolution and regulation of fruit ripening processes.

title: Chromosome painting facilitates the identification of all chromosomes in banana (Musa Spp.) genome
narrative: Until now it was possible to identify only a few chromosomes in banana karyotypes.  The method of oligo painting Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization (FISH) was established to identify all chromosomes in banana (Musa spp.) and to anchor pseudomolecules of reference genome sequence of Musa acuminata spp. malaccensis “DH Pahang” to individual chromosomes in situ.

title: Pestdisplace: platform to integrate and collectively monitor the occurrence and movement of pests and diseases in RTB and other crops
narrative: Pestdisplace uses novel visualization tools to share, track and communicate the distribution of crop pests and diseases over time and space (longituinal & spatial). A great part of this data was passive (stored in old reports and lab-books) and could not be used for decision making. By facilitating data collation from research and official sources the platforms is intended to accelerate decision making by stakeholders thus reducing risk and/or the impact of pests and diseases on crop yield.

title: VirusDetect: high-throughput sequencing of small RNAs for virus detection
narrative: VirusDetect is a bioinformatics pipeline that efficiently analyzes large scale small RNA (sRNA) datasets for both known and novel virus identification. The technology has proven to be highly efficient, sensible and reliable in plant and animal virus detection.

title: Herbicides Calculator App to Help Farmers Control Weeds
narrative: Mobile app developed by the IITA-led Cassava Weed Management Project (CWMP) to forestall incidents of under-dosing or overdosing of herbicides. It will help resource-poor farmers to maximize the use of their inputs by allowing them to determine correctly the quantity of herbicide needed to add to a knapsack for a given spraying operation.

title: Dataset of the Peruvian Potato Virome, a web platform to detect and identify potato viruses
narrative: The dateset of the Peruvian Potato Virome is organized in a webpage (http://potpathodiv.org/) which includes photos (from field, plants, and collected leaves), field information, and molecular information (genome sequences) of the detected and identified viruses (known and unknown) which are necessary to better understand the diversity and distribution of viruses and their correlation with potato production in Peru.

title: Cassava variety (Mpale) resistant to cassava mosaic disease released in Malawi
narrative: Officially released in Malawi, Mpale is a sweet and high yielding variety (30 tons per hectare) and is more resistant to cassava mosaic disease than Mbundumali, the local sweet variety. It has high dry matter content, is pleasantly mealy when cooked, and makes a good fermented flour, a locally prized delicacy.

title: Potato-legume inter-cropping systems to enhance climate resilience and soil conservation in different agroecologies
narrative: Different potato-legume intercropping combinations optimized for different agro-ecological zones of Kenya, provide benefits for soil conservation, soil nutrients and moisture content, and yield and economic benefits for smallholder farmers.

title: Vertical transmission of tilapia lake virus (TiLV) demonstrated
narrative: Research findings suggested that Tilapia lake virus (TiLV) causes systemic infection in tilapia broodstock with the virus being able to spread into the reproductive organs. Subsequently, the fertilized eggs produced by infected broodstock tested positive for TiLV. The results of this study suggests, for the first time, that TiLV can be transmitted vertically and provides the basis for development of recommendations to manage risks in tilapia hatchery operations.

title: Typology analysis of interventions to reduce antimicrobial use in aquaculture systems
narrative: Aquaculture systems are inherently complex with diverse ecological characteristics. Regulation and enforcement in Low- and Middle-income Countries (LMICs) of responsible use of antimicrobials (AMs) is often inefficient.  A comprehensive typology to understand existing interventions to reduce antimicrobial use (AMU) in aquaculture systems is lacking. Typology analysis was developed and applied in LMICs.

title: Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index (WEFI), a methodological tool for assessing women’s transformative change in fisheries and aquaculture
narrative: A methods package (tool) for assessing women’s empowerment and transformative change in fisheries and aquaculture. The tool draws from the Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index, but has adapted it in key ways: i) for fisheries and aquaculture; ii) for use as a before and after measure; iii) to include both qualitative and quantitative measures; iv) to include measures of gender transformative change, i.e., change in local structural gender barriers, in particular gender norms and attitudes.

title: Use of "garden-irrigation systems" and "WISH ponds (Water and Fish artificial ponds lined with tarpaulin)" for fish production in Myanmar
narrative: Research has explored novel solutions for utilizing small water bodies for fish production on small-holder farms in Myanmar. Innovations focused on two types of water bodies: "garden-irrigation systems" and "Water and Fish" so called WISH ponds. These novel solutions are a viable option for fish culture in Myanmar. This can have important contribution to poverty reduction and food and nutrition security, whilst increasing efficiency and productivity of water systems.

title: Systems-thinking approach for identifying hot-spots for antimicrobial resistance (AMR) emergence and elucidating pathways for human exposure in aquaculture systems
narrative: Aquaculture systems are highly complex, dynamic and interconnected systems influenced by environmental, biological, cultural, socio-economic and human behavioral factors. A systems-thinking approach was used to map two aquaculture systems in Vietnam – striped catfish and white-leg shrimp – to identify hot-spots for emergence and selection of resistance, and human exposure to antibiotics and antibiotic-resistant bacteria.

title: Solar-social innovations to reduce waste and loss, increase incomes and improve equity in capture fisheries systems
narrative: The use of solar technology, including solar-powered freezers, offers opportunities to reduce value and quality losses experienced in fisheries value chains. When solar technologies are developed through action research and combined with social innovations (particularly gender transformative or gender sensitive approaches), the complementary outcomes ranging from increased gender equity, reduction of fish quality loss and increased likelihood of sustainability.

title: Solar updraft Aeration SUpA - Passive Aeration System for Aquaculture in Bangladesh
narrative: The proposed clean energy solution is a new aeration method for aquaculture ponds which does not require electricity, has low maintenance requirements (no moving parts), and can be inexpensively fabricated and deployed in Low-Income Countries (LICs) with local labor and materials. The system is cheaper than current technology (less than 10%) and requires less surface area (around ¼) than expensive photovoltaics which have been suggested as a means of aeration in LICs without grid electricity.

title: Smartphone-based Citizen Science Approach for Improved Fish Catch Monitoring in Bangladesh
narrative: Innovative approach of engaging trained boat skippers as Citizen Scientists with Smart Phone to generate reliable fisheries data have been successfully piloted. The novel catch monitoring system has been introduced in five sanctuaries and marine habitats involving 60 Citizen Scientists, who efficiently provided real-time species-wise catch data directly to database following easy to use Bangla Apps adapted from ODK (open data kit) module.

title: Rupali: Digital platform for input and aquaculture advisory services to increase productivity and efficiency in Bangladesh
narrative: Rupali is an android-based mobile application (app) that aims to improve the availability of knowledge on improved aquaculture practices and access to quality input among farmers.

title: Social, political, environmental and technical adjustments for viability of rice-fish systems in Myanmar
narrative: Integrating agriculture–rice fish, in areas where rice mono-cropping was the only form of agriculture allowed, improves production and sustains livelihoods. Trials demonstrate productivity gains - 13% conversion of rice land to fish refuge sustains/enhances rice production, reduces inputs, increases fish biodiversity, and doubles income per land area through sale of fish. Test plots and early outcomes enabling research progression to compare land use scenarios and deeper challenges of the innovation at scale.

title: Raised Pond System (RPS) in Kenya
narrative: With Raised Pond System (RPS) approach, the fish production facilities, which are made from wood and pond liners, are constructed on earth surface without digging and obstruction of surface. This new design allows fish farmers to practice fish farming in communities and on land that is not suitable for other uses.

title: Public-Private partnership (PPP) model genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) hatchery for scaling of Aquaculture in Timor-Leste
narrative: Improving access to and the availability of quality seed is a prerequisite to the scaling of aquaculture in Timor-Leste. The first Public Private Partnership (PPP) model hatchery, regulated by a public and private stakeholders' agreement, was established at Leohitu village in the west of the country. This has not only helped in narrowing supply – demand gap for seed but has also demonstrated the role of private sectors in scaling of aquaculture in the country.

title: Nearshore fish aggregating devices (FADs)  for food and nutrition security and distributive justice in Timor-Leste
narrative: Nearshore FADs are used in artisanal fisheries to attract oceanic fish within reach of fishers in small boats or paddle canoes.  FADs make fishing more efficient by allowing fishers to spend less time fishing. Enhancing FAD technology in Timor-Leste could be a powerful tool to increase the productivity of SSF while contributing to food security.

title: Methodological innovation for ‘Illuminating Hidden Harvest’ of small-scale fisheries
narrative: An innovative methodology was developed to assess the social, environmental, economic and governance contribution and impacts of small-scale fisheries (SSF) to sustainable development at local, national and global scales. The novel method includes a country-level case study approach linking diverse traditional- and non-traditional data sources, and analyses of employment, nutrition, gender, governance and productivity across the 52 country cases for which data were collected in 2019.

title: Model for enhancing in situ produced protein and highly unsaturated fatty acids (HUFA) in shrimp ponds
narrative: Protein and highly unsaturated fatty acids (HUFA) inclusion in fish diets puts a high demand on natural resource use and are an expensive component in shrimp diets. Fish research discovers that these ingredients in shrimp diets can be reduced by enhancing in ponds the contribution of in situ produced protein and HUFA to shrimp production.

title: Land-use modelling, scenarios and decision-support tools to optimize integrated fish-agri food systems
narrative: Novel GIS and modelling approaches characterizing rice-fish systems integrating biophysical, land-use and rights, demographic and social data layers. This allowed the production of a unique dataset that considers key biophysical, land use and socioeconomic characteristics of the Ayeyarwady Delta region. Outputs include suitability maps designed as decision-support tools and production-system scenarios and trade-off analysis for multi-functional landscapes.

title: Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) introduction in Odisha State (India)
narrative: GIFT strain of tilapia was introduced for the first time in Odisha State in India. The production and management system were defined and set up for starting GIFT production on a larger scale in Odisha State.

title: Generation 1 of improved strain of Silver Carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix)
narrative: Generation 1 of an improved strain of silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix) was spawned (>150 families) in Bangladesh.  The generation 1 of silver carp has an improved growth rate and thus will enhance production.

title: Gender-sensitive financing mechanism for the fisheries sector in Malawi
narrative: Adoption of good capital intensive technologies is challenged by access to financing especially for women and youth in Africa. This financing mechanism comprise of a product that provides access to loans especially to women in the fisheries sector by being sensitive to interest rate, seasonality of fish production and credit risk assessment tool for the fisheries sector. The innovative gender-sensitive financing mechanism, was developed in consultation with stakeholders and potential users.

title: Gender-inclusive sustainable livelihood diagnostic tool
narrative: All too often ‘sustainable livelihood projects’ fail because the local context is not a good match to an external idea or crucial external factors are not known or properly considered. Community members are in many ways best placed to assess the potential livelihoods that best match their situation and this guide aims to assist their efforts in understanding external factors that may be important and local strengths and weaknesses to work with.

title: Gender Transformative Approaches in relation to small-scale fishery and small-scale aquaculture
narrative: An approach to engaging with gender within development that goes beyond ‘business-as-usual’ gender approaches in that it explicitly addresses, rather than accommodates, underlying gender barriers that perpetuate inequalities. Emerging findings indicate that the transformative approaches may contribute to more potent gender outcomes. GTA approach increased women’s participation in fishing (from 5% to 75%) and increased women’s contributions to intra-household decisions about the income generated from processing fish (49%).

title: Gender inclusive methodologies for co-management of fisheries
narrative: Co-management is a dominant, policy-backed approach for fisheries. Whilst it performs well for participation generally, it can exacerbate existing power imbalances. This mixed methods approach assesses drivers and outcomes of inclusion/exclusion (for whom, why, and at which point) in the management process. Subsequent guided participatory reflections allow determination of strategies towards greater inclusion. The methodology includes a training module for projects, programs, organisations to roll out the assessment and respond to findings.

title: Gangetic Hilsa ecotypes/races and its return to natal river for spawning discovered by genetic analysis
narrative: We applied an innovative model that uses fundamental population genomics information to inform conservation and management of Hilsa shad. This help in motivating fishers not to catch the juveniles, as they will get the assurance of getting back the juvenile as adult in the respective rivers. This innovative model that may be valuable for other aquatic species, especially in anadromous fish species that intersect diverse ecotypes during their life-history stages.

title: Generation 7 of genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) has been produced in India
narrative: Fully-pedigreed genetic improvement program for GIFT established in India. GIFT germplasm was supplied to the WorldFish's partner in the genetic program, the Rajiv Ghandi Center for Aquaculture (RGCA) , in 2011 and 2016. Considering 2011 as G0 in India, RGCA has now produced 109 families of G7 in 2019.

title: Fish foresight modelling tools involving quantitative assessments of fish production and consumption patterns
narrative:
An innovative fish sector model that is less data-demanding while able to analyze scenarios and impacts of country’s fish sector​. Fish foresight modeling involves quantitative assessments of fish production and consumption patterns at global, regional and national levels. 

​

title: Digital tool for on-farm performance assessment of aquaculture systems
narrative: A digital tool for on-farm performance assessment of aquaculture systems has been developed and made available for use in FISH CRP focal and scaling countries and by other stakeholders such as public and private sector. This benefits consistency, comparability and effectiveness of research and data delivered around on-farm performance of aquaculture systems.

title: Digital MachHaat: Food Fish Buying and Selling Service for Bangladesh
narrative: Digital MachHaat is a digital market place (mobile app supported by a call center) to connect smallholder fish farmers with fish buyers throughout Bangladesh. This is a digital market linkage platform that will connect smallholder fish farmers with fish buyers of different sizes. It will widen the sales opportunity of smallholder fish farmers to hard to reach buyers through the power of mobile network and smart phones.

title: Database of the nutrient composition of ingredients locally available for low-cost feed formulation in Africa and Asia
narrative: This database presents the nutrient composition of selected locally available ingredients, which can be used by feed manufacturers to formulate low-cost, sustainable aquafeeds in Africa and Asia. The database will be expanded to include information on the digestibility of macro and micro-nutrients for accurate feed formulation.

title: DArTseq molecular genetic marker developed for rohu carp (Labeo rohita)
narrative: Analysis of DArTseq genetic marker data successfully identified and characterised single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and silicoDArT markers in rohu. The analysis identified an unexpectedly high level of sibship among breeding population founders and found no or low levels of divergence in SNPs among the three river populations of rohu carp (Labeo rohita) studied.

title: Coral Triangle (CT) Atlas database portal built upon open source geospatial solutions to enable its sustainability
narrative: The Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs has started to manage an independent CT Atlas database, separated from WorldFish's global ReefBase database, to provide governments, NGOs and researchers with a view of spatial data at the regional scale. The sustainability of the portal has been improved through the integration with the CTI-CFF monitoring and evaluation (M&E) framework that provide continuous updates to the system and ensure its continued use and development.

title: Contextualized better management practices (BMPs)  for genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) in Timor-Leste
narrative: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) in Timor-Leste were developed based on learning from farmers’ field schools (FFSs) and demonstration ponds, including empirical evidences from elsewhere. A BMPs manual was published, in both English and Tetum languages, in partnership with the Ministry of Aquaculture and Fisheries (MAF) to provide guidelines for sustainable intensification of tilapia production systems in Timor-Leste and to serve as a handbook for aquaculture technicians/practitioners.

title: Contextualized better management practices (BMPs) for smallholders farming tilapia (GIFT) in pond-based systems in Zambia
narrative: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for small-holder farming tilapia (GIFT) in pond-based systems in Zambia were developed based on learning from farmers’ field schools (FFSs) and demonstration ponds, including empirical evidences from elsewhere. A BMPs manual was published to provide guidelines for sustainable intensification of tilapia production systems in Zambia and to serve as a handbook for aquaculture technicians/practitioners from different stakeholders such as I/NGOs and private sectors.

title: Community Fish Guards (CFGs) enhanced compliance in coastal biodiversity conservation in Bangladesh
narrative: Enforcement agencies in Bangladesh have insufficient manpower, funds, equipment and transport. To provide the necessary support in patrolling the fish sanctuaries during the juvenile and brood hilsa ban periods, WorldFish through the EcoFish project has introduced the Community Fish Guards (CFGs), a unique initiative to encourage community ownership of the natural resources conservation. CGFs is a co-management process that offers community members an opportunity to engage in local economic development and governance activities.

title: Co-management of community fish refuges (CFRs) in multifunctional rice/wetland landscapes to enhance fish production, water security and adaptive capacity to climate change in Cambodia
narrative: A CFR is a form of stock enhancement or a fish conservation measure to improve the productivity of rice-field fisheries within rice-dominate multi-functional landscapes. The CFR is a refuge, or sanctuary, for brood fish that is protected from fishing year-round and is especially important as fish habitat during the dry season in seasonally inundated rice fields. During the dry season fish refuges in remaining deeper pools, during the flood season the fish emerge to breed.

title: Climate smart culture of genetically improved tilapia through In-Pond Raceway System (IPRS)
narrative: An In-Pond Raceway System (IPRS) was developed in Egypt to recycle water within tilapia pond. The system is established using a raceway cells/units inside ponds and creating a water current in the cell. The open pond area is subdivided by dikes to allow full water circulation through the raceways. The system was developed to improve water use efficiency in tilapia ponds, particularly farms adopting genetically improved tilapia.

title: Boneless Hilsa products (Hilsa soup, Hilsa noodles and Hilsa minced cubes) developed for Bangladesh
narrative: Hilsa (Tenualosa ilisha) is the most popular fish in Bangladesh and Bengali people living abroad, but its pin bones are problematic to many people, especially to younger consumers. Assistance was provided  through the bilateral USAID-funded project ECOFISH and FISH research to formulate and produce boneless hilsa products through a public-private partnership (PPP), involving the Fisheries Technology Department of Bangladesh Agricultural University (BAU) and a private entrepreneur, Virgo Fish & Agro Process.

title: Big data technology and system (PeskAAS) to improve small-scale fisheries management in Timor Leste
narrative: A digital catch documentation system combined with tamper proof, solar powered trackers (developed by the partner Pelagic Data Systems) provided near-real time small-scale fisheries production  and effort information to government fisheries managers on a decision dashboard using open-source software.

title: Rapid genomic detection of aquaculture pathogens
narrative: Tilapia is a major contributor to fish supplies and livelihoods, so diseases in tilapia are an important concern. Early detection of pathogens and their genetic variations are critical to inform disease management and control measures. By leveraging portable sequencing technology and supervised machine learning classification, we develop a genome-wide analysis tool enabling real-time fish pathogens diagnostics and timely investigation of the origins and spread of disease outbreaks.

title: Better Management Practices for Carp Intensification adopted by Women Self Help Groups in India
narrative: Adoption of better management practices for carp polyculture systems involving nutritious small indigenous fish species (the mola carplet, Amblypharyngodon mola) have been set up and used to train Women Self Help Groups in India (Odisha State).

title: Better Management Practices (BMPs), including production of mono sex tilapia and use of probiotics, to enhance tilapia production in Cameroon
narrative: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) in Cameroon are piloted based on demonstration ponds and empirical evidences from other FISH CRP focal and scaling countries.

title: Predictive analytical and data tools enabling nutrition-sensitive management of fisheries
narrative: Data for 4500 nutrient measures, 419 fish species, across 45 counties were collated, analysed with ecological traits and used in predictive Bayesian hierarchical models. Real and predicted nutrient values were applied to national fisheries landings to determine nutrient potential of catches relative to malnutrition risks in each country. Model outputs identified where changes to fisheries management, trade and distribution could better address particular nutrition deficiency risks per country.

title: Advantages of inclusion of slowly degradable fibres (non starch polysaccharides - NSP) in fish diets for circularity in food production
narrative: Plant-based ingredients incorporated in formulated fish feed are often rich in fibres (non starch polysaccharides-NSP) which are difficult to digest by fish. This lowers the fish feed's overall digestibility. FISH research discovered that when NSPrich-plant-based ingredients are incorporated in the fish diet, extra energy and nutrients are funneled into the pond's food web, enhancing natural food availability and increasing fish natural food consumption that contribute to circularity in agriculture-aquaculture food systems.

title: A smartphone app providing aquaculture extension information in Myanmar
narrative: A virtual aquaculture extension application has been co-designed with a local ICT company called Greenway. The app has been designed based on their previous agriculture and livestock App in use by 85,000 farmers. The Aquaculture App brings access to weather forecasts for the immediate area where the farmer is located. It also delivers messages about sourcing inputs (seed and feed), market prices and trends plus climate risks.

title: Four scaling approaches for community-based, co-management for coastal fisheries in Solomon Islands
narrative: Community-based, co-management approaches are nationally (and Pacific regionally) agreed as the main strategy through which coastal fisheries livelihoods and food security will be secured. Strategies to spread community-based approaches are now being tested utilizing earlier research findings and mobilizing sub-national and national partnerships and enabled by changes in the policy.

title: A novel mixed-method approach to climate change vulnerability assessments for fish production systems in Myanmar
narrative: A methodological innovation built upon the IPCC 2014 risk assessment - adjusted for application in integrated fish production systems. Adaptations to the method include broader analysis of exposure to compounding risks (i.e., climate change+) and use of consultative processes and perception data.  The new methodology suits the hazard and vulnerability profile of Myanmar's fish production systems (i.e., aquaculture, inland fisheries and fish in agri-food systems).

title: Multi-model systems analysis to identify Low Emissions Development Pathways – exploring synergies and trade-offs in Mahbubnagar District, Telangana, India
narrative: Triple-win solutions with positive contributions to productivity, adaptation and mitigation are the key to achieve sustainable agricultural systems. Quantifying synergies and trade-offs among these we employed simulation modelling- crop, livestock and whole-farm models, and Cool Farm Tool to estimate net GHG emissions.  Multi-model systems analysis using participatory design and tools could be a decision support for policymakers guiding investments towards synergistic climate smart agriculture strategies.

title: High yielding Pearl millet hybrid: BHB 1602 for drought prone environments of north-west India
narrative: Average grain yield 18.21 q/ha, dry fodder yield 42.29 q/ha, maturity in 75-79 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for drier regions of Rajasthan, Gujarat and Haryana.

title: Iron and zinc-biofortified Pearl millet cultivar: ICMH 1301 (Phule Mahashakti) for India
narrative: Iron biofortified hybrid, average grain yield 29.30 q/ha, dry fodder yield 56 q/ha, maturity in 88 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for Maharashtra state.

title: Iron and zinc-biofortified Pearl millet cultivar: ICMH 1505 (GHB 1225) for India
narrative: Iron biofortified hybrid, average grain yield 30.23 q/ha, dry fodder yield 73.06 q/ha, maturity in 81 days, resistance to downy mildew other disease and insect pests. This hybrid was identified for Gujarat state.

title: New forage sorghum hybrid - Punjab Sudax Chari 4 developed using ICRISAT-bred female parent ICSA 94012 was released by Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana, India
narrative: The Punjab Sudex Chari 4 (PSC 4)  is a multi-cut forage sorghum hybrid developed at Punjab Agricultural University, Ludhiana, India from a cross between ICSA 94012 x SGL 87.

title: Chickpea cultivar: ICCV 08112 (BG 3062)
narrative: This Chickpea cultivar is Fusarium wilt resistant and moderate resistant to dry root rot. It is also suitable for machine harvest.

title: Chickpea cultivar: ICCIL 01029 (Geletu)
narrative: This chickpea cultivar is developed by marker-assisted back crossing  crosses (breeding and molecular) and high yielding variety. It is drought tolerant variety.

title: Chickpea cultivar: ICCV 07108
narrative: It is high yielding, fusarium wilt and extra early maturity variety.

title: Chickpea cultivar: ICCV 04305 (Koka)
narrative: This chickpea cultivar is Fusarium wilt resistant and high-yielding kabuli variety.

title: Early maturing, groundnut rosette disease resistant groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 01514 (MGV9) for Zambia, Tanzania and Malawi
narrative: This groundnut cultivar is a short duration variety with resistance to groundnut rosette disease.

title: Drought tolerant, and high yielding groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 03520 (AMM – 018) for Mozambique
narrative: The variety is high yielding and drought tolerant.

title: Drought tolerant, and high yielding groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 03530 (Mapupulo 2018) for Mozambique
narrative: This cultivar is a drought-tolerant and high yielding variety suited for the lowland mid altitudes.

title: Drought tolerant, and aphid resistant groundnut cultivar: ICGV-SM 08528 (AMENA 2018) for Mozambique
narrative: This cultivar has aphid resistance and is early-maturing.

title: High oleic groundnut cultivar, Girnar 4 (ICGV 15083) available in India
narrative: Girnar 4 is a high-oleic Virginia Bunch variety with more than 80% oleic acid content. This groundnut variety is the first high oleic commercially released cultivar in India.

title: High oleic groundnut cultivar, Girnar 5 (ICGV 15090) available in India
narrative: Girnar 5 is a high oleic Virginia Bunch groundnut variety with more than 80% oleic acid content and an average pod yield of 3147 Kg/ha in national trials.

title: Large seeded groundnut variety: CG7 (EUGN-1) for Kenya
narrative: This cultivar has high yield potential, medium duration.

title: High yielding groundnut cultivar ICGV 08307 (EUGN-2) for Kenya
narrative: This variety has high yield potential.

title: ICEAP 00557-1 (Egerton Mbaazi 3): a new pigeonpea medium maturing cultivar with drought tolerance and fusarium wilt resistance, for mid and high altitude areas of Kenya
narrative: This cultivar has medium duration, is drought tolerant, Fusarium wilt resistant, and released for cultivation in mid and high altitude areas of Kenya. It is suitable for both green peas and dry grain. It is suitable for ratooning.

title: ICEAP 00554-1 (Egerton Mbaazi 4): a new pigeonpea medium maturing cultivar with drought tolerance and fusarium wilt resistance, for Kenya and Zambia
narrative: Medium maturing variety with drought tolerance and fusarium wilt resistance, released for cultivation in mid-high altitude semi-arid areas of Kenya. Variety is suitable for both green peas and dry grain. Also suitable for ratooning and intercropping systems with cereals and legumes.

title: UFM 19-1 (KNE 689): a new finger millet high yielding variety for Mid Altitude Medium rainfall in Kenya and Tanzania
narrative: KNE 689 is medium duration variety flowering at 55-60 and maturing at 100 days. Mature plant is 85-100 cm tall, erect, tan in color with green leaves. the pant has large open ears with a good exertion (7-12 cm). The seeds are brown in color and exposed glume covering. Has a yield potential of 2.5-4.5 tha-1, large open eyes, has moderate resistance to drought and high resistance to blast and striga.

title: Methods for assessing poverty reduction due to adoption of improved varieties
narrative: Adoption of improved agricultural technologies has long been recognized as critical for reducing poverty through increased productivity, incomes, and asset accumulation. Using a nationally representative survey data from a sample of  >1500 households in Nigeria. The method involves a comparative evaluation of poverty headcount ratios based on the observed and counterfactual income distributions with and without technology adoption where the size of the income effects of adoption is first derived using endogenous switching regression techniques.

title: Farming system sustainability assessment through mix-methods approach for arid and semi-arid regions
narrative: The major outcomes of this activity is a Comprehensive framework for farming systems sustainability assessment and an open access online tool for sustainability assessment, resulting capacity development of of partners on sustainability assessment innovation (see evidence link), and publication on Measuring farm household vulnerability and resilience among the intermediate outcomes. The online tool will be available for stakeholders to use by the end of 2020 or early 2021, then will be piloted in 2021.

title: Model to assess sustainable intensification in the ‘old cotton basin’ in southern Mali
narrative: Rapid population growth in sub-Saharan Africa demands an intensification of the agri-cultural production. Accordingly, a model was developed to assess sustainable intensification in the baseline situation and in six subsequent scenarios, based on incremental policy intervention and agricultural intensification strategies, for 411 smallholder farms in the ‘old cotton basin’ in southern Mali. The model checked for different SI indicators from four domains of sustainability.

title: Crop modelling tools for identifying the G×E×M options for enhancing resilience and productivity of sorghum in India
narrative: In this innovation “Crop modelling tools for identifying the G×E×M options for enhancing resilience and productivity of rabi sorghum in India” we put in place the APSIM modelling framework enabling the target stakeholders (primarily the sorghum improvement teams) to understand the spatial variability of post rainy sorghum production systems in India and the optimal GxM leading to production stabilization/enhancement in given E. The baseline framework and will be further developed with stakeholder feedback.

title: Bio-control agents of pests and diseases in Benin and Burkina Faso
narrative: These biocontrol agents which are now ready for scaling out in West Africa uses Therophilus javanus, and has long field viability as evidenced in collected parasitized Maruca vitrata caterpillars in cowpea pods in experiments in Benin and Burkina Faso. Result is pest pod-borer populations have been consistently low, with an average of 86.3% reduction with the use of this biocontrol agent.

title: Plant growth promoting microorganisms (PGP) for sweet sorghum
narrative: Sweet sorghum bagasse compost prepared with microbes successfully promoted plant growth and significantly enhanced yields in sweet sorghum. Also, five strains of Streptomyces and another 5 strains of Bacillus were evaluated as bio-control agents against Fusarium wilt and PGP agents in chickpea. Under both greenhouse and wilt sick field conditions, the selected Streptomyces and Bacillus isolates reduced disease incidence and delayed expression of symptoms of disease, over the non-inoculated

title: Molecular breeding products released in chickpea and groundnut
narrative: The breeding work was supported by ICRISAT’s Genetic Gains research program and partners. Genomic tools that enabled early generation selection, wherein molecular markers developed at University of Georgia, USA for two FAD (Fatty Acid Desaturase) mutant alleles were used in Marker Assisted Breeding to develop high oleic groundnut lines. The linked allele-specific and cleaved amplified polymorphic sequences (CAPS) markers for both the mutant alleles were used in the breeding.

title: RapidGen (RGT) Platform
narrative: The workings of this innovation can mimic the right set of conditions within these closed installations to convince a plant to grow faster at high density and to reproduce quickly.  These set of conditions, which we call ‘recipes’, are crop specific-protocols to hasten the crop cycle while producing healthy, viable seeds. This innovation is all about the test bed/condition optimization to speed up the growth and life cycle of specific crops.

title: Five soybean (high yield & large size) and six cowpea genotypes (multi-traits) selected for further integration into cropping systems in Mozambique
narrative: Five soybean genotypes with yields ranging from 5.1-5.8 tons/ha with large seed size (15.2 to 25.9 g/100-seed) have been selected. For cowpea, the top six high- yielding genotypes had yields ranging from 1.2-1.5 tons/ha and four were selected by farmers based on six traits (high yield, early maturity, pods load, cooking time,  taste, and pest and disease resistance.

title: Identification of varieties of groundnut and pigeonpea for intercrops to optimize yields
narrative: Identified groundnut and pigeonpea varieties that optimize  yields of smallholder farmers when intercropped. Land equivalent ratios of the intercrop combinations were greater than unity indicating more efficient and productive use of environmental resources by the intercrops than sole crops.  Returns on investments by farmers were greater for intercrops compared either sole crop.

title: Markers deployment in breeding programs in groundnut, sorghum and soybean
narrative: Marker-assisted backcrossing (MABC) is the most successful approach to introgressing or pyramiding one or more traits using traitlinked markers. We used MABC to improve three popular Indian cultivars (GJG 9, GG 20, and GJGHPS 1) for foliar disease resistance (FDR) and high oleic acid content. To improve Annigeri 1 and JG 74, we introgressed a genomic region conferring resistance against FW race 4 (foc4) through marker-assisted backcrossing using WR 315 as the donor parent.

title: Genome editing platform for sorghum
narrative: Platform caters to all aspects of gene editing including workflows with bioinformatics, cloning and genetic transformation, and screening. In collaboration with our private partner, Corteva, we established the genome editing platform (technology, vectors, next gen transformation etc.) in sorghum.

title: Quality control panel developed and initially validated in groundnut and pearl millet
narrative: Sequencing, SNP discovery and shortlisting of 48 most promising SNPs in addition to 10 more informative SNPs for which KASP assay already available. KASP assay developed for all the 48 SNPs and verified at Intertek (Hyderabad) on ICRISAT germplasm. Tested successfully the initial quality check panel with 20 SNPs by genotyping 1536 groundnut samples from HQ. This innovation once deployed in breeding program will enhance the accuracy to check true crosses.

title: Varietal performance assessment using crowd-sourcing citizen science approach  to test sorghum and finger millet varieties in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania
narrative: Innovative application of the crowdsourcing citizen science approach and the use of the tricot methodology to test the varieties of sorghum and finger millet in Kenya, Uganda and Tanzania. the technical methodology is also called Triadic Comparison of Technologies (TRICOT), and the process is managed by ClimMob app.  The involvement of a large number of farmers in testing varieties, allows to have a more significant feedback than when using conventional Participatory Variety Selection (PVS).

title: Hybrid model including expert generated and environmental covariates for mapping BXW spread risks in Africa
narrative: The proposed model combines covariates generated using knowledge of experts and available literature to improve the predictions of regression models that use limited surveys points to make predictions over larger areas.

title: Monitoring and Evaluation of Land in Africa framework
narrative: The Monitoring and Evaluation of Land in Africa (MELA) framework allows tracking of progress on commitments made under the African Union Declaration on Land Governance in Africa, including commitments to land rights for women and special groups, e.g. pastoralists.

title: Improved Rice Variety WITA 9
narrative: WITA9 was selected and released for lowland agro-ecosystems primarily because of its resistance to Rice yellow mottle virus (RYMV), a devastating yet common disease in Côte d’Ivoire.

title: Soil-plant spectral diagnostic protocols for rapid and low-cost analysis of soil properties and plant nutrients using only light (infrared, x-rays)
narrative: The rapidity and low cost of this technology allows soil and plant analysis to be conducted faster and at wider scales than was previously possible. This permits digital mapping of soil properties and measurement of nutrient constraints faced by different crops in multiple agronomic trials over large areas. It is also enabling soil and plant testing services to be delivered to smallholder farmers through handheld devices.

title: Nine promising heat stress tolerant maize inbred lines with desirable secondary traits and grain yield under severe heat stress
narrative:
Heat stress resilience has emerged as an important trait in maize hybrids targeted for post–monsoon spring cultivation in large parts
of South Asia and many other parts of the tropics. Selection based on grain yield alone under heat stress is often misleading, and
therefore an approach involving stress-adaptive secondary traits along with grain yield could help in the development of improved,
stable heat stress tolerant cultivars. A panel of 99 elite maize inbred lines representing the
wider genetic diversity of tropical maize and a set of 58 elite hybrids were phenotyped under natural heat stress and optimal
temperature for grain yield and 15 secondary traits including 10 morpho-physiological traits and 5 yield attributes. Of these, the study identified nine promising heat stress tolerant maize inbred lines with desirable
secondary traits and grain yield under severe heat stress, which could be used as source germplasm in heat stress tolerance maize
breeding program.

title: Identification of more productive, resilient and farmer-preferred chicken breeds for Ethiopian, Tanzanian and Nigerian smallholder farmers
narrative: Through the African Chicken Genetic Gains (ACGG) program, the International Livestock Research Institute (ILRI) identified three chicken strains (Sasso in Ethiopia, Kuroiler and Sasso in Tanzania and Noiler in Nigeria) which demonstrate higher productivity levels and climate adaptability and are also preferred by farmers.

title: Bean cultivar: NAROBEAN 7
narrative: NAROBean 7 was developed and released in Uganda in 2019. it is drought tolerance and resistance to major diseases (anthracnose, BCMV, ALS and rust).

title: Novel insurance-linked credit product that covers loan repayment during drought for Kenyan smallholder farmers
narrative: Weather-related agricultural risks and limited access to credit are serious impediments to agricultural productivity and growth in developing countries. This innovation is a novel insurance-linked credit model piloted in Kenya. In this model, drought risk related perils are transferred from borrower to lender via an insurance premium paid by borrowers. A drought event triggers repayment of the loan by the insurer, thereby increasing incentives for farmers to borrow.

title: Stories of Change, a structured case study approach which systematically assesses and analyzes drivers of nutritional change in specific country contexts
narrative: Stories of Change is a structured case study approach which systematically assesses and analyzes drivers of nutritional change in specific country contexts. These resulting ‘stories’ improve our understanding of what drives impact in reducing undernutrition, and how enabling environments and pro-nutrition policy and implementation processes can be cultivated and sustained.

title: Multistakeholder dialogue tool for cross-border integrated landscape management in Kenya and Somalia
narrative: Conflicts over natural resource management intertwined with insecurity and lack of capacity make it difficult for local governments at the border between Kenya and Somalia to engage in a constructive dialogue. The multistakeholder dialogue tool provides a platform for exchange of information between stakeholders, with the aim of conserving biodiversity resources in the Tana-Kipini-Badana bushland and seascapes of Kenya and Somalia.

title: Picture-based insurance: delivering affordable crop insurance using farmers' smartphone pictures to assess crop damage
narrative: Farmers register each site to be insured through an initial picture taken via a smartphone App. They take follow-up pictures to trigger personalized advisories, monitor crop health, and document losses. When assessing claims, experts evaluate the damage using the pictures. The pictures are geotagged and time-stamped, and the App has built-in features to prevent tampering with pictures.

title: "Agroclimatic similarity" variable developed to improve the measurement of the spatial spillover potential of agricultural R&D investments
narrative: A novel variable, the agroclimatic similarity between the locations of plant breeding institutes and the locations of the farms that adopt the improved technologies developed in these institutes, is introduced. This variable provides a useful indicator of spatial variations in spillover potentials of agricultural technologies developed through public investments. In 2020, this methodology was further applied and improved to capture a more complex, multi-faceted concept of "agroclimatic similarity".

title: E-learning course on Mainstreaming Biodiversity for Food and Nutrition (available in English, Portuguese and Turkish)
narrative: Targeting multiple stakeholders, this free online course is divided into 4 modules, with 7 interactive lessons, covering: The main issues and barriers of the current food production and consumption patterns and how they affect biodiversity; The importance of biodiversity and how it can be integrated across different sectors to create more sustainable and nutritious food systems; International and national policies and initiatives related to biodiversity conservation, food and nutrition security; Practical tools, metrics and indicators.

title: Biodiversity Mainstreaming for Healthy and Sustainable Food Systems - A toolkit
narrative: Targeting policy makers and practitioners, this open-access guide outlines the main steps to mainstream biodiversity into policy and practices drawing on case studies from Brazil, Kenya, Sri Lanka and Turkey.

title: Methodology to assess drivers of vegetables intake in urban Nigeria
narrative: The methodology provides insights into how to assess an aspect of the food environment, in particular, vegetable consumption behavior of urban consumers across different socioeconomic classes, their main food choice motives, and the associations of these motives and other drivers with consumption. It can be useful in the design of food system interventions.

title: Project-level Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index for Market Inclusion
narrative: The project-level Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index for Market Inclusion (pro-WEAI+MI) includes the core pro-WEAI module as well as new complementary indicators to investigate barriers to market access and inclusion for different value chain actors.

title: Agricultural Investment for Development Analyzer tool designed to help governments and donors prioritize agricultural investments in the Middle East and North Africa
narrative: The Agricultural Investment Data Analyzer (AIDA) is the first online tool that uses an economy-wide model to assess the impact of agricultural investments on economic growth, job creation and household welfare at country level. Users design a package of investments and AIDA predicts how these investments will affect the country's economy and population. AIDA helps governments and donors strengthen policy dialogues and prioritize interventions. AIDA is available for Egypt, Tunisia, Yemen and Jordan.

title: SMART-Valleys: a new participatory approach for land and water management in Benin and Togo
narrative: Smart-Valleys is a participatory approach used by smallholder farmers for land and water management for rice-based systems in inland valleys. The approach enables farmers to improve, at low cost, water control by using simple means to design and construct drainage axes for siting of irrigation canals and create bunded and levelled fields according to the topological conditions.

title: RiceAdvice: an android based decision support tools for Nigeria
narrative: Android based decision support tools for providing farmers with field-specific management guidelines for rice production systems in Africa

title: Cropping calendar construction model for rice production in Madagascar, Senegal
narrative: Excel-based decision support tool that can generate, compare and visualise opportunities for single/double/triple cropping systems consisting of irrigated rice and optionally a vegetable/legumes

title: Alternate wetting and drying (AWD) in Africa
narrative: Alternate wetting and drying is a water saving technology that enables irrigated rice cultivation with less water than the conventional practice of maintaining the field continuously flooded. Under AWD, ﬁelds are subjected to intermittent ﬂooding where irrigation is interrupted, and water is allowed to subside until the soil reaches a certain moisture level, after which the field is re-flooded. It has been reported that this technology can reduce water input and GHG without yield penalty.

title: Pro-WEAI (project-level Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index)
narrative: The pro-WEAI is a survey-based index that builds on the Abbreviated Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index (A-WEAI). It measures women’s empowerment reported at project level, with an enhanced livestock module and an add-on module specific to nutrition and health projects. It is made up of 12 indicators that measure three types of agency: intrinsic agency, instrumental agency, and collective agency. It was developed as part of Phase 2 of the Gender, Agriculture, and Assets Project.

title: Web-based map on knowledge and tools on implementation science for nutrition to support Scaling up Nutrition (SUN) countries
narrative: This web-based map provides users with details of tools available across countries and regions within the field of implementation science for nutrition. The map is structured around nutrition programming categories allowing users to browse by category of interest. Formative research highlighted the need for country specific knowledge, so map is browsable by country and region, making scientific and contextual information more accessible to implementers and policymakers.

title: MINCER micrometerological station used to improve spikelet sterility estimations in crop models for rice
narrative: Tools were developed for the adaptation of crop models to improve rice spikelet sterility induced by extreme temperatures.  A radiation-shielded, solar-powered, force-ventilated system that is designed to facilitate its use by researchers to  accurately measure the thermal environment within the canopy.

title: Use of nudges to improve food safety in the pork value chain in Viet Nam
narrative: Based on nudge theory, a sub-field of behavioral economics, ‘nudges’ are interventions with a low level of intrusiveness on personal choice that can be used to alter the behavior of people, in this case value chain actors in the pork value chain to change their behavior in ways that reduce risks of foodborne illness.

title: CGIAR Core Metadata Schema version 2
narrative: CGIAR Generic metadata schema for harmonizing the description of CGIAR information products in repositories.The CG Core aims to describe all types of information products that are published by the different CGIAR centres. There are many benefits of having a clear and harmonised way to describe information products: better interoperability, better transparency and easy monitoring.

title: Aflasafe MWMZ01 and Aflasafe MW02 for Malawi
narrative: Biocontrol approach to preventing aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: AfricaRice weather: a free web-database
narrative: Web-based database for sharing weather data collected by AfricaRice and its partners for free. Our data are same as those in AfricaRice dataverse. We consider this dataverse as backstop for storage/access, and our website is more user-friendly and convenient.

title: Weather-rice-nutrient integrated decision support system (WeRise) in Indonesia
narrative: WeRise is a web-based, seasonal climate prediction-based decision support system for rainfed rice farmers through integration of statistical downscaling model of GCM (global climate model) and crop growth model. WeRise provides an optimum variety, and timing for sowing and fertilizer application which are key information to deal with yield increase in rainfed. In collaboration with local partners in research and agricultural extension, field validations were conducted in Laos, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

title: Weather-rice-nutrient integrated decision support system (WeRise) in Philippines
narrative: WeRise is a web-based, seasonal climate prediction-based decision support system for rainfed rice farmers through integration of statistical downscaling model of GCM and crop growth model. WeRise provides an optimum variety, and timing for sowing and fertilizer application which are key information to deal with yield increase in rainfed rice. In collaboration with local partners in research and agricultural extension, field validations were conducted in Laos, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

title: Enhanced P-cycling with stylosanthes (Stylosanthes guianensis) in upland rice-based cropping systems in Madagascar
narrative: Soils in the lowland and upland rice fields were found to be mostly P deficient with high P-fixation by Al- and Fe- oxides in the central highland of Madagascar. Introducing stylosanthes (Stylosanthes guianensis) having its high Fe-P solubilizing capacity as a cover/relay crop can enhance phosphorus cycling in upland rice-based cropping systems.

title: Toolkit to capture diversity and drivers of food choice of a target population to identify entry points for novel food products and nutritional interventions
narrative: The toolkit aims at capturing diversity and drivers of food choice of a target population to identify entry points for novel food products and nutritional interventions. It proposes a novel framework of "gastronomic systems research" (GSR) and a research protocol with six components: (1) expert elicitation workshop; (2) standardization of food dishes in nutritional laboratory; (3) consumer survey, (4) use of an interactive tablet application; (5) behavioral change communication strategy; and (6) behavioral experiments.
