title: Food Choice Application (FCA): An interactive tablet application for capturing diversity of food choice
narrative: The FCA maps the weekly food portfolio of a household by featuring all dish options that can be consumed during a set of eating occasions over seven days of the week. Respondents can specify the number of servings of the dishes their household are planning to consume using up/down buttons in half steps of servings. As the servings increase, a budget bar indicates the available percent budget left for the household to invest.

title: Policy sequencing framework for rice value chain upgrading in West Africa
narrative: A three-stage policy sequence required to upgrade rice value chains is developed for import-biased countries. The first stage focuses on enhancing rice quality though contracts, the improvement of post-harvest practices, and investment in modern milling technologies. The second stage consists of scaling through investment in irrigation infrastructure, productivity enhancement and storage infrastructure as well as of supporting the working capital of millers. The third stage involves advertising to increase consumer demand for domestic rice.

title: Solar Bubble Dryer, a mobile and low-cost drying technology for rice
narrative: This is a mobile and low-cost drying technology for rice for solving the drying problems by providing a simple and flexible alternative to sun drying that offers protection of the grains from rain. It is also a climate smart technology as it does not require an external energy source. It consists of a drying tunnel inflated by ventilators that are powered by a photovoltaic system.

title: Rice straw downdraft furnace for paddy drying in the Philippines
narrative: The downdraft rice straw furnace was newly developed by IRRI for a 4-ton paddy flatbed dryer in 2019. This was adapted from the downdraft rice husk furnace which was also developed by a consortium led by IRRI. Factorial and optimization combustion experiments on the furnace connected to a paddy flatbed dryer simulator were performed to maximize drying air efficiency and minimize cost. Its heating efficiency from straw combustion is 50-60%.

title: New method and indicators for measuring inclusiveness of value chain upgrading
narrative: Devising correct and targeted policies for fostering inclusiveness in value chain upgrading crucially hinges on deploying correct econometric specification of the decision to participate in value chain upgrading. To illustrate this, we model participation in and intensity of value chain upgrading in four different ways along the vertical coordination continuum: as a discrete, categorical, ordered, and continuous choice.  The method evaluates and juxtaposes several indicators of inclusiveness of value chain upgrading.

title: Indicators and protocol to identify sustainable post harvest management practices in rice production in Vietnam and Myanmar
narrative: The indicators and protocol to identify sustainable post harvest management practices were developed by using Life-Cycle Assessment approach. These were used to identify best drying practices and sustainable post harvest management in Vietnam and Myanmar.

title: Market-based incentive mechanism for adoption of sustainable production standards throughout rice value chains, in Vietnam
narrative: We develop and pilot a market-based incentive mechanism for the adoption of sustainable production standards throughout rice value chains. We elicit consumers’ willingness-to-pay (WTP) for rice produced and labeled under a national sustainable production standard through experimental auctions under gradually-increasing levels of information on certification and traceability. Findings suggest that sustainable production labels for rice should be accompanied by supplementary information on certification and traceability to increase consumers’ awareness and appreciation of sustainably-produced rice.

title: An automated approach for mapping inland valleys on suitability for rice production in Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: We developed an automated approach for mapping inland valleys from digital elevation models (DEM), which utilizes three main attributes of inland valleys, namely lowness in the local landscape, wetness in the local landscape and lower stream order. The approach is a fuzzy-based morphometric approach that allows for broad-scale inland valley morphometry as well as smaller valleys to be delineated without unnecessary detail.

title: ARICA 6, an iron toxicity-tolerant rice variety for West and Central Africa
narrative: Iron toxicity is one of the most important abiotic stresses limiting rice production in SSA lowlands and affects up to 60% of the lowland rice area in West and Central Africa. ARICA 6 has shown that it is high-yielding, well adapted to plains and lowlands and very tolerant of iron toxicity. Impact assessment showed that ARICA 6 variety increased rice yield by 330 kg ha-1 and net income by US$ 120 ha-1

title: Sustainable Rice Platform (SRP) Standard and Performance Indicators in Africa
narrative:
SRP Performance Indicators are designed to assess sustainability improvements resulting from changes in farm practice, and include profitability, labor and land productivity, food safety, resource use efficiency, climate change mitigation, labor conditions, and
women empowerment. The Standard defines a set of key requirements with different levels of performance allowing for a stepwise improvement and compliance process.

title: Upland rice-based cropping systems with conservation agriculture in Ivory Coast
narrative: Alternative cropping systems for improving soil quality, system productivity, and climate resilience, as well as reducing weed and pest pressure. This include rice and maize together with forage legumes such as stylosanthes.

title: RiceAdvice-WeedManager android application for Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: Andorid application for generating farm-specific advices for weed management to smallholder rice farmers for Android based smartphones and e-tablets

title: RiceAdvice: an android-based application for rice crop management in Burkina Faso, Mali and Senegal
narrative: Android based decision support tools for providing farmers with field-specific management guidelines for rice production systems in Africa

title: Smart-Valleys approach in Burkina Faso, Liberia and Sierra Leone
narrative: Smart-Valleys is a participatory approach used by smallholder farmers for land and water management for rice-based systems in inland valleys. The approach enables farmers to improve, at low cost, water control by using simple means to design and construct drainage axes for siting of irrigation canals and create bunded and leveled fields according to the topological conditions.

title: Optimal irrigation scheduling for off-season vegetable crops in Côte d'Ivoire
narrative: Farmers in Côte d'Ivoire need recommendations on water management for off-season vegetable crops. We developed an optimal irrigation scheduling in the dry season to increase the yield of vegetable crops and water productivity

title: Water management options for malaria and climate change mitigation in intensified rice production in Cote d'Ivoire
narrative: The water management options could reduce malaria transmission potential and greenhouse gas emission while increasing water productivity and rice yield. We are testing different water management options to identify suitable water management practices for the above targets.

title: Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) for improving rice productivity in Senegal
narrative: GAP is an integration of management practices that encompasses land preparation options (bunding, puddling and leveling), crop establishment method, variety choice, weed, and nutrient management along with crop calendar and record-keeping for improved rice productivity. A total of 83 farmers including 33 women were trained on applying GAP for sustainable rice production in 2020.

title: High potential inland valley maps for rice intensification in Cote d'Ivoire and Ghana
narrative: We developed an integrated mapping approach to assess the potential of inland valleys for agricultural development and ecosystem services preservation. Our approach utilizes freely available data from remote sensing on the biophysical and socio-economic characteristics of inland valleys. The evaluation metrics were higher than 90% for both training and validation datasets.

title: Rice-legume and vegetables rotation systems in lowlands in Cote d'Ivoire
narrative: Development of locally adapted rice-legume and vegetables rotation systems could increase food and nutritional security. Furthermore, the systems could boost soil carbon and nitrogen, provide nutritional support to the small-holder farmers, increase the system productivity, and reduce the weed pressure due to its smothering effect, driving the rice-based system towards the sustainable intensification.

title: Mechanical seeders to save labor for direct seeded rice in the lowland and upland of Madagascar
narrative: Three different types of mechanical seeders were developed to save labor in direct seeded rice. The seeders were tested in lowland and upland conditions in Madagascar. The three manual seeders reduced the labour requirement by 60-70% compared to manual seeding. Received feedback from 222 farmers for further improvement and are being improved considering the farmers feedback.

title: Fertiseeder, a manual seeder cum fertilizer micro-dose applicator in Madagascar
narrative: A manual seeder cum fertilizer micro-dose applicator (Fertiseeder) developed to save labor in direct seeding and micro-dose placement. The fertiseeder was tested in lowland and upland conditions in Madagascar. Fertiseeder reduced the labour requirement by 74% compared to manual seeding and micro-dose placement. Received feedback from 222 farmers for further improvement and the fertiseeder is being improved considering the farmers feedback.

title: Two Adapted Motorized Weeder (AMW) for irrigated and rainfed lowland systems in sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: Locally adapted two-row Motorized Paddy Weeder (AMW) developed in collaboration with private fabricators. The weeder can be used in irrigated and rainfed lowland systems and can save labour for weeding up to 80%.

title: Two-row Motorized Paddy Weeder for Irrigated and Rainfed Lowland Systems in Eastern Africa
narrative: The locally adapted two-row Motorized Paddy Weeder is being developed in collaboration with private fabricators in Kenya, Uganda and Madagascar. The weeder can be used in irrigated and rainfed lowland systems and can save labour for weeding up to 80%.

title: Crop diversification options to improve farmers' livelihoods in Madagascar lowlands
narrative: Crop diversification options by introducing different vegetables and legumes options before and after lowland rice cultivation in the wet season in the highlands of Madagascar.

title: Mechanical weeders for rice production in Sub Saharan Africa
narrative:
Mechanical weeders could reduce labour requirements for weeding as well as the use of herbicides and be
instrumental in downsizing overall production costs. There are different types such as 1) ring hoe; 2) twisted-spike conical weeder; 3) curved-spike conical weeder; 4) straight-spike conical weeder; 5) straight spike weeder; 6) simple rotary weeder. 1 and 6 are new types for testing in Africa. Others existed before, but we tested in new sites.

title: Good agricultural practices (GAP) to improve rice productivity in Tanzania
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability.

title: Good agricultural practices (GAP) to improve rice productivity in Madagascar
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices (GAP) that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability. GAP components were modern cultivar, line planting, fertilizer application and rotary weeding.

title: Good agricultural practices (GAP) to improve rice productivity in Uganda
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices (GAP) that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability. GAP components were Variety Wita9, Line planting, 15-24day old seedlings, fertilizer application and timely harvesting.

title: Development of micronutrient fertilizer strategies for rice yield increase in Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: Deficiency of micronutrients from soils is thought to be one of limiting factors for rice production in SSA. A combination of different micronutrients (Mg, S, Zn, B, Cu) increased the rice yields by 0.6 t/ha under irrigated lowland and by 1.8 t/ha under rainfed lowland conditions in Tanzania, when applied as a basal application, together with NPK fertilizers.

title: Integrated package for sustainable restoration of silvopasture production systems in Tunisia
narrative: Using a participatory approach, all concerned stakeholders conducted a thorough diagnostic of the silvopasture production systems, identified critical gaps and  addressed these deficiencies using an integrated package for sustainable restoration of silvopasture in Tunisia.

title: Toolbox for sustainable rehabilitation of rangelands in arid environments
narrative: New rangeland management toolbox based on an integrated and multidisciplinary approach to achieve sustainable practices. The toolbox takes into account the spatial and temporal variability of the complexity of rangeland ecosystems. A combination of sustainable rangeland management tools are available ranging from simple soil surface scarification to deep ripping to livestock grazing management.

title: SEONT: Agricultural Household Survey Ontology
narrative: CGIAR and partners produce a great amount of household surveys and community-agreed set of well defined and semantically organized concepts was missing to annotate data. SEONT, socio-economic ontology developed by IFPRI, CIMMYT and Alliance, integrates the core set of 'must have' 100 questions  based on RhoMIS.  The objective is to support the design of survey forms, so collected data are properly described according to the interoperable principle of FAIR data for storage in databases.

title: Dry inoculum (active ingredient in Aflasafe): reduces manufacturing costs for Aflasafe and addresses barrier to commercialization
narrative: IITA researchers developed a process to dry out large quantities of spores by vacuuming the liquid inoculum through a special membrane and drying it in an oven. The dry inoculum is not heavy or fragile like the liquid version, making it last longer and easier to transport. From Ibadan, IITA can send enough for a whole season’s Aflasafe production to factories anywhere in Africa using an ordinary courier service, after obtaining appropriate phytosanitary certificates.

title: Gap analysis of crop modeling activities within CGIAR and a community of practice (CoP) of 1,000 external members, with specific guidance on improved modeling practices.
narrative: The CGIAR Community of Practice led a gap analysis to determine strengths, weaknesses/gaps, opportunities, and threats of CGIAR and partners' modeling capacity, skills and expertise. The study is to determined how modeling can support other research and outreach activities within CGIAR centers, to identified best practices in terms of modeling tools and methods, opportunities and needs in terms of funding, infrastructural support and access to databases, and finally collaboration opportunities across 1,000 CoP members.

title: Approach to encourage market actors to invest in food safety by stimulating consumer demand for safer maize flour in Kenya
narrative: A randomized marketing campaign, including advertising and promotional discounts, for a mass-market, aflatoxin-tested labelled brand of maize flour sold primarily in shops in rural counties in Central and Eastern Kenya was co-developed with A4NH researchers and a private sector partner. Innovation was tested to assess how consumers respond to information about food safety, specifically its impacts on sales over the long-term.

title: Picture-Based Insurance tools for improved risk management for the poor
narrative:
Farmers register each site to be insured through an initial picture
taken via a smartphone App. They take follow-up pictures to trigger personalized advisories, monitor
crop health, and document losses. When assessing claims, experts evaluate the damage using the
pictures. The pictures are geotagged and time-stamped, and the App has built-in features to prevent
tampering with pictures. As more training data become available, machine learning is used to build
automated image-processing algorithms.

title: Underutilised food species database with nutrition data, common and local names, medicinal uses and links to recipes
narrative: The database currently displays information for 185 prioritized underutilised food species. Entries include nutrition data, common and local names, medicinal uses and links to recipes, when available. Additional nutrition information is available for some species at the variety level. This database fills a gap in global food composition information. Global databases and food composition tables tend not to include nutritional values of orphan crops nor traditional knowledge associated with their collection, preparation and use.

title: Participatory community-based farm diversification and nutrition education approach to increase farm, market and dietary diversity in Kenya
narrative: Approach applies community participation in a way that allows researchers to understand the communities' context, and allows the communities to gain ownership from the outset and decide autonomously how to create changes in their environment. Research was conducted in Vihiga County in Western Kenya on how effective an integrated, participatory approach can be on improving farm, market, and dietary diversity. Approach can be integrated in agroecological transitions plan and related policy adaptations.

title: Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) regional action plan for rice self-sufficiency by 2025
narrative: Currently, the ECOWAS region depends on imports from Asia to fulfill about half of its consumption need. ECOWAS initiated a regional offensive to reach rice self-sufficiency by 2025. The Regional Offensive for sustainable and sustained recovery of rice production in West Africa Programme was approved by the ECOWAS Council of Ministers in June 2014. This Offensive aims to reduce imports to zero by 2025. AfricaRice contributes to ECOWAS - see also the related RICE policy.

title: Access of youth agripreneurs to agricultural finance for entrepreneurship and self-employment in Mali and Senega
narrative: In Africa, rural youth unemployment is the main cause of rural exodus and emigration. The innovation aims to bolster the rural youth potential through capacity building and entrepreneurship and to link them to the agricultural banks to have access to credit. Innovative business plans were developed covering the activities in the rice value chain and presented to the banks for cofinancing.  The models could encourage policymakers to develop special funds dedicated to youth.

title: Multi-actor platform design guide for improved natural resource governance at landscape level
narrative: This guide enables field practitioners and local government staff to undertake context-appropriate design and implementation of multiactor platforms, in three stages: (1) assessment of the governance context and selection from a menu of institutional design options; (2) implementation and strengthening of the platform through sustained and inclusive dialogue and action planning; (3) monitoring progress, assessing challenges, learning and adapting.

title: Vegan Community Ecology Package
narrative: The vegan package provides tools for descriptive community ecology. It has most basic functions of diversity analysis, community ordination and dissimilarity analysis. Most of its multivariate tools can be used for other data types as well.

title: New BiodiversityR package for Community Ecology and Suitability Analysis
narrative: Graphical User Interface and utility functions for statistical analysis of biodiversity and ecological communities, including species accumulation curves, diversity indices, Renyi profiles, GLMs for analysis of species abundance and presence-absence, distance matrices, Mantel tests, and cluster, constrained and unconstrained ordination analysis, methods for (ensemble) suitability modelling and mapping.
evidence_link: Kindt, Roeland, 2020. BiodiversityR: Package for Community Ecology and Suitability Analysis. Version 2.12-1. URL https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=BiodiversityR

title: Landscape Analysis of Financial Flows (LAFF): An inclusive methodology to analyze investment flows in a landscape
narrative: Methodology developed to explore existing financial flows in a landscape and their perceived impacts on previously defined landscape objectives. The methodology helps to define flows relevant to achieving objectives and worthwhile for in-depth studies on how to improve/scale up their impacts.

title: "Three-legged stool" approach, a combined intervention to improve food safety in informal or traditional markets
narrative: The three aspects of the approach include (1) training and technologies, which include training, awareness raising and simple technologies; (2) the enabling environment, meaning that regulatory authorities have to be on board with the intervention and there has to be some mechanism for institutionalization and a means of quality assurance; and (3) motivation and incentives, which are essential but very context specific. Each reporting year, innovation moves across stages of innovation in different value chains/countries.

title: WorldFlora: R package to standardize Plant Names According to World Flora Online Taxonomic Backbone.
narrative: Standardization of plant names is a critical step in various fields of biology including biodiversity, biogeography and vegetation research. WorldFlora matches lists of plant names with a static copy from World Flora Online (WFO), an ongoing global effort of completing an online flora of all known vascular plants and bryophytes.
evidence_link: Kindt, R. 2020. WorldFlora: An R package for exact and fuzzy matching of plant names against the World Flora Online taxonomic backbone data. Applications in Plant Sciences 8(9): e11388. doi:10.1002/aps3.11388. Kindt, Roeland, 2020. RcmdrPlugin.WorldFlora: R Commander Plug-in for the 'WorldFlora' Package. The Comprehensive R Archive Network. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=RcmdrPlugin.WorldFlora Kindt, Roeland, 2020. WorldFlora: Standardize Plant Names According to World Flora Online Taxonomic Backbone. Version 1.6. The Comprehensive R Archive Network. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=WorldFlora. [Versions 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 also published 2020]. Kindt, Roeland; Jens-Peter B. Lillesø, Fabio Pedercini, 2020. WorldFlora: User Guide for Graphical User Interface. ICRAF. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/342657019_WORLDFLORA_User_Guide_for_Graphical_User_Interface. 19 pp.

title: Sweetpotato silage-based diet for animal feeding in Uganda
narrative: Sweetpotato silage making, marketing and use for animal feeding has proven to be technically and economically viable. Initially tested for pig production, the latest experiences shown that is also suitable for dairy feeding

title: Low-cost and energy-efficient small-scale flash dryer for cassava
narrative: Drying of cassava starch and flour is essential to ensure longer shelf life. Low-cost and energy-efficient pneumatic flash dryers represent a viable alternative to sun-drying for small processing units.

title: Farmer Business school (FBS) to generate inclusive value chains for the pro-poor agri-enterprise development in Asia
narrative: Farmer Business school is a participatory action learning approach to support farmer groups’ participation to and benefit from agricultural value chains guided by a market-chain curricular framework, through a series of learning activities over a production-marketing cycle, including interaction with other chain actors and stakeholders. It is a modular/ step-wise platform for developing or upgrading value chains especially fit for small farmer-entrepreneurs.

title: Multi-stakeholder framework for intervening in RTB seed systems
narrative: The tool is designed to better understand RTB seed systems or to improve seed system interventions (e.g., projects or programs). It helps in identifying key stakeholders and in assessing availability, access, and quality of seed as well as in identifying bottlenecks and in designing key actions for the upcoming intervention.

title: Tumaini: an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-powered banana diseases and pest detection App
narrative: Tumaini is an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-powered banana disease detection mobile application. The app can be used to diagnose 5 banana diseases (Banana Xanthomonas Wilt (BXW), Banana Bunchy Top Disease (BBTD), Fusarium wilt, Black Leaf Streak and Yellow Sigatoka) and one pest (weevil).

title: Scaling Readiness: a stepwise process to generate evidence for more effective scaling of innovation
narrative: The scaling readiness offers a toolkit to support the design, implementation, and monitoring of scaling strategies at the portfolio and project level. The aim is to improve the efficiency and impact of research for development programs through critical reflection on how ready innovations are for scaling and what appropriate actions could accelerate or enhance scaling

title: Loop-mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP) assay protocol for field detection of Ralstonia solanacearum spp
narrative: Seed potato certification standards have zero tolerance for bacterial wilt (caused by Ralstonia  solanacearum) leading to rejection of entire potato seed fields. Current seed potato certification process involves costly and time consuming  diagnosis protocols.  This molecular method is a validated cost-effective LAMP assay for the detection of Ralstonia from potato stem, leaf, tuber and soil also in the field.

title: Two new white yam and three new water yam varieties for Nigeria with strong yield stability and high tuber yields and improved cooking and nutritional qualities
narrative: These five newly released varieties were passed through many evaluation stages including the early clonal stages, preliminary performance trials, advanced performance trials, coordinated national performance trials. The criteria used for advancing these varieties in breeding stages were plant vigor, pest and disease resistance, tuber shape and appearance, tuber flesh color, non-oxidization & eating quality. Both released varieties had high and stable fresh tuber yield, expressed superior boiled & pounded yam quality compared to standard varieties

title: Banana Musa balbisiana high quality B-genome sequence for evolution, genetic diversity and functional divergence of subgenomes of banana in China
narrative: The majority of edible cultivated bananas originated from intraspecific or interspecific hybridization between wild diploid M. acuminata (A-genome) and M. balbisiana (B-genome) species. A high-quality B-genome sequence is required for germplasm characterization and molecular breeding of banana. This high quality sequence has been completed and used to analyze evolution, genetic diversity and functional divergence of subgenomes of banana, providing insights into the evolution and regulation of fruit ripening processes.

title: Pestdisplace: platform to integrate and collectively monitor the occurrence and movement of pests and diseases in Roots, Tubers, Bananas and other crops
narrative: Pestdisplace uses novel visualization tools to share, track and communicate the distribution of crop pests and diseases over time and space (longituinal & spatial). A great part of this data was passive (stored in old reports and lab-books) and could not be used for decision making. By facilitating data collation from research and official sources the platforms is intended to accelerate decision making by stakeholders thus reducing risk and/or the impact of pests and diseases on crop yield.

title: Herbicides Calculator App to Help Farmers Control Weeds in Cassava production in Nigeria
narrative: Mobile app developed by the IITA-led Cassava Weed Management Project (CWMP) to forestall incidents of under-dosing or overdosing of herbicides. It will help resource-poor farmers to maximize the use of their inputs by allowing them to determine correctly the quantity of herbicide needed to add to a knapsack for a given spraying operation.

title: Women’s Empowerment in Fisheries Index (WEFI), a methodological tool for assessing women’s transformative change in fisheries and aquaculture
narrative: A methods package (tool) for assessing women’s empowerment and transformative change in fisheries and aquaculture. The tool draws from the Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index, but has adapted it in key ways: i) for fisheries and aquaculture; ii) for use as a before and after measure; iii) to include both qualitative and quantitative measures; iv) to include measures of gender transformative change, i.e., change in local structural gender barriers, in particular gender norms and attitudes.

title: Social, political, environmental and technical adjustments for viability of rice-fish systems in Myanmar
narrative: Integrating agriculture–rice fish, in areas where rice mono-cropping was the only form of agriculture allowed, improves production and sustains livelihoods. Trials demonstrate productivity gains - 13% conversion of rice land to fish refuge sustains/enhances rice production, reduces inputs, increases fish biodiversity, and doubles income per land area through sale of fish. Test plots and early outcomes enabling research progression to compare land use scenarios and deeper challenges of the innovation at scale.

title: Methodological innovation for ‘Illuminating Hidden Harvest’ of small-scale fisheries
narrative: An innovative methodology was developed to assess the social, environmental, economic and governance contribution and impacts of small-scale fisheries (SSF) to sustainable development at local, national and global scales. The novel method includes a country-level case study approach linking diverse traditional- and non-traditional data sources, and analyses of employment, nutrition, gender, governance and productivity across the 52 country cases for which data were collected in 2019.

title: Land-use modelling, scenarios and decision-support tools to optimize integrated fish-agri food systems for Myanmar
narrative: Digital tools for tailoring and targeting rice fish investments developed. Outputs include refined suitability maps (v1.5 June and V2 December 2020) incorporating available social and economic data at the township level for all 26 townships in the Ayeyarwady region and climate predictions to 2040 utilising WorldClim data layers. A technical report and a set of guidelines for database design and formatting, R coding language and use of QGIS and comprehensive database for the AD.

title: Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) introduction in Odisha State (India).
narrative: Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) strain of tilapia was introduced for the first time in Odisha State in India. The production and management system were defined and set up for starting GIFT production on a larger scale in Odisha State.

title: Gender Transformative Approaches in fish agri-food systems
narrative: An approach to engaging with gender within development that goes beyond ‘business-as-usual’ gender approaches in that it explicitly addresses, rather than accommodates, underlying gender barriers that perpetuate inequalities. Emerging findings indicate that the transformative approaches may contribute to more potent gender outcomes. GTA approach increased women’s participation in fishing (from 5% to 75%) and increased women’s contributions to intra-household decisions about the income generated from processing fish (49%).

title: Digital tool for on-farm performance assessment of aquaculture systems
narrative: A digital tool for on-farm performance assessment of aquaculture systems has been developed and made available for use in FISH CRP focal and scaling countries and by other stakeholders such as public and private sector. This benefits consistency, comparability and effectiveness of research and data delivered around on-farm performance of aquaculture systems.

title: Database of the nutrient composition of locally available ingredients for low-cost fish feed formulation in Africa and Asia
narrative: This database presents the nutrient composition of selected locally available ingredients, which can be used by feed manufacturers to formulate low-cost, sustainable aquafeeds in Africa and Asia. The database will be expanded to include information on the digestibility of macro and micro-nutrients for accurate feed formulation.

title: Contextualized better management practices (BMPs) for smallholders farming tilapia (GIFT) in pond-based systems in Zambia
narrative: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for small-holder farming tilapia (GIFT) in pond-based systems in Zambia were developed based on learning from farmers’ field schools (FFSs) and demonstration ponds, including empirical evidences from elsewhere. A BMPs manual was published to provide guidelines for sustainable intensification of tilapia production systems in Zambia and to serve as a handbook for aquaculture technicians/practitioners from different stakeholders such as I/NGOs and private sectors.

title: Big data technology and system (PeskAAS) to improve small-scale fisheries management in Timor Leste
narrative: A digital catch documentation system combined with tamper proof, solar powered trackers (developed by the partner Pelagic Data Systems) provided near-real time small-scale fisheries production and effort information to government fisheries managers on a decision dashboard using open-source software.

title: Rapid pathogen sequencing (Rappseq): a cloud platform for identifying aquaculture bacterial pathogens from long-read DNA sequence data
narrative: The Nanopore MinION DNA sequencer offers a cost-effective solution for identifying bacterial pathogens in real time. However, the data it produces is inherently noisy, making accurate pathogen typing a challenge. This new developed cloud platform employs a learning and classification approach to accurately and rapidly identify bacterial pathogens to serotype and sequence type (ST) level. This tool will enable farmers to make timely and effective decisions around treatment and vaccination when pathogen outbreaks occur.

title: A novel mixed-method approach to climate change vulnerability assessments for fish production systems in Myanmar
narrative: A methodological innovation built upon the IPCC 2014 risk assessment - adjusted for application in integrated fish production systems. Adaptations to the method include broader analysis of exposure to compounding risks (i.e., climate change+) and use of consultative processes and perception data.  The new methodology suits the hazard and vulnerability profile of Myanmar's fish production systems (i.e., aquaculture, inland fisheries and fish in agri-food systems).

title: Bio-control agents of pests and diseases in Benin and Burkina Faso
narrative: These biocontrol agents which are now ready for scaling out in West Africa uses Therophilus javanus, and has long field viability as evidenced in collected parasitized Maruca vitrata caterpillars in cowpea pods in experiments in Benin and Burkina Faso. Result is pest pod-borer populations have been consistently low, with an average of 86.3% reduction with the use of this biocontrol agent.

title: Plant growth promoting microorganisms (PGP) for sweet sorghum for India
narrative: Sweet sorghum bagasse compost prepared with microbes successfully promoted plant growth and significantly enhanced yields in sweet sorghum. Also, five strains of Streptomyces and another 5 strains of Bacillus were evaluated as bio-control agents against Fusarium wilt and PGP agents in chickpea. Under both greenhouse and wilt sick field conditions, the selected Streptomyces and Bacillus isolates reduced disease incidence and delayed expression of symptoms of disease, over the non-inoculated

title: Eight guide steps for setting up a Climate-Smart Village: A trainer's guide for Southeast Asian countries
narrative: The training manual presents a step-by-step process of establishing a CSV, with each step being complemented with learning objectives, session guides, and educational support materials. Additional links were provided for each step to promote further learning. Different forms of visuals such as photos, maps, and graphs make the publication easy to read and understand. This is almost a one-stop-shop for implementers to acquire the information, capacity, and other prerequisites necessary for establishing a CSV.

title: Toolbox for tools, guidelines, and templates for monitoring, reporting, and verification of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) calculation in rice in Vietnam
narrative: An Monitoring Reporting and Verification (MRV) toolbox has been built consisting of tools, guidelines, and templates to advance the work of monitoring, reporting, and verification of Greenhouse Gas (GHG) calculation along the rice value chain, that can be applied by both the public and the private sectors in Vietnam.

title: Digital tool for mapping suitable areas for Alternate Wetting and Drying (AWD) adoption for Vietnam
narrative: Mapping suitability of the Alternate Wetting and Drying practice for rice production (MapAWD) is a Microsoft® Excel-based tool developed to evaluate bio-physical suitability of the AWD water saving technique.

title: Manual of Operations for the Schools-on-the-Air on Smart Rice Agriculture in the Philippines
narrative: This manual serves as a guide in conducting the School-on-the- Air on Modern Rice Agriculture program. It has six chapters: (1) Context, (2) Introduction, (3) Implementation scheme, (4) Organizing and conducting the SOA, (5) Logistical requirements, and (6) Reporting procedures. Also included are the various activities from the pre-broadcast to the post-broadcast phase, roles and responsibilities of partners involved in the program, references on modern, climate-smart rice agriculture and a sample SOA curriculum.

title: Solar bubble dryer for mushroom drying
narrative: An inflatable solar dryer for mushroom drying was developed by IRRI in collaboration with GrainPro Inc. This dryer was adapted from the Solar Bubble Dryer(TM) originally designed for paddy drying. The improved dryer with a perforated elevated floor added ensured a premium quality dried mushroom product without any requirement of mixing or turning the mushroom during drying.

title: Flood tolerant variety IR13F265 (NSIC Rc 590) for the Philippines
narrative: This variety was released for cultivation in flood-prone areas of the Philippines. The variety possesses tolerance to Submergence (up to 15 days) and moderate tolerance to stagnant flooding as well.

title: Smarter metrics in climate change and agriculture Business guidance for target-setting across productivity, resilience and mitigation.
narrative: This corporate guide was collaboratively developped as part of WBCSD ‘Smarter Metrics’ workstream. It acts as an essential repository for companies who are embarking on addressing Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA), providing both an overview of industry trends, and practical guidance to help businesses start the journey of setting and disclosing targets.

title: The Climate-Smart Village approach nominates to the GCIAR's 50 greatest innovations
narrative: The Climate-Smart Village AR4D (CSVs) approach is an innovative and holistic “model” founded on the principles of participatory action research, with context-specific theory of change, implementation processes and scaling up mechanisms geared towards fostering wide adoption of technical and institutional options to address the effects of climate change in agriculture. Building on multi-stakeholder partnerships with research, extension, NGOs, public and private sectors, it has being implemented with farming communities across more than 20 countries.

title: Salinity management in the delta of Senegal River Valley minimizing damage on rice growth and yield
narrative: Agronomic management of salt-affected soil which includes the application of different nutrient sources and salt-tolerant rice varieties

title: Auto-CCAFS-MOT: a batch calculator tool for farmers greenhouse gas emissions (GHG)
narrative: The main purpose of this repository is to offer a tool that can estimate GHG emissions for multiple crop-events.This tool estimates GHG emissions, likewise offers mitigation alternatives. Our scope was to automatize this tool, giving the option of addressing multiple crop events in a faster way.

title: Heat stress maps for pigs in Uganda
narrative: Pig heat stress maps for Uganda: These maps are based on spatial analysis of historical and projected climate data and highlight hotspot areas in Uganda where heat stress could significantly affect pig production.

title: Let it Rain Game linked to iShamba service to provide weekly agri-tips
narrative: The game itself is a simple USSD survey, that you can play on a regular feature phone, or using a smartphone. The game promotes farmers to share information about the farming activities, as well as experience with weather extremes, in order to qualify for another guess. Once the user finishes playing, he/she is signed up to iShamba, the farmer mobile service, and receives weekly agri-tips, for crops and livestock, market prices and weather information.

title: Rappseq: a cloud platform for identifying bacterial pathogens from long-read DNA sequence data
narrative: The Nanopore MinION DNA sequencer offers a cost-effective solution for identifying bacterial pathogens in real time. However, the data it produces is inherently noisy, making accurate pathogen typing a challenge. Our cloud platform employes a learning and classification approach to accurately and rapidly identify bacterial pathogens to serotype and sequence type (ST) level. This tool will enable farmers to make timely and effective decisions around treatment and vaccination when pathogen outbreaks occur.

title: Perennial rice varieties for irrigated rice system in the Sahel
narrative: Perennial rice varieties are varieties that have a strong ratooning ability and are capable of regrowing season after season without reseeding. Ratoon rice cropping has the potential to increase annual rice production per unit land area and saving labor, time, seeds, and water.

title: Consideration of remote sensing to facilitate minimum data set collection for Crop Simulation Modeling
narrative: Crop Modeling Community of Practice members at Purdue University and CIMMYT recently launched a project for investigating the use of remotely sensed data to substitute for destructively measured traits that are prerequisites for driving crop models. We expect to demonstrate the value of remote sensed data as alternative or complementary inputs for crop models, thereby increasing precision of simulations, and potentially making more field research data sets amenable to simulation exercises.

title: Target Population of Environment (TPE) modelling as a synergy between Big Data Platform (BDP) and Excellence in Breeding (EiB) platforms
narrative: Incorporation of a crop modeling tool into the CGIAR’s Enterprise Breeding System, supported by the EiB and Crop Modeling Community of Practice. This tool can help classify environments based on crop physiological and morphological responses to climate and soil drivers, help identify factors responsible for yield reductions in order to assist breeders in the trait selection for a given environment with the ultimate goal of delivering better varieties that meet farmer’s needs in a shorter period of time.

title: A rapid approach for informing the prioritization of degraded agricultural lands for ecological recovery: A case study for Colombia
narrative: This approach allows to identifying and prioritizing degraded agricultural lands for low-cost ecological recovery. Using publicly available remote sensing datasets at the national level, the proposed methodology was applied to Colombia, where we identify opportunities for cost-effective interventions on productive lands with moderate to light degradation, based on biophysical indicators of soil degradation.

title: Libertad FL: A new rice variety for Venezuela
narrative: This is a rice variety derived from the CIAT/FLAR cross CT9162-12-6-2-2-1/PANAMA1048//FL00595-19P-8-1P-M-M. This variety has a potential (under experimental trails) of 9,000 Kg/ha. It is resistant to Rice Blast (Magnaporthe grisea), Helminthosporium, Grain discoloration, and other pest. This is an innovation delivered in partnership with INIA (NAR institute in Venezuela)

title: The Agro-Chain Greenhouse Gas Emissions (ACGE) calculator for estimating total GHG emissions associated to a food product
narrative: The Agro-Chain Greenhouse Gas Emissions (ACGE) calculator is a tool for estimating total greenhouse gas emissions associated with a food product. It addresses the most common stages of "linear" agro-food chains (chains for fresh and simple processed products: canned, frozen, packaged, and other minimally processed forms). It combines a calculation framework with datasets containing crops, greenhouse gas emission factors, and food loss factors along the chain.

title: Integrated system to produce updated-estimates of the cost of adaptation to climate change in agriculture
narrative: Decision-makers are increasingly concerned about the impacts of climate change on agriculture and the need to invest in adaptation. Estimates of adaptation costs exist but are now dated. This innovation created and used an integrated system of updated climate, water, crop and economic models to assess new estimates of the costs of key agricultural investment to support adaptation. Results shared with the gates foundation and the global commission on adaptation through a publication.

title: GARDIAN Labs, an open-access service to enable researchers to collaborate and share data and analytic approaches and tools
narrative: This open-access service enables CGIAR researchers to collaborate and share data and analytic approaches and tools.

title: agCelerant: world's first fully automated processing system providing concurrent detection of field-level agricultural events, monitoring of crop response, and production forecasts from combined field mobile, IoT and EO data streams
narrative: By interfacing a state of the art technology to discover, collect and organize big data sets, the Geospatial Exploitation Platform (GEP), with agCelerant, a phygital smallholder value chain orchestration platform, we built the world's first fully automated processing system providing concurrent detection of smallholder plot-level agricultural events, monitoring of crop response, and production forecasts based on combined field and EO data streams, which are both essential for operational exploitation and scalability in heterogeneous smallholder agriculture.

title: Potato AI model able to detect potato late and early blight
narrative: Potato AI model to detect early and late blight was added to the PlantVillage Nuru app and is now available for Android and iOS operating systems. The innovation aims to help farmers diagnose crop disease in the field, without an internet connection.

title: Quick appraisal monitoring and evaluation tool for the  Local Technical Agroclimatic Committees (LTACs) in Latin America (LAM)
narrative: We developed a Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) instrument for the LTACs with the support of the M&E teams of CIAT-CCAFS and IRI, and WFP. The M&E tool helps us understand the agricultural and biophysical context of each territory of influence of the LTACs, the perception of the quality of the meteorological information that is shared (eg seasonal forecast), and an estimation of the scope of the agroclimatic bulletins and the dissemination media effectivity.

title: AgroclimR: an Agro-Climate Seasonal Forecast tool for Central America
narrative: AgroClimR is a tool developed in R programming code for crop simulations with Aquacrop based on climate information. The tool helps agricultural stakeholders to translate the climate information (i.e. historical data and forecast) into predicted crop yields and turn these into agronomic recommendations. The tool is being adopted at the level of ministries of agriculture linked to the regional agricultural discussion group (RADG) of the CA-COF.

title: A method to predict women's empowerment using call detail records in Uganda
narrative: This study uses two sources of data: a phone-based survey with MTN Uganda (one of the largest mobile service providers in the country) subscribers and de-identified call detail records of the MTN subscribers who participated in the phone survey. The call detail records were used to train machine-learning classifiers to predict indicators of women's empowerment collected from the survey.

title: Agricultural information videos to increase women's empowerment in agriculture in Uganda
narrative: Agricultural information videos designed to increase women's empowerment in agriculture were tested, focusing on two design features: targeting of information (who watches the videos in the participating households: the male co-head, the female co-head or both co-heads together) and the use of role models (who is featured in the video: a man, a woman or a couple). Recommendations were made on how to design video-based agricultural information campaigns to increase women's empowerment.

title: Updated Tropical Forages Selection Tool
narrative: Based on expert knowledge systematization, the Tropical Forages Selection Tool helps researchers, advisors, development specialists and farmers to make informed choices of species and genotypes for particular environments and farming systems. The tool was developed to capture the expertise of experienced, often retired, global forage specialists and present it in a structured way to guide a new generation of implementers.

title: New forage variety Avena sativa AV25T, “Altoandina” to improve the efficiency of dairy farming systems in the Colombian high tropics
narrative: New forage variety (Avena sativa AV25T, “Altoandina”) released by NARS partner in collaboration with CIAT (Colombian Forages Network)

title: Protocol for in-vitro introduction and multiplication of Urochloa
narrative: The protocol finds the best photoperiod and light wavelength range treatments to induce flowering in Brachiaria humidicola. This is a significant and pioneering advance in the standardization of in-vitro propagation methods for Urochloa.

title: Digital imaging as scoring method for spittlebug tolerance in Urochloa humidicola hybrids
narrative: American spittlebug complex (Hemiptera: Cercopidae) is a critical pest for Urochloa humidicola. Visual scoring of plant damage by spittlebugs, the standard method to screen for variation in plant tolerance, is slow, prone to human bias, and reliant on trained personnel. Damage estimated from digital images was twice as fast as expert visual scoring and gave heritability values for plant damage as good as, or better than, those obtained by expert visual scoring.

title: Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) - Rwanda
narrative: An integrated set of recommended crop, soil, water and weed management practices that were proven to improve rice productivity and increase profitability.

title: Proximal sensing of Urochloa grasses to increase selection accuracy
narrative: Digital colour image and spectral analysis techniques that improve precision and reduce time for tropical forage grass phenotyping.

title: Root length as proxy for high-throughput screening of waterlogging tolerance in Urochloa spp. grasses
narrative: A study showed that total root length of Urochloa spp. had the strongest positive influence on shoot dry mass and can therefore be used as proxy for selecting waterlogging tolerant genotypes.

title: First record of the presence of the spittlebug Aeneolamia reducta (Lallemand, 1924) (Hemiptera: Cercopidae) in Valle del Cauca (Colombia)
narrative: As part of the spittlebugs complex (Hemiptera: Cercopidae) the species of the genus Aeneolamia can considerably affect grass crops by extracting sap from the xylem. With the objective of corroborating previous observations, a spittlebug sampling was carried out in the vicinity of Santiago de Cali city and the collected specimens (Cercopidae) subjected to a taxonomic identification process. As a result, the first report of A. reducta in Valle del Cauca was presented.

title: Biological Nitrification Inhibition (BNI): Phenotyping of a core germplasm collection of the tropical forage grass Megathyrsus maximus under greenhouse conditions
narrative: Intensively managed pastures receiving large external nitrogen (N) inputs account for high N losses through nitrate leaching and emissions of nitrous oxide (N2O). Natural plant capacity to shape the soil N cycle through exudation of organic compounds can be exploited to favour N retention without affecting productivity. Evaluation of the relationship between biological nitrification inhibition (BNI), N2O emissions and plant productivity for 119 germplasm accessions of Guineagrass (Megathyrsus maximus) found 30-70% reductions in nitrification activity.

title: A new genome allowing the identification of genes associated with natural variation in aluminium tolerance in Urochloa grasses
narrative: Toxic concentrations of aluminium cations (AL3+) and low phosphorus availability are the main yield-limiting factors in acidic soils, which represent half of the potentially available arable land. Brachiaria grasses show greater tolerance to high concentrations of Al3+ than most other grass crops. Research exploring the natural variation in Al3+ tolerance between Brachiaria species identified three quantitative trait loci (QTLs) associated with root vigour during Al3+ stress and 30 genes putatively responsible for Al3+ tolerance.

title: Population of advanced interspecific hybrids of Urochloa Br12 released to private sector partner for seed production viability study and further registration and dissemination
narrative: Population of advanced interspecific hybrids of Urochloa Br12 and all characterization information associated to it (biotic and abiotic resistance for each hybrid, as well as forage quality and biomass multilocational performance), released to private sector partner for seed production viability study and further registration and dissemination.

title: Population of advanced interspecific hybrids of Urochloa Br15 released to private sector partner for seed production viability study and further registration and dissemination
narrative: Population of advanced interspecific hybrids of Urochloa Br15 (forage hybrids with high nutritional value and resistance to different types of environmental stresses resulting in more productive pasture) released to private sector partner for seed production viability study and further registration and dissemination. Package with all supporting characterization information is being completed and pending to be released.

title: Population of advanced interspecific hybrids of Urochloa Bh16 released to private sector partner for seed production viability study and further registration and dissemination
narrative: First ever population of advanced hybrids of Urochloa humidicola, Bh16 (forage hybrids with high nutritional value and resistance to different types of environmental stresses resulting in more productive pasture) released to private sector partner for seed production viability study and further registration and dissemination. Package with all supporting characterization information is being completed and pending to be released.

title: Near infrared reflectance spectroscopy as a low-cost method for analysis of the nutritional quality of Urochloa humidicola in breeding selections
narrative: Brachiaria humidicola (BH) (syn. Urochloa humidicola) is an important tropical forage grass due to its capacity to grow in nutrient-deficient soils, tolerate waterlogging, and inhibit soil nitrification. Since a major objective of BH breeding is to improve its nutritional quality, a rapid and low-cost method is needed to assess parameters such as neutral detergent fibre, acid detergent fibre, in vitro dry matter digestibility, and crude protein, and models were developed using near infrared reflectance spectroscopy.

title: Kenya (national scale), in-season crop modeling for monitoring food security shocks
narrative: Leveraging farm data and modeling expertise from multiple partners, and the computational power of Google X, the partners were able to detect onset of maize crops at a national scale in Kenya, enabling estimation of total planted area in-season, and prediction of total national maize production.

title: Experimental methods for measuring individual decision-making power within households in Ghana and Uganda
narrative: These experimental methods  to measure individual decision-making power within households include: (1) a game that measures willingness to pay to control resources, and (2) dictator games that measure preferences for resource allocation and the extent to which those preferences are reflected in joint decisions. After comparing results between the two methods and with standard survey measures of empowerment and resource control, the games are found to provide effective measurements in the right context.

title: New barley variety "Ay" released by National Agricultural Research Systems (NARS) in Turkey
narrative: High yielding and disease resistant six-row feed barley variety ideal for high input conditions released in Turkey by NARS.

title: 4 new dual-purpose barley elite genotypes shared with the Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique (INRA) in Morocco for validation and potential release
narrative: 4 new dual-purpose barley elite genotypes were shared with INRA Morocco to be planted in the 2020/21 season for validation and potential release. Dual-purpose meaning that they can be used for green forage (grazing) and exhibit good recovery that provides high yield for grain and straw at maturity for feed.

title: 5 new elite feed barley genotypes shared with Lebanese Agricultural Research Institute (LARI) to start the variety registration process
narrative: 5 new elite feed barley genotypes for biotic and abiotic stress and malting quality for different agro-ecologies were shared with LARI in Lebanon to start the variety registration process.

title: 198 new elite multi-purpose barley genotypes for food, feed, forage, and malt shared with Indian Institute of Wheat and Barley Research (IIWBR) for multi-location testing
narrative: 98 new elite multi-purpose barley genotypes for food, feed, forage, and malt were selected out of a total of 993. These were shared with IIWBR-Karnal for multi-location testing across India.

title: 321 new multi-purpose barley genotypes for food, feed, forage, and malt shared with National Agricultural Research Systems (NARS) partners and collaborators for final evaluation and potential release
narrative: 321 new multi-purpose barley genotypes were shared with NARS and collaborators in 23 countries for final evaluation and potential release. These can serve as food, feed, forage, and malt.

title: Forage seed business development for cooperatives in Tunisia using mobile seed cleaning and treatment units
narrative: A local manufacturer in collaboration with ICARDA and its national partners in Tunisia designed and developed a prototype of a “mobile seed cleaning and treatment unit” which has been locally manufactured at low cost. With the help of these mobile seed cleaning and treatment units, members of farmer cooperatives can significantly increase their seed quality and consequently their fodder production.

title: Use of locally available ingredients to produce small ruminant feed in pellet form in Tunisia
narrative: Using locally available material to produce pellets for feeding small ruminants

title: Predicting yields using biophysical crop simulations, machine learning and remote sensing in India
narrative: The accuracy of statistical crop models and insurance indices for yield estimation depends on the quality of the underlying input data used to run these models. In this context, a major challenge is the lack of accessible and reliable ground truth data. A scalable approach to bridge these gaps is to estimate statistical yield models from biophysical crop simulations using machine learning, and predict yields using these models using remote sensing and gridded weather data.

title: Barinesa FL: A new Rice variety for Venezuela
narrative: This a rice variety derived from the CIAT/FLAR cross FL001028-8P-3-2P-1P-M-2X-3P-1P/FL03188-7P-5-3P-3P-M-1P//FL04621-2P-1-2P-M-1P. It has a potential (under experimental trails) of 10,000 Kg/ha. It is resistant to Rice Blast (Magnaporthe grisea), Helminthosporium, Grain discoloration, and Tagosodes orizicolus Muir, the latter an endemic insect (planthopper) in tropical LAC. This is an innovation delivered in partnership with INIA (NAR institute in Venezuela)

title: Araureña FL: A new rice variety for Venezuela
narrative: This is a rice variety derived from the cross FL00596-54P-12-3P-M/CT9748-13-2-1-M-M-1-1//FL04577-3P-11-4P-2P-M. This is a variety valued by rice breeders for its earliness (less than 110 days from planting to harvesting) , with a yield potential, under experimental trials, of 7,500 Kg/ha. It is resistant to the main pest in Venezuela and, in addition, it has milling and cooking quality adapted to the Venezuelan market.

title: Guariqueña FL: A new rice variety for Venzuela
narrative: This is a rice variety derived from the cross FL01028-8P-3-2P-1P-M-2X-3P-1P/FL03188-7P-5-3P-3P-M-1P//FL02764-3P-3-4P-2P-M-1P-M-M-1P. This is a variety with very high yield potential (11,500 Kg/ha) under irrigated conditions under good crop management.  In addition, it has milling and cooking quality adapted to the Venezuelan market.

title: Nory FL: A new rice variety adapted to the western rice producing region of Venezuela
narrative: This variety was selected from the cross FL09203-7P-3-2P-M/FL10030-12P-9-2P-1P. Nory FL is well adapted to the western rice producing region of Venezuela, were the Rice Farmers Association (ASOPORTUGUESA) selected it aim at delivering seeds to more than 800 small-scale rice farmers. ASOPORTUGUESA is integrated in the rice value chain, so that they can go from the seeds to the commercial grain to distribute rice (as food) to more than 2,000,000 people in its area of influence.

title: Victoria FL: A rice variety with excellent cooking quality adapted to Ecuador
narrative: This is a rice variety derived from the cross (COMPACTA 1 /COLOMBIA XXI//FL03188-7P-5-4P-1P-M). A private company, AGRIPAC, selected it from a FLAR Nursery, highlighting its cooking and milling quality, and grain yield similar to current widely grown rice varieties in Ecuador. AGRIPAC commercializes seeds and other inputs to ag farmers in Ecuador.

title: CropGalaxy - a unified analysis platform for multiple crops
narrative:
In 2020 separate Galaxy servers RiceGalaxy, serving rice research community, and EiB Galaxy, developed by Excellence in Breeding Platform, were combined into a unified server called CropGalaxy, allowing researchers working on multiple crops to avail of the tools that were formerly in Rice- or EiB galaxy servers. 
In addition new tools for GWAS utilising fast and accurate genome-wide mixed model analysis were implemented in CropGalaxy.

title: Biofortified varieties Fedearroz BioZN-035 for Colombia
INIAP ELITE FL: New rice variety for Ecuador
narrative: In January 2020 INIAP FL ELITE was released by the National Institute of Agricultural Research (INIAP) in Ecuador. This variety  was selected from the cross FL10384-2P-4-2P-M /FL05679-7P-1-1P-3P-M-F7-1P//FL8419-8P-2-1P-1P-M. INIAP FL ELITE meets the demands of the industry and consumers, in terms of milling and culinary grain quality. This variety targets the market of consumers of the Ecuadorian Sierra, who prefer long grain and crystalline rice, with high amylose and good culinary quality

title: GRDB 16 FL: New rice variety for Guyana
narrative: The Ministry of Agriculture of Guyana launched the rice variety GRDB 16. This variety has the potential to produce nine tones per hectare, with premium grain quality that have been desired by rice farmers. It has the characteristics of a premium game-changing variety which maintained its greenness throughout the crop, did not lodge and can come through standing water of up to nine inches. GRDB 16 takes only 110 days to reach its maturity stage.

title: 5 new elite food-feed barley genotypes shared with India
narrative: 5 new elite food-feed barley genotypes shared with India

title: Promotion of cactus pear as a multipurpose crop to enhance the livelihood of poor farmers in dry areas of Northern Africa and Western Asia
narrative: Cactus pear is recommended for use across dry areas (particularly semi-arid regions). ICARDA has introduced cactus to the Gulf states, West Asia (Syria and Jordan), South Asia (Pakistan), Afghanistan, etc.

title: Ecological niche modeling approach for assessing potential for expansion of irrigated rice under alternate wetting and drying method in Burkina Faso
narrative: A two-step, spatially explicit approach that is based on i) machine learning models, namely Random Forest (RF) and Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt) deployed in ecological niche modeling to assess the land suitability for irrigated rice cultivation and ii) the climatic suitability for alternate wetting and drying (AWD), an irrigation management method for saving water in rice cultivation in irrigated systems using a simple water balance model. The approach was successfully validated in Burkina Faso.

title: New barley variety Guldeste released by National Agricultural Research Systems (NARS) in Turkey
narrative: High yielding and disease resistant six-row naked barley variety ideal for high input conditions released in Turkey by NARS

title: Climate Risk Profile Climate Risk Profiles for presenting key challenges posed by climate change and the impacts it might have on the agricultural sector
narrative: The Climate Risk Profiles provides a comprehensive overview of the farming systems, key value chains and the types of inputs used, presenting key challenges posed by climate change and the impacts it might have on the agricultural sector. These profiles then suggest specific interventions that could address those challenges and outline financing opportunities for Climate-smart agroiculture (CSA). To date, there are more than 70 climate risk profiles, with many more in the pipeline.

title: Nitrogen efficient rice breeding line
narrative: Nitrogen efficient breeding line developed through introgression of actpk1 gene into Sahel108 background
evidence_link: no link yet for discovery research

title: New knowledge on antibiotic resistance genes in Ethiopian indigenous chickens
narrative: Antibiotic resistance in poultry is increasingly becoming a human public-health issue for the poultry sector. Understanding the baseline backyard poultry antibiotic resistance status will allow veterinarians and government extension officers to guide livestock health interventions at the smallholder level. The research found that antibiotic resistant genes to cephalosporin, tetracycline and MLS antibiotics (macrolides, lincosamides and streptogramins) are significantly more abundant in indigenous chickens distributed in the lowlands than in the highlands of Ethiopia.

title: QTLs for anaerobic germination of rice
narrative: We explored a BC1F2:3 population developed from a cross between BJ1, an indica landrace, and NSIC Rc222, a high-yielding recurrent parent. The population was phenotyped under different screening methods (anaerobic screenhouse, anaerobic tray, and aerobic screenhouse) to establish the relationship among the methods and to identify the most suitable screening method, followed by bulk segregant analysis (BSA) to identify large-effect QTL

title: Development of high-quality new reference genomes for Asian rice
narrative:
We concluded the generation, validation and preliminary analyses of transposable element and long-range structural variation content of 12 near-gap-free reference genome sequences (RefSeqs) from representatives of 12 of 15 subpopulations of cultivated Asian rice. 

Zhou, Y., Chebotarov, D., Kudrna, D. et al. A platinum standard pan-genome resource that represents the population structure of Asian rice. Sci Data 7, 113 (2020). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41597-020-0438-2

title: New Variety: Arica 4 (F187) for Madagascar
narrative: A new variety for the MO of Madagascar (similar to Nerica 4 but more productive) developed by AfricaRice was assayed by Cirad and FOFIFA. The variety was evaluated in the DHS (Distinctiveness, Homogeneity and Stability trials) and approved by the institution responsible for the variety registration process. It is thus registered in the variety catalog
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: Guidance note for gender-inclusive agro-advisories in Vietnam
narrative: Findings from a baseline study in Southeast Asia suggest that climate services must be adjusted to better match farmers’ information needs. This guidance note aims to assist extension officers in developing weather forecast and weather forecast-based advice ("agro-advisories") that are gender-inclusive and useful for both men and women farmers, taking into account five indicators: availability, accessibility, timeliness, understandability, and usefulness of the information.

title: New variety: SCRID 091-38-4-3-4-1-1-5 (F188) for Madagascar
narrative: A new variety for the MO of Madagascar (well appreciated by framers, productivity, yield stability) developed by Cirad and FOFIFA.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: New Variety: SCRID 220-2-3-3-5-3-4 (F189) for Madagascar
narrative: A new variety for the HT of Madagascar (earlier than local check and well appreciated by farmers) developed by Cirad and FOFIFA.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: ASI thresher for reducing postharvest loss in rice production in Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: ASI is a throw-in type of motorized machine for rice threshing. The ASI is capable of processing 6 tons of rice per day using the equivalent of 6 manual labourers, while the traditional methods would require 36 manual labourers to thresh an equivalent output levelASI cleanly separates 99% of the grains, resulting in a better-quality product.

title: Perennial rice: improving input efficiency for sustainable rice landscape in C?te d?Ivoire
narrative: Perennial rice is a viable pathway towards sustainable food production systems. Deep-rooted perennial rice enhances soil structure and contributes to soil and water conservation, decreases drought vulnerability, and greatly reduces the need for tilling, weeding, and the use of external inputs as compared to annual crops. Perennial rice contributes to both climate adaptation and mitigation and increases biodiversity and ecosystem services.

title: High yielding rice variety SEBERI 1 for irrigated lowland rice production systems in Niger
narrative: A high yielding rice variety SEBERI 1 (WAB 2101-WAC4-1-TGR1-WAT B6) was released in Niger in 2020 after having been evaluated through the Africa-wide Rice Breeding Task Force network.

title: High yielding, aromatic variety SEBERI 4 for irrigated lowland rice production systems in Niger
narrative: A high yielding rice and  aromatic rice variety which was introduced through the Green Super Rice project was evaluated through the Africa-wide Breeding Task Force network and released in Niger in 2020 for irrigated lowland rice production systems as SEBERI 4.

title: High yielding rice variety SEBERI 2 for irrigated lowland rice production systems in Niger
narrative: A high yielding rice variety SEBERI 2 was released in Niger in 2020 for irrigated lowland production systems

title: High yielding rice variety SEBERI 3 for irrigated lowland rice production systems in Niger
narrative: SEBERI 3, a high yielding irrigated lowland rice variety was released in 2020 by Niger

title: Understanding G x E x M by global characterization of rice array panels
narrative: A better understanding of G x E x M is essential for the development of future climate smart rice varieties. Here we characterized global rice array panels across several locations globally, and successfully generated data sets, curated and carried out preliminary analysis. There results showed wider genotypic responses, effects of environments and management practices. The preliminary GWAS resulted in consistent loci for major agronomic traits

title: New hybrids that out-yielded the released hybrid AR051H by 20-47% identified for Senegal and Cote d'Ivoire
narrative: 22 new hybrids that out-yielded the released hybrid AR051H by 20-47% were identified in the 2020 dry season.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: 20 Elite upland breeding lines out-yielding NERICA 4 by up to 57% identified in Cote d'Ivoire.
narrative: 20 elite upland breeding lines out-yielding check variety NERICA 4 by 12-57% were identified in yield trials conducted at Mbe, Cote d'Ivoire.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: 30 Elite irrigated lowland breeding lines which out-yielded ISRIZ-07 and Sahel 108 by up to 47% identified in Senegal
narrative: In two Preliminary Yield Trials (PYT) conducted during the dry and wet seasons of 2020,  with 75 entries and 45 entries, respectively,  30 lines with yield advantages of up to 47% over check varieties ISRIZ-07 and Sahel 108 (8.8 t/ha) were identified at Ndiaye, Senegal.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: Technical books for extension service and farmers to improve fertility and pest management of upland cropping systems in Madagascar
narrative: Technical books for extension service and farmers to improve fertility and pest management of upland cropping systems.

title: Algorithm for measurement of rice leaf Eh-pH-EC
28 High yielding irrigated lowland breeding lines exceeding Sahel 108 and ISRIZ-07 by up to 36% identified in replicated yield trials in Senegal
narrative: 28 high yielding irrigated lowland breeding lines exceeding Sahel 108 and ISRIZ-07 by up to 36% were identified in replicated yield trials conducted at Ndiaye, Senegal during the dry and wet seasons of 2020.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: Sampling methods for assessing intra- and inter-genetic diversity in O. glaberrima, O. sativa and O. barthii compared
narrative: In 2016, the Rice Biodiversity Center for Africa (RBCA) genotyped 3,255 accessions with nearly 32,000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) using DArT-based genotyping by sequencing technology (DArTseq). In 2020, these data were used for comparing different sampling methods for assessing intra- and inter-genetic diversity in O. glaberrima, O. sativa and O. barthii

title: Revised mini-core collection of 350 O. glaberrima accessions that captured 97% of the SNP (single nucleotide polymorphisms) and most of the observed genetic variation, created
narrative: Using 3,834 polymorphic single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), the genetic variation and population structure of 2,179 Oryza glaberrima accessions was characterized and a mini-core collection created comprising 350 accessions that captured 97% of the SNP polymorphism. In 2020,  951 more accessions were genotyped , increasing the number  to 3,130, and the number of polymorphic markers to 9,990 SNPs. With the current dataset, the mini-core was revised and the revised list  captured 98.5% of the SNP polymorphisms

title: 61 Superior irrigated lowland breeding lines with yield advantages of up to 22% identified in observational yield trials
narrative: 1326 lines were evaluated in Observational yield trials in  2020 dry season and 61 lines superior to best checks Sahel 210 and Sahel 177 with 20 lines having yield advantage of 4-22% over best checks and good plant type
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: 21 NILs with introgression of 11 different blast resistance genes
narrative: 21 NILs with introgression of 11 different blast resistance genes developed in the IR64 background

title: Introgression lines for additional partial resistance genes for blast.
narrative: Introgression lines for additional partial resistance genes for blast developed.
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: 3 lowland breeding lines with Pup1 introgression and improved yield under low-input (P deficient) conditions for Madagascar
narrative: 3 lowland breeding lines with Pup1 introgression and improved yield under low-input (P deficient) conditions advanced to the final stage of the variety registration process in Madagascar; potentially 2 of them will be released as variety

title: 4 upland breeding lines with improved yield under low-input (P deficient) conditions in Madagascar
narrative: 4 upland breeding lines with improved yield under low-input (P deficient) conditions were identified through farmer-participatory selection on smallholder farms in Madagascar; ; potentially 2-3 of them will be released as variety

title: Genomic Selection model to predict grain Zn concentrations
narrative: Developed a Genomic Selection model to predict grain Zn concentrations among the 3K SNP-Seek set
evidence_link: none as yet for Discovery research

title: 7 Nutritious rice combining high Zn content and high yield identified in preliminary yield trialin Senegal
narrative: In a preliminary yield trial conducted at Ndiaye, Senegal in the dry season of 2020, under direct seeding or transplanting, 12 lines including 7 high Zn lines, were identified with yields superior to best checks (Sahel 210 and Sahel 134, respectively).

title: 14 superior irrigated lowland breeding lines identified in multi-location trials in Cote d'Ivoire, Nigeria and Senegal
narrative: Multi-location trials were conducted at 4 trial locations (Ndiaye & Fanaye in Senegal; Mbe in CIV and Ibadan in Nigeria) during the wet season of 2020 and 14 lines superior to checks at two or three out of locations, were identified. The entry ARS 4M-B-73-2 -1-1 –B was found to be superior to the best checks at 3 locations.

title: 3 surface root QTLs - qSFR2, qSFR5 and qSFR - confer salt tolerance when iintrogressed in IR64 background
narrative: Yield trials were conducted using 21 lines with introgressions of 3 root QTLs for surface rooting in background of IR64. Under saline conditions Sahel 108 and Sahel 134 had yields <1 tonne/ha. The triple pyramid of qSFR2, qSFR5, and qSFR7 gave the best yield under saline conditions with yield of  3.1 tonnes/ha. Under fresh water conditions it had a yield advantage of 32% over best check, Sahel 134 (5.7 tonnes/ha)
