narrative: Four diverse entries from the antenna panel of the global Rice Array (NSIC Rc240, Giza 178, IRGC 79837-1, and UPL RI 7) were found to have consistent, high yield at M'be, Cote d'Ivoire. From the reference panel consisting of MAGIC Indica lines, four lines (19, 62, 296, and 326) were identified with consistently high yield and favorable yield components at both M'be and Ndiaye, Senegal. These 8 entries are now being used for breeding.
evidence_link: To be provided, AfricaRice Annual Report 2020. The report is yet to come as of June 2021; the contents were resented in AfricaRice Science Week in Feb 2021.

title: Expert System for Soil Nutrient Management developed for El Salvador
AGRI World Sources platform is a mapping application that uses public information on terrain, soil and climate to identify water sources for small-scale irrigation
Mobile phone application to engage farmers and expand the reach of nutritious zinc-biofortified wheat in Pakistan
narrative: Advisory content provides information in local languages (Urdu and Saraiki), plus a helpline, backed by a call center, answers farmers' questions and gets their feedback about adoption of biofortified crops. Content focuses on the signs of and risks from zinc deficiency, the agronomic and nutritional benefits of zinc wheat, and the commercial benefits of zinc wheat to farmers. In the pilot, customized SMS and push calls were sent to farmers in five districts of Punjab.

title: Traceability technologies tailored to scaling biofortified crops in Nigeria
narrative: Using blockchain technology (a type of distributed ledger technology) this app-based innovation can help value chain partners improve transparency and efficiency of business transactions, compliance processes and tracking and tracing of food products. Lack of traceability in the supply chain is impairing the wide adoption of Vitamin A Orange Maize in Nigeria. If it is not possible to differentiate foods across the supply chain, then the added value cannot be communicated to the consumer.

title: Biodiversity integrity indicator and threshold of minimum 10–20% of land for conservation in agricultural landscapes
Application of the Bayesian Belief Network methodology for analyzing institutional performance and rangeland governance in Tunisia
narrative: Bayesian Belief Network is a probabilistic graphical model of causal relationships which has been successfully adapted to characterize levels of rangeland governance and pathways to enhance rangeland governance under different land tenure systems.

title: Radio programming enhances agricultural technology awareness and dietary diversity and promotes women's empowerment in Malawi
narrative: Radio programming in Malawi consists of year-round daily broadcasts over national and community radio stations. The study assesses the effect of radio programming on agricultural development, nutrition and women's empowerment using nationally representative household panel data and qualitative interviews. Radio programming was found to enhance agricultural technology awareness (but not adoption) and dietary diversity and to promote women's and younger men's empowerment.

title: Operational framework to identify intervention points for supporting a tenure- and governance-enabling environment for community forest enterprises in Nepal
narrative: The innovation draws on success factors identified by Baynes et al. (2015) (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gloenvcha.2015.09.011) for community forestry (i.e., reduced social inequality; secure tenure rights, transparent and equitable community forest group governance, government support, provision of material benefits to community members) and adapts these factors into a framework geared toward identifying policy and programming intervention points for supporting tenure and governance-enabling environments for community forest enterprises.

title: Mechanism for the Operationalization of the Forest Stewardship Council Policy on Conversion
narrative: The objective of this procedure is to define permanent, equitable and effective measures for remediation of social and environmental harm caused by conversion.

title: Diversity for Restoration (D4R) decision support tool
narrative: The Diversity for Restoration (D4R) is a decision support tool that helps in species selection and seed sourcing for restoration using local site conditions and user-determined restoration objectives. This tool integrates different methods in order to obtain a suggestion on the best combination of species to achieve a given set of restoration objectives, recommendations on where to collect the planting material, and implications of future climate change for suitability.

title: Shademotion software for tree shade modeling, Version 5.0
narrative: CATIE's ShadeMotion innovation is an open-source technology that models tree shade and can inform tree-planting practices to improve crop yields, enhance agroforest sustainability, and support climate adaptation of both farm and agro-ecosystems. Version 5.0 of Shademotion was released in 2020. The new version  considerable reduces the time in the implementation of simulations and includes new features such as: trees can be planted in arrangements without the need of planting each tree individually; the development of the crop below the crown can be used to compute the shade map at the height of the crop plants; trimmable species with regular expansion-contraction of the crown can be modelled.

title: Implications for applying El Niño Southern Oscilation (ENSO) based precipitatio outlooks took agricultural management decisions in Ethiopian Highlands
narrative: Through analysis of precipitation and temperature records at monitored locations, we explore observed variability in climate patterns and trends across sites and seasons. This has implications for applying ENSO-based precipitation outlooks to agricultural management decision. Potential users are other researchers. Our scientists are available to brief those who are interested in further details or require clarification.

title: Set of solutions using remote sensing and supervised learning to replace autoregressive integrated moving average models to forecast weather
narrative: The convergence of remote sensing and supervised learning (SL) can generate solutions for the problems arising from climate change. A function that maps a set of variables to an output. This function can be used to predict new examples. Because they are nonparametric, these methods can mine large quantities of satellite data to capture the relationship between climate variables and crops, or successfully replace autoregressive integrated moving average models to forecast the weather.

title: Support of policy makers in Bangladesh to address the COVID19 pandemic based on foresight analysis.
narrative: Support to policy makers in Bangladesh to address the COVID19 pandemic based on foresight analysis. This second assessment, developed with FAO, CIMMYT, WorldFish, provides an invaluable and wide-ranging analysis that underlines the scale and scope of COVID-19’s impact on food and agriculture in Bangladesh.

title: Aflasafe product for Benin
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for Burundi
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for Cameroon
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for the Democratic Republic of Congo
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for Sudan
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for Uganda
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Aflasafe product for Zimbabwe
narrative: Biocontrol approach to prevent aflatoxin from growing in crops like maize and groundnuts

title: Set of training manuals for improving the quality and safety of informal dairy and pork value chains in Assam (India)
narrative: A set of seven training manuals were developed by ILRI for local government officials in Assam (India) to use in training targeted dairy and pork farmers and other actors along the value chain. The manuals were based on training needs assessments of the dairy and pork value chain actors in the state. The manuals are written in simple and clear language and contain photographs and illustrations to make them understandable.

title: Flexible agricultural index insurance products catering to heterogeneity in farmers' risk exposure improve farmers' welfare compared to traditional insurance schemes
narrative: The benefits of offering flexible agricultural index insurance products - comprising a number of independent insurance units covering against different timing and intensities of excess rainfall - were quantified by comparing farmer welfare under this scheme to that achieved under alternative counterfactual insurance options. Results show that, in contexts where farmer characteristics and farming practices are heterogeneous, providing flexibility improves farmers' welfare compared to selling a single insurance policy.

title: Series of commercialization guides for Aflasafe
narrative: Four guides outline the core processes of Aflasafe commercialization, i.e., how to take scientific research products to market. These guides include Market Assessment and Strategy Development, Investor Selection, Structuring the Business Relationship, and Implementation of the Business Development Strategy. The guides can enable the continued commercialization of Aflasafe and potentially support IITA or other CGIAR institutions in commercializing other products in the future.

title: COVID-19 and nutrition state-level monitoring report for India
narrative: This online report consolidates relevant data to monitor the interactions between COVID-19 and nutrition across the most populous states affected by both the pandemic and overall malnutrition. The report sources information from surveys, rapid assessments, academic journals, media, health management information systems, state and district level reports and is updated monthly. The purpose is to present available data to policy makers and program managers to strengthen public health and nutrition during the COVID-19 crisis.

title: Real-time artificial intelligence driven diagnostic that can be used to assess diets
narrative: A global-scale artificial-intelligence (AI) app for mobile devices that diagnoses diet-related problems for adolescents. The tool could also provide nutritional advice tailored to each individual, allowing users to make decisions to improve their diets, offline, without the need to access the cloud. Moreover, the AI tool could provide governments and development partners with real-tie diagnostics to strengthen surveillance systems in health and nutrition.

title: Women’s self-help groups as a delivery platform for nutrition and health interventions in India
narrative: There are more than 6 million women’s groups, including self-help groups (SHGs) in India. A4NH provided the first evidence synthesis on whether and how such groups improve women’s and children’s health. Results show that women’s groups can be a useful platform for delivering interventions but will be more effective if the intervention includes strategies to build communities’ capabilities.

title: Development of maize pre- breeding lines for climate change adaptation in Mexico.
narrative: Identification  of nine new pre-breeding lines for drought tolerance , Climate change adaptation

title: Development of Climate Change adaptation Open pollinated  varieties in Mexico
narrative: Building climate change resilient Seeds for food security

title: Water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) and biosecurity interventions for reducing burdens of infection, antibiotic use and antimicrobial resistance in animal agricultural settings
narrative: This systematic review identifies and synthesizes evidence from interventions designed to improve water, sanitation, and hygiene (WASH), and biosecurity in animal agriculture and in people that live and/or work with animals. Infection prevention and control is essential to addressing the emergence and spread of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in human health, food production and the environment. This review provides guidance on how best to address this through a One Health perspective.

title: Seed quality assurance options for roots, tubers and bananas, including conclusions and recommendations from several cases studies
narrative: Vegetatively propagated crop seed is particularly prone to damage from pests and diseases, leading to potential yield decline. A set of checklists was developed to assess the status of national seed quality assurance frameworks for vegetatively propagated crops. Three case studies (cassava in Nigeria, potato in Kenya, potato and cassava in Vietnam) provide a range of policy options which vary by crop, agro-climatic and market context.

title: Integrated model of economic impact of intersectoral One Health interventions for antimicrobial resistance (AMR)
narrative: Basic microeconomic evaluation model that incorporates impacts of antibiotic usage scenarios. With the application, users can evaluate resistance management interventions, especially those where the intervention is in one sector (e.g. agriculture) but the intended impact is expected to be in another sector (e.g. human health).

title: Big data applications in Ethiopia to support agricultural transformation
Respondent-driven method for mapping small agricultural plots using tablets and high-resolution imagery in Kenya
narrative: Developed an integrated and cost-effective way to simultaneously gather spatial and survey data. During household survey interviews, we helped farmers draw the boundaries of their plots on the tablets reloaded with high-resolution satellite imagery, and then related those boundaries to the detailed information the farmers provided about them.

title: Food system environmental data layers compiled and adapted to further innovate the Food Systems Dashboard
Innovative Food Systems Solutions Portal and online interactive portal that hosts and connects groups around innovative food systems solutions for healthy diets and a healthy planet
Digital repeat photography to operationalize fail-safe contract design in index insurance in Ethiopia
narrative: IFPRI and the R4 Rural Resilience Initiative led by the World Food Programme and Oxfam in Ethiopia have developed a prototype and app (AzmeraCam) for using crop images to operationalize fail-safe contract design in index insurance. This innovation will enable farmers to use smartphone photos to request audits in case of losses when the traditional satellite rainfall and vegetation indices do not trigger a payout.

title: Culturally Grounded Indicators of Resilience in Social-ecological Systems
narrative: The system includes gender equity in terms of access to opportunities and resources and recognition of women’s knowledge, experience and skill at household, community and landscape levels. The approach and set of indicators have been increasingly used and validated in a variety of settings, programs and engagements.

title: Protocol for systematic review on the impact of diversification on biodiversity
A practitioners’ guide to applying The Nature Conservancy’s Voice, Choice, and Action framework for community-based management of freshwater resources
Global and regional assessment of the potential of wastewater as a water, nutrient and energy source
narrative: Provides an estimate of the potential amount of water and nutrients recoverable from wastewater for use in agriculture.

title: Inclusion of lessons regarding the impact of COVID-19 and response actions in the Approach, Process and Methodology document for the City Region Food Systems (CRFS) program
narrative: The tool documents the severe impacts on the urban poor when food supplies from the hinterland to cities are disrupted.

title: Methodology for identifying suitable watersheds for rehabilitation in dryland areas
Low-cost, multi-purpose handheld and next generation soil-plant sensors to drive quality through the agricultural value chain

Seeds for Needs, comprehensive package to promote selection of local varieties adapted to local conditions from national genebanks through farmers' use, using crowdsourcing and citizen science approaches
narrative: A comprehensive participatory package to promote the selection of local varieties adapted to local conditions from the national genebank through farmers’ use, using crowdsourcing and citizen science approaches. This approach to promoting diverse wheat varieties is showing significant impacts.

title: Cross-CGIAR knowledge brokering framework for integrated landscape management
Predictive, integrated hydrological and groundwater use model in South Asia
narrative: Tool can be used for other joint groundwater and hydrological models.

title: Regional energy trading model for the Eastern Nile Region
narrative: Tool can be applied to other regional energy trading systems.

title: Enabling environment tool for scaling water innovations
narrative: Agricultural innovation scaling approaches need to include ‘softer elements’ such as people, supply chains, markets, financing mechanisms, policies, professional knowledge, power relations, incentives and history. The tool provides guidance to implementers to identify enablers and hinderers influencing farmers’ adoption of irrigation and water management technologies and, thus, increase impact.

title: "How are we doing?", a tool for participatory monitoring and adaptive learning in multi-stakeholder fora
narrative:
This tool is designed to be used by multistakeholder fora participants to foster better communication, mutual understanding and adaptive learning towards truly inclusive
processes.

title: Agricultural information videos to increase women's empowerment in agriculture in Uganda
narrative: Agricultural information videos designed to increase women's empowerment in agriculture were tested, focusing on two design features: targeting of information (who watches the videos in the participating households: the male co-head, the female co-head or both co-heads together) and the use of role models (who is featured in the video: a man, a woman or a couple). Recommendations were made on how to design video-based agricultural information campaigns to increase women's empowerment.

title: Participatory Prospective Analysis to understand the implications of tenure reform scenarios for the forestry sector and communities in forested landscapes.
narrative:
Participatory Prospective Analysis (PPA) aims to help decision makers understand the key drivers, challenges and consequences of tenure security policies and reforms in the forestry sector and for communities in forested landscapes. Through participatory meetings,
stakeholders identify and develop a range of tenure security scenarios and elaborate actions in response to each scenario while gaining confidence about their capacity to understand and better their own futures.

title: Tool for enhancing social inclusion through local dialogues on natural resource management
narrative:
This tool offers guidance on a tested approach for enhancing social inclusion through natural resource management (NRM). It can be used to accompany processes of community engagement and community-based or -led deliberations on NRM. As processes of social
exclusion are historically and contextually rooted, the tool is not meant to be overly prescriptive. Rather, it draws attention to the importance of representation, process and content in fostering inclusion in NRM or other community affairs.

title: Volunteer farmer trainer approach in Eastern Africa
narrative: The volunteer farmer trainer (VFT) approach is a type of farmer-to-farmer extension which involves the provision of training by farmers to farmers, often through the creation of a farmer trainers' structure.

title: Diagnostic tool for collaborative monitoring of forest landscape restoration
narrative: Checklist of 42 core success factors to be assessed at local, subnational, and national levels at different stages in the planning and implementation of FLR. The tool has practical application by providing guidance on best practices: specifically, how to start collaborative monitoring, and more generally, how to plan, prepare for, and evaluate FLR activities.

title: Role-playing game to promote the participation of key stakeholders in the livestock sector and catalog of fodder trees in Mesoamerica
narrative: The objective is to develop a tool to help mitigate the impact of traditional farming on the environment and the transformation of these production models into sustainable farming systems.

title: A typology for land restoration through agroforestry
narrative: After reviewing pantropical international research on forests, trees, and agroforestry, we developed an options-by-context typology that can help to link knowledge with action in people-centric restoration in which external stakeholders coinvest, reflecting shared responsibility for historical degradation and benefits from environmental stewardship.

title: A Framework for COVID 19 and Agroecosystems resilience Management
narrative:
This framework for the analysis and management of COVID 19 impact pathways in the context of agroecosystems.
The way the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted human lives and livelihoods constituted a stress test for agroecosystems in developing countries, as part of rural–urban systems and the global economy. We applied two conceptual schemes to dissect the evidence in peer-reviewed literature so far, as a basis for better understanding and enabling ‘building back better’

title: Tool for assessing ecosystem services in Bamboo forests in Colombia
narrative: The tool describes a step-wise approach to assessing multiple ecosystem services in natural bamboo forests as well as bamboo agroforestry systems. Examples of the application in such systems in Colombia are presented.

title: A framework for regenerative energy supply options for Africa
narrative: The framework examines the role of ecosystems in household energy supply in Africa and explores pathways to ecosystem-based approaches to bioenergy generation by building on the regenerative economy concept.

title: Step-by-step guide to conducting farmer surveys for tilapia epidemiology and health economics
narrative: Online mobile phone data collection tools (farmer surveys) to generate data needed for an integrated assessment of tilapia epidemiology and health economics. Guide for field implementation of surveys developed. This includes procedure for recruiting the field team, providing training and pretesting the survey tool. Guidance for the use of open access digital solutions for data gathering also included.

title: A formal financial package facilitated by Digital Financial Service (DFS) channels to improve access to credit for small aquaculture farmers and small and medium enterprises in Bangladesh.
Community-based green mussel production system in Cox's Bazar (Bangladesh)
narrative: The green mussel production system is a community-driven initiative to develop a blue food production system as a nature-based solution in the Bay of Bengal, Bangladesh. The coastal fishing households are generating an increased income from green mussel farming to cope with the hardship of marine fishing bans.

title: Development and piloting of a comprehensive framework for farming systems sustainability assessment
narrative: A comprehensive framework for farming systems sustainability assessment with five domains- Environmental sustainability, Economic sustainability, Social sustainability, Productivity and Human well-being and 115 measurable indicators has been developed and implemented/validated in one location in India (Nalgonda) for different functional farm types. The development of online open access Dashboard tool for farming system sustainability assessment using the comprehensive framework has been conceptualized and being developed as a global public good.

title: Scaling community seed banks to implement seed production
narrative: Community-seed producers are a relatively under-researched and under-documented category, but have the potential to cater to the seed needs and interests of smallholder farmers. This innovation supports community-seed production and access using community seedbanks setup. Community seedbanks first emerged with a focus on conservation of crop diversity, but in recent years, some of them have developed additional and complementary activities, such as crop improvement and seed production and distribution.

title: Hand Push Legume Planter Seeder (HPLS) to improve cropping efficiency in Mozambique
narrative: The introduction of the HPLS machine not only saves on time used at planting but also enables the farmer to save on cost for other field operations. The amount of time saved with HPLS in relation to hoe plus line spacing could be invested in increasing the area of production for the same legume or diversifying to other cropsGender-friendly hand push legume planter which reduce planting time and drudgery of farm women and cut down

title: New sorghum variety Jaicar Nutrigaze for fodder yield and digestibility and resistance to biotic stress factors in the dry mid-altitudes of India
narrative: Jaicar Nutrigaze is quite resistant to grain mold (30%, superiority over checks CSV 23 and SPV 2012); with 9-10 mt/ha grain yield, and 6-6.5 mt/ha fodder yield estimates. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG 1,2,3, and 17.

title: Sorghum variety Telangana Jonna 1 for cultivation in dry mid-altitudes of India for grain yield, with biotic stress resistance, and high digestibility
narrative: Telangana Jonna 1 is an inbred variety unique for its yellow-white, elliptic shape, and medium sized grains. Its strong qualities are on grain yield and digestibility, and biotic stress resistance. This variety will potentially contribute towards SDG Goals 1,2,3, and 17.

title: Finger millet inbred variety Katope for cultivation in low to mid-altitudes in Malawi and Kenya
narrative: Katope is a green-colored plant with small ears and copper brown seed. It stands erect of medium height. The variety yields 2.0-2.5 t/ha in farmers fields. Katope is tolerant to several abiotic stresses. The dietary value of this variety lies in its high Calcium and Iron content. This variety has been developed under the AVISA Project, and will potentially contribute to SDG Goals 1,2,3,5,8,12,13, and 17.

title: Finger millet inbred variety Kambulanje for cultivation in low to mid-altitudes in Malawi and Uganda
narrative: Kambulanje was selected from a regional kit shared by ICRISAT-Nairobi and evaluated by releasing partners in Malawi under the AVISA Project. Its yield estimates range from 2-2.5 mt/ha, and is noted for biotics stress resistance, and abiotic stress tolerance, with dietary value being high in Calcium, Iron and Protein. It is a green colored plant with erect and medium height, and responses well to fertilizer. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3,5,10,12,12 and 17.

title: Groundnut inbred variety CG15 for cultivation in low to mid-altitudes in Malawi and Mozambique
narrative: CG15 is a Spanish variety that has a yield potential of 1.8 mt/ha, with drought tolerance and resistance to early leaf spot and groundnut rosette disease. It is an early-maturing variety (90-110 days) with high protein content. The pods have a medium constriction with a small pod beak and contain two seeds per pod.

title: Groundnut inbred variety CG16 for cultivation in low to mid-altitudes in Malawi and Mozambique
narrative: CG16 is a Spanish variety that has a yield potential of 1.3 to 1.8 mt/ha, early-maturing variety (90-110 days) with high grain yield and protein content. The pods have a medium constriction with a small pod beak and contain two seeds per pod. CG16 is tolerant to early leaf spot and the groundnut rosette disease. The seeds are medium sized with a tan color. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG Goals 1 and 2.

title: Groundnut inbred variety CG17 for cultivation in low to mid-altitudes in Malawi and Zambia
narrative: CG17 is an early-maturing Spanish variety that is high-yielding (1.3 to 1.8 mt/ha). This variety demonstrates biotic stress resistance, and produces grain with high protein and digestibility. This variety has been tested in Malawi and Zambia under the AVISA Project, and will potentially contribute to SDG Goals 1 and 2.

title: Chickpea inbred variety ICCV 97105 for cultivation in mid-altitudes in Malawi, Kenya, and Tanzania
narrative: ICCV 97105 is a medium duration desi variety adapted across the medium and high-altitude semi arid environments. This variety is relatively less susceptible to pod sucking bugs and to pod borers, and has tolerance to leaf diseases and wilt. It flowers in 35-44 days and matures in 125-142 days, with yield potential of 2.6 mt/ha. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG Goals 1,2 and 3.

title: Chickpea inbred variety ICCV 96329 for cultivation in medium to high altitudes India and Malawi
narrative: ICCV 96329 is a medium duration (flowers in 35 - 44 days and matures in 125 - 142 days) kabuli variety for semi-arid environments. This Variety is relatively less susceptible to pod sucking bugs and to pod borers, and has tolerance to leaf diseases and wilt. This high-yielding variety (2.1-2.6 mt/ha) is also known for its grain/pod size and protein content. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2, and 3.

title: Pearl millet inbred variety TSFB 15-4 for cultivation in India
narrative: The variety TSFB 15-4 developed by random mating among progenies of IP 20485, IP 20550, IP 20555, IP 20584. This variety is specialized for fodder yield and nutrition particularly for digestibility and protein content. In field tests, it exceeded the national check Giant bajra (by 9.1%) and zonal check Moti bajra (by 5.7%) in terms of dry matter yield

title: Pearl millet inbred variety TSFB 15-8 for cultivation in India
narrative: TSFB 15-8 was developed by random mating between the progenies of IP 22269, IP 15352 and HTGP coded breeding lines. It`s preferred traits include fodder yield and nutrition (digestibility and protein content), and biotic stress resistance. in terms of dry matter yield, TSFB 15-8 exceeded the national check Giant bajra by 10.8%, and the zonal check Moti bajr by 7.3%.

title: Pearl millet hybrid variety IKMH18001 for cultivation in the Sudanian Zone
narrative: IKMH18001 is the first commercial single cross hybrid released in Burkina Faso. It`s main biotic stress resistance is against downy mildew. It produces medium long heads, grey-colored anthers, and large grains/pods. It also stay green trait. It is a high-yielding (3.8 to 4.5 mt/ha) dual purpose hybrid i.e. cultivated for both grain and fodder yield. It is also high in Iron and Zinc. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2, and

title: Pearl millet inbred variety IKMV18004 for cultivation in the Sudanian Zone
narrative: IKMV18004 is a high yielding (2.0 to 2.2 mt/ha), dual purpose (i.e. for grin and fodder yield), downy mildew resistant, medium duration pearl millet variety with high nutritional value (Iron and Zinc). this variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3, and 17.

title: Pearl millet inbred variety IKMV18001 for cultivation in the Sudanian Zone
narrative: IKMV18001 is  a high-yielding dual (2.1 to 2.3 mt/ha) purpose variety for grain and fodder yield. it is a mildew resistant, medium duration variety. It also has high nutritional value containing Iron and Zinc. this variety will potentially contribute to the SDG`s 1,2,3, and 17.

title: Chickpea inbred variety NBeG 452 for cultivation in the dry lowlands in India
narrative: NBeG 452 is a high-yielding (2.2 to 2.3 mt/ha) short duration rainfed chickpea variety. It is resistant to wilt, and has tolerance to drought. This variety produces grains with high digestibility, and high protein content. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3,12, and  17.

title: Chickpea inbred variety Phule Vishwaraj for cultivation in dry lowlands in India
narrative: Phule Vishwaraj is an early-maturing variety with semi-erect stand. it has high yield potential (1.6 to 2.8 mt/ha) with Fusarium wilt resistance, and drought tolerant making it suitable for rainfed condition. It`s dietary value is high digestibility, and high protein, iron and zinc content. this variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,8,11,12, and 13.

title: Chickpea inbred variety Eshete for cultivation in dry mid-altitudes in Ethiopia and India
narrative: Eshete is the first machine harvestable, early maturing variety released in Ethiopia with grain yield estimates of 1.4 to 1.5 mt/ha. Among its stress-related traits are fusarium wilt resistance, aschochyta blight resistance, and drought tolerance. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3,7,8,11,12, and 13.

title: Chickpea inbred variety RVG 204 for cultivation in the dry lowlands of India
narrative: RVG 204 is the first machine harvestable desi variety of chickpea for central and northern India. This variety has high yield potential in rainfed condition (2.20 to 2.25 mt/ha). it has desirable abiotic and biotic stress robustness, and dietary characteristics including digestibility, and high contents of iron, zinc, and protein. this variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3,8,10,12 and 13.

title: Kabuli chickpea inbred variety JGK 6 for cultivation in dry lowlands in India
narrative: JGK 6 is is a large-seeded Kabuli early- maturing chickpea variety with semi-erect crop stand. Field tests estimated yield potential of 2 mt/ha. it has desirable biotic and abiotic stress robustness, with highly-digestible and high-protein grains. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3,8,12,and 13.

title: Kabuli chickpea inbred variety NBeG 810 for cultivation in low altitude areas in India
narrative: NBeG 810 is an extra large seeded, and early maturing Kabuli chickpea with Fusarium wilt resistance. It is high-yielding (2.2 to 2.5 mt/ha) producing highly digestible grains high in iron, zinc, and protein. This variety will potentially contribute to SDG`s 1,2,3,7,8,10,11,12,13,15, and 17.

title: Kabuli chickpea inbred variety RLBGK 1 for cultivation in dry lowlands in India
narrative: RLBGK 1 is an extra large-seeded, early-maturing kabuli type chickpea with semi erect crop stand. Its yield potential ranges from 1.6 to 2.2 mt/ha. It is fusarium wilt resistance and suitable for rainfed conditions. It produces highly digestible grains with high iron, zinc and protein content.

title: Groundnut inbred variety ICGV 06189 for cultivation in low humidity mid-altitude areas in India.
narrative: ICGV 06189 is a superior export-quality confectionery groundnut variety with higher recovery of large seeds (> 70g /100 seeds).  It has high yield potential of 2.45 mt/ha, and desirable nutritional value. The development and release of this variety has contributed to SDG 17.

title: Groundnut inbred variety Chhattisgarh Mungfali-1 for cultivation in low to mid altitudes in India
narrative: Chhattisgarh Mungfali-1 is a high yielding (2.0 to 2.5 mt/ha), high oil containing variety with very good pod and kernel features groundnut variety. The level of partnerships contributing to the development and release of this variety has contributed to SDG 17.

title: Integrated and adaptive delivery system for climate-resilient common bean varieties
narrative: To adapt to pandemic-related challenges affecting delivery of common bean technology, two innovative solutions were implemented: (1) a farmer service center (FSC) managed by trained core farmer entrepreneurs, and (2) capitalizing on digital tools to sustain bean value chains. The FSC model empowers a mobilizer group trained to provide extension services (inputs+ information) within bean corridors. Digitalization of bean value chains helped data gathering and research, farmer access to technical information, and digital payment solutions.

title: Standardization of different artificial diets for rearing protocols and development of integrated pest management strategies for fall armyworm
narrative: Fall army worm (Spodoptera frugiperda ) is one of the important invasive pests causing economic losses to maize, sorghum and other millets. Study revealed that the least life cycle period (egg to adult) was obtained with sorghum+ chickpea based diet (D1: 31-39 days) as compared to sorghum based diet(D2: 37-44 days) and maize+ chickpea based diet (D3: 40-48 days). Developed IPM strategies for Fall armyworm

title: Low-cost feed formulation with local ingredients for tilapia farming in Democratic Republic of Congo (Bukavu and Kinshasa)
narrative: Following a feed ingredient scoping in Bukavu and Kinshasa, cost-effective tiapia feed was formulated using locally available ingredients. Locally produced fish feed has the potential to reduce fish feed imports and add value to highly available local ingredients with important value for tilapia farmers in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Model resilient fishing village: an approach of livelihood transformation of fishery communities in Bangladesh
narrative: The resilient model fishing village is intended to facilitate change in ecological, social, cultural, and economic well-being through inclusive community development initiatives. The approach brings some positive outcomes in improving the livelihoods of fishing communities, the co-management system, women empowerment and social capitals in a holistic manner.

title: DArTseq genetic marker developed for Catla
narrative: Analysis of DArTseq genetic marker data successfully identified and characterized single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and silicoDArT markers in catla. The analysis identified an unexpectedly high level of sibship among breeding population founders and found no or low levels of divergence in SNPs among the three river populations studied.

title: Generation 17 of Genetically Improved Farmed Tilapia (GIFT) strain regeneration in Penang, Malaysia
narrative: Ninety-nine families (80 unique families) of GIFT G17 produced in Penang (Malaysia) from the backup stock and performance tested in quarantine conditions in 2020

title: Design of tilapia single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) chip
narrative: A SNP chip optimized for genomic selection of GIFT and Abbassa tilapia strains was designed in collaboration with the Roslin institute for manufacture and application to Nile Tilapia genetic improvement programs in 2019.

title: Low-Cost portable fish dryer to produce food safe dried fish and promote the use of dried powdered small indigenous fish species (SIS) for improved nutrition in Myanmar
narrative: The initial idea for the portable fish drier was inspired by a Thai design, which WorldFish, through the MYSAP Inland project, modified and tested as 2 prototype versions, before having 60 fish driers manufactured in Shwebo Township that were distributed to 20 households in each of three townships for community testing

title: Generation 8 of genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) has been produced in India
narrative: Fully-pedigreed genetic improvement program for GIFT established in India. GIFT germplasm was supplied to the WorldFish's partner in the genetic program, the Rajiv Ghandi Center for Aquaculture (RGCA) , in 2011 and 2016. Considering 2011 as G0 in India, RGCA has now produced 41 families of G8 in 2020.

title: Gendered value chain: Framework and methodology
narrative: A value chain analysis framework and method that combines gender and economic analysis. The framework can be combined with nutrition or environmental modules and applies a gender social relations approach . It fits with FISH gender integration guidelines framing and enables comparisons. It has been developed in Aquaculture Flagship but is relevant also to SSF and to wider food system chain analysis

title: Malawi Gold Standard Aquaculture Production System
narrative: The Malawi Gold Standard Aquaculture Production System was developed. The use of the Gold Standard was supported by 8 training modules that covers key aspect of the fish production systems.

title: Generation 3 of Rohu Carp
narrative: Generation 3 of Rohu Carp was produced – grown out and assessed

title: Contextualized biosecurity practices and protocols for tilapia hatchery technicians in Bangladesh
narrative: Biosecurity practices and protocols for  tilapia hatchery technicians in Bangladesh were developed based on previous experiences, including practical and empirical evidences from Bangladesh and elsewhere. A manual in Bengali was published in 2020 to provide guidelines for capacity development activities at hatchery level and to thus support sustainable intensification of tilapia production systems in Bangladesh.

title: Standard operating procedure (SOP) for tagging Indian major carps with Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags in India
narrative: Standard operating procedure for tagging Indian major carp with Passive Integrated Transponder (PIT) tags developed and distributed by WorldFish is a set of step by step instructions to carry out tagging of broodstocks. This allows identification of individual broodfish in the multiplication centres and hatcheries.

title: Contextualized better management practices (BMPs) for monosex tilapia seed production in Timor-Leste
narrative: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for producing high-quality genetically improved farmed tilapia (GIFT) monosex seed were developed to support the scaling of fish farming to contribute to food and nutrition security in Timor-Leste. These simple and low-cost methods and recommendations, including biosecurity, have been tested and proven over five years of research and development in Timor-Leste.

title: Genetic diversity of tilapia lake virus genome segment 1 from 2011 to 2019 described and a newly validated semi-nested RT-PCR method developed
narrative: The newly established PCR protocol is 100 times more sensitive than previous protocols when comparatively assayed with RNA extracted from infected fish. The assay was also shown to be specific when tested against negative control samples.

title: Rapid diagnostic for Flavobacterium columnare developed. This bacteria is a causative agent of columnaris, a serious disease affecting numerous freshwater fish species worldwide.
narrative: Although several molecular protocols have been established to detect this pathogen, there still was a need to develop simpler on-field applicable techniques. Hence, we have developed a more practical and efficient assay to detect F. columnare based on the combination of recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) and a lateral flow dipstick (LFD). Cross-reactivity against other bacteria and false results on 20 clinical samples were not observed, indicating its extremely high specificity and accuracy.

title: New generation of fish friendly irrigation innovations (sluice gates, irrigation canals, dams) to strengthen the resilience and sustainability and livelihoods of fisheries-dependent communities in Asia and Africa
narrative: This nature-based solution serves to integrate fisheries into irrigation systems. The innovation produces mutual benefits to both fisheries and irrigation systems through allowing fish migration, the creation of new aquatic habitats for fish species in irrigated lands and the enhancement of inland fisheries productivity through integrated systems, such as irrigated rice-fish farming systems.

title: Contextualized better management practices (BMPs) for tilapia hatcheries in Myanmar
narrative: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for hatcheries in Myanmar were developed based on learning from field experiences, including empirical evidences from Myanmar and elsewhere. A BMPs manual, in both English and Burmese languages, funded by EU and BMZ Myanmar Sustainable Aquaculture Program inland component, has been published to provide guidelines for tilapia breeding and all-male fry production to support sustainable intensification of tilapia production systems in Myanmar.

title: Dried Small Fish Species (SIS) powder as complementary food in Myanmar targeting particularly young children
narrative: Dried small fish powder has been introduced in communities in several countries in Africa and Asia, by WorldFish and partners. To explore suitable entry points for introducing small fish powder in Myanmar, WorldFish is collaborating with a local business partner, FedWell Foods. The homemade fish powder can be introduced as a complementary food for children over 6 months-old. The home-made fish powder is particularly beneficial for young children (06-23 months) as a complementary food.

title: Project Monitoring Unit (PMU) with GIS based Management Information System (MIS),  Web and Mobile application adopted by the Government of Odisha
narrative: WorldFish has facilitate and set up a Project Monitoring Unit (PMU) with GIS based Management Information System (MIS). The proposed platform will be integrated with 2 components (Mobile and Web Application) as cloud-based services. The digital innovation will support the Directorate of Fisheries, Odisha is implementing several State in the implementation of several State and Central Government schemes.MIS produces real-time information that supports the management functions of an the government and facilitates the decision-making process.

title: Rice fish production practice typology in South and South-East Asia
narrative: A novel typology of rice-fish production practices was developed, drawing on agroecological principles, to refine decision making and scenarios for resilient and diverse food system transformation in Southern Asia.

title: Contextualized better management practices (BMPs) for tilapia broodstock conditioning and mass spawning in hapas in ponds  in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC)
narrative: In cooperation with the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) in Bukavu and Kinshasa, WorldFish has worked to build the capacities of technicians and hatchery operators from the hatchery sites in the country. The partnership has helped increase access to high-quality aquaculture inputs—specifically seed and feed. These guidelines have been developed to optimize the conditioning and spawning of tilapia broodstock for improved fry and fingerling production.

title: Genetic markers (SNPs) for identifying improved tilapia strains in Asia
narrative: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) were identified and a low density panel of several hundred were developed using samples from core breeding programs of several improved tilapia strains used in Asia. This panel successfully distinguished the different strains and was used to identify the strains used in a large sample of hatcheries (about 100 in each country) in Bangladesh and the Philippines, providing a tool to assess seed supply in Asia.

title: Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for the inclusion of dried small fish in the Supplementary Nutrition Program (SNP) in Odisha, India
narrative: This Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) has been prepared in line with existing implementation guidelines for Odisha’s Supplementary Nutrition Program and international criteria for sustainably improving the nutritional content of state delivered meals . The SOP is intended as a unifying document for use by the WorldFish Odisha team and collaborating stakeholders in piloting and evaluating the inclusion of dried small fish products in the Odisha State Supplementary Nutrition Program.

title: Better Management Practices (BMPs) for climate resilient paddy-cum-fish integrated farming in Assam, India
narrative: The BMPs for paddy-cum-fish integrated farming are a set of recommendations on technical and management interventions for realizing the sustainable and climate-resilient increase in productivity of paddy cum fish integrated farming system in Assam.

title: Better Management Practices (BMP) for Beel (wetland) fisheries in Assam, India
narrative: WorldFish based on its experience in wetland development projects in Bangladesh has provided the necessary technical support to Assam Department of Fisheries and has developed Better Management Practices (BMP) for beel (wetland) fisheries to be implemented. The activity for improving productivity of Beels include habitat restoration and culture-cum- capture fisheries technology demonstration in the selected Beels.

title: Better management practices (BMPs) for Indian major carp hatcheries in India
narrative: Hatcheries play a crucial role in aquaculture since availability of quality fish seed at desirable time is one of the most decisive factor to increase production, vertical expansion and growth of the industry. The Better Management Practices for Indian major carp hatcheries refers to a set of standard management practices guidance that are developed based on existing practices and associated risks to support the seed producers in India to produce and deliver quality carp seeds.

title: Standardized processing methods for boneless rohu (Labeo rohita) products in Odisha, India.
narrative: Rohu (Labeo rohita) is one of the commercially important freshwater fish in India. Despite its high production and good taste, the market value of carps and consumer acceptance is low in many states of India because of the presence of intramuscular spines and bones. WorldFish developed standardized processing method for preparation of boneless rohu. Promotion of boneless Rohu in Odisha and India would create a new line of business and employ many rural people.

title: Fish powder for new livelihood opportunities for women in Timor-Leste
narrative: The fish based powder is made of fish, moringa leaves, dried shrimp, roasted sesame seeds, onion powder, salt, pepper, sugar, oil and cooked chili. The idea to make fish-based powder came from the women themselves. WorldFish has been doing research with the community for many years . Having previously received training on making fish-based powder, the women decided to build on these existing skills. Doing so enables them to improve their livelihoods.

title: Transgenic banana resistant to banana Xanthomonas wilt (BXW) disease in Uganda
narrative: Banana Xanthomonas wilt (BXW)  is a serious threat to banana production in East Africa. Transgenic bananas have been generated by inserting Hrap or Pflp genes in two local banana cultivars, and shown to be resistant to BXW over five seasons in confined field trials.

title: High quality cassava peel for animal feed in Nigeria
narrative: Production of high quality cassava peels to be used for animal feed is based on a simple and low-tech process that can be carried out by small-scale processors. This process allow to add value to the large quantities of wastes and residues generated by cassava processing and contribute in reducing the environmental hazards and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions.

title: Triple S – Storing Sweetpotato Roots in Sand and Sprouting for Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: Triple S refers to Storing sweetpotato roots in Sand and Sprouting to initiate development and growth of healthy shoots for timely production of clean  planting material. Based on existing farmer practice, it is targeted for areas where a long dry season makes it difficult for farmers to conserve planting material. Small to medium pest free, mature roots are selected, cured under open shade, and then placed in containers  layered with coarse sand. The containers are stored in a cool house for up to seven months.

title: Participatory Market Chain Approach (PMCA): A Process to Facilitate Collaboration among Value Chain Stakeholders
narrative: This multi-stakeholder approach is based on a flexible three-stage participatory process to improve communication, build trust, and facilitate collaboration among value chain stakeholders so that they can jointly identify, analyze, and exploit new market opportunities.

title: Satellite nursery production of potato rooted apical cuttings by private sector in Kenya and Uganda
narrative: Making cuttings more accessible by producing cuttings in small scale nurseries to make cuttings more accessible to rural farming communities and hence increasing users.

title: Seed and soil health intervention framework for potato
narrative: Field deployable Loop-mediated isothermal Amplification (LAMP) diagnostic test for bacterial wilt (BW) pathogen used by national regulatory bodies and private diagnostic services.

title: Potato Stakeholder Platforms in Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: GIZ SEWOA global program is supporting the south-south Green Innovation potato advisory role to support the development and operations of potato stakeholder platforms in SSA, including Cameroon, Nigeria, and Uganda. Within this framework, the National Potato Council of Kenya (NPCK) will lead south-south capacity development.

title: Thermal chamber: Scaling up multiplication of disease-free banana and plantain planting material in Colombia
narrative: This is part of a project funded by COLCIENCIAS, and looks to reduce the impact of pests and diseases in Valle del Cauca. The thermal chamber technology has been proven efficient to accelerate the multiplication of disease-free planting material. Thanks to this, ASOMUSACEAS partners (176 plantain families-farmers)  have increased their production and by only using clean seeds they help controlling the re-emergence of Moko disease in their fields.

title: Impact network analysis (INA) to understand and describe RTB seed systems
narrative: Impact Network Analysis (INA) is a multi-layer network analysis that looks at the effects of a technology – such as a new variety, a management strategy, or other types of information – as it influences the outcomes of linked socioeconomic networks and biophysical networks.

title: ClimMob 3.0 a digital platform for citizen science on food and agriculture
narrative: ClimMob 3.0 has been released in 2020 and is now used by all new tricot projects. ClimMob is a professionally implemented digital platform that facilitates on-farm/end-user experiments on agricultural/food technological options. It is being used for variety trials in cassava, potato and sweetpotato, as well as many non-RTB crops. The platform facilitates experimental design, barcodes, electronic data collection, monitoring of progress, and automatic reporting. A special RTB version has been made available (https://rtb.climmob.net).

title: Climate-smart mid-altitude disease-resistant potato in Rwanda
narrative: The International Potato Center (CIP) has developed a new population of late blight resistant and heat tolerant potatoes (LBHT).  These clones have been sent to several countries in Africa, Asia and Latin America for variety development and use in breeding.

title: Humid Tropical and Sub-Tropical Highlands Late-Blight Resistant Potatoes in Kenya
narrative: Potato is a traditional crop in the Sub-Saharan Africa highlands, where late blight is also endemic. Breeding efforts for highland tropical potato focus on combining late blight resistance with market-preferred traits, as most processing potatoes originate from highland areas in Kenya.

title: Rapid multiplication of planting material through rooted apical cuttings for seed potato systems in Kenya
narrative: Rapid multiplication technique for potato planting material. It consists in producing rooted cuttings from tissue culture plantlets grown in screenhouses. Once planted in the field, each cutting produces 7 to 10, and up to 15+, tubers which are multiplied a further season or two, then the harvest is sold as seed.

title: Decentralized seed multiplier approach to potato seed production for Eastern Africa
narrative: Onward multiplication of certified seed by decentralized seed multipliers is the step along the seed value chain that makes quality seed available for potato farmers. Certified seed producers are only a few in a given country and cannot produce the demanded seed quantities, and few producers result in long distances farmers have to travel to purchase seed. At a planting rate of 2-2.5 t/ha, localized seed production is necessary to ensure farmers have access to quality seed.

title: Mid-altitude and Semi-humid Subtropical Highlands Heat-Drought and Virus-Resistant Potatoes in Kenya
narrative: Virus pressure is greater in mid-altitude, semi-humid subtropical agro-ecologies, therefore breeding efforts focus on combining abiotic stress tolerance with virus resistance. Tolerance to heat and water stress is required for semi-humid regions where rainfall is erratic. Introducing heat-tolerant potatoes will expand the area suitable for potato production. CIP observes high demand among farmers for heat-tolerant potato to supply to tropical urban centers to replace crops originating from distant highland regions.

title: Potato-legume intercropping systems for smallholder climate resilience and soil conservation in different agro-ecologies for Kenya
narrative: Different potato-legume intercropping combinations optimized for different agro-ecological zones of Kenya, provide benefits for soil conservation, soil nutrients and moisture content, and yield and economic benefits for smallholder farmers.

title: Integrated Pest Management (IPM) of cassava whiteflies in Eastern Africa
narrative: Commercial entomopathogenic biopesticides were tested on for efficacy against cassava whiteflies under laboratory and field conditions. Mycotal caused significant mortality of up to 80% under laboratory conditions and suppressed whiteflies and nymphs for up to 3 times compared to control under field conditions.

title: Nuru Potato Artificial Intelligence for diagnosing crop disease in the field
narrative: AI was trained with pictures of late blight and early blight and an AI model developed, which was subsequently tested for accuracy in potato farmers field in Uganda. The validation report is provided. The next step is to integrate it into the Nuru app.

title: Method for predicting climate-based risk of insect vectored diseases using temperature dependent insect phenology models and transmission functions
narrative: The Insect life cycle modeling tool (ILCYM) has previously been shown to predict insect pest risk locally on a global scale based on current or future temperatures. This innovation expands the application of ILCYM to include insect transmitted diseases, viruses in this case, by linking insect phenology models to temperature dependent virus transmission rates, enabling predictions of disease risk and disease risk maps.

title: Technology for inducing flowers to make crosses in breeding programs in Colombia
narrative: The Flowering inducing technology uses photoperiod extension, pruning, and plant growth regulators to modify the plant architecture and promote flower development of cassava. Erect plant type is included in the production profiles for variety development in breeding programs. In crossing nurseries, the progenitors with erect plant type flower late or produce few flowers. To promote the flowering of the erect progenitors, we collaborated with IITA and Cornell University and developed a flower-inducing technology.

title: Development of transgenic potato variety resistant to late blight in Uganda
narrative: Potato variety Victoria, which is a popular variety in Uganda, has been transformed with three stacked genes taken from wild potato species, that confer resistance to the late blight pathogen, Phytophtora infestans. Having more than one resistance gene ensures the resistance is more robust, and cannot be overcome easily by the pathogen. This product has been tested in multi-location trials under confined conditions, and shown to be identical to the variety Victoria, and completely resistant.

title: Open Data Kit (ODK) tool for disease surveillance that allows data harmonization and visualization in near Realtime
narrative: The tool allows harmonization of protocols, avoids problems with handwritten notes that might not be legible, avoid time lapse between data collection and analysis, standardize data collection parameters and allow report visualization in near real-time. The tool was validated during Foc TR4 surveys.

title: BananaTainer: High throughput phenotyping system to evaluate the potential to grow in specific agro-eco environments
narrative: The BananaTainer is a high throughput system that simulates different abiotic environments (temperatures, air humidity, CO2, nutrients) and is able to grow 504 plants simultaneously. By simulating different climates in this sophisticated controlled lab environment at the same location as the germplasm collection, the ITC collection is efficiently being screened for potential varieties that have good growth performance for the different agro-eco zones.

title: Identification of intergenomic structure in ABB allotriploid bananas
narrative: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) are used to calculate genomic variant ratios and to infer the structure of chromosomes that underwent intergenomic recombination in hybrid cultivars.

title: Flower inducing technology in cassava in South-Eastern Asia and Western Africa
narrative: Cornell University and IITA collaboration allow to develop of the technology to inducing flowers, so breeders can harvest more seeds and much earlier. The flower-inducing technology includes three major components, photoperiod extension, pruning, and growth regulators.

title: AKILIMO Mobile Application Decision Support System For Cassava Farmers for Nigeria and Tanzania
narrative: The AKILIMO smartphone app provides tailored decision support in cassava agronomy for Nigeria and Tanzania. The user can receive advice on fertilizer application, best planting and harvesting time, type and intensity of soil tillage and on inter cropping, for cassava - maize in Nigeria and cassava-sweet-potato in Tanzania. An important feature of AKILIMO is that the recommendations focus on an increase of profit for the farmer rather than only yield.

title: Development of Kompetitive Allele Specific polymerase chain reaction (KASP) genotyping technique for identification of cassava whiteflies in Africa
narrative: Kompetitive Allele-Specific PCR (KASP) assay a rapid and accurate diagnostic tool was developed for cassava Bemisia tabaci whiteflies. Out of the 152 whitefly samples that were tested from 18 countries in Africa using seven primer sets,151 (99.3%) produced genotyping results consistent with NextRAD sequencing data. This assay can, therefore, be routinely used to rapidly diagnose cassava whiteflies in Africa.

title: Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA) tools for rapid detection of African and East-African Cassava Mosaic Virus in cassava tissue and whiteflies
narrative: Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA) is a novel isothermal method for rapid amplification and detection of targeted cassava mosaic begomovirus genomic DNA amplicons within 15 to 20 min of incubation at 38 ℃. This assay provides rapid, reliable and sensitive detection of African and East-African Cassava Mosaic Virus and suitable for use in surveillance, phenotyping for breeding, seed health testing and other applications.

title: An innovative Healthy Baby Toolkit to improve infant and young child feeding practices for Ethiopia and Bangladesh
narrative: The nutrition toolkit, designed for use by infants 6-23 months of age, consists of a bowl with lines and symbols that cue age-appropriate meal frequency and volume, a slotted spoon that promotes optimal thickness of infant foods and a pictorial counseling card that uses locally adapted images to convey use of the toolkit to achieve optimal infant-and-young-child feeding practices as well as messages on dietary diversity, handwashing and safe preparation of food and water.

title: Protocol for sweetpotato leaf collection using locally available material for accurate varietal identification based on DNA fingerprinting in Malawi
narrative: Sweetpotato leaf collection for varietal identification is key for accurately understand varietal impact at household level. However, logistics to collect and conserve leaves can be complicated, specially in sub-saharan countries with poor road infrastructure and few places to keep cold the material during survey development. To overcome this problem, we developed a protocol to use locally available products together with high quality standard for managing plant material for DNA extraction.

title: Community-Based Disease Monitoring System for Action against Late Blight in Ethiopia
narrative: An intervention that combines community-based disease monitoring and learning systems with the use of social media platforms to foster effective collective action against plant diseases.

title: Gender Responsible Scaling (GRS) Tool for Roots, Tubers and Bananas in Africa
narrative: A tool that supports scaling initiatives in adapting their scaling strategies to socially differentiated groups in order to prevent or mitigate negative consequences of scaling

title: Accelerated multiplication and deployment of clean planting materials
narrative: The CIAT cassava program has established practicable multiplication innovations in Laos and Cambodia during 2020 to provide disease-free planting material to the cassava growers and also for rapid dissemination of improved variety(s).

title: A modeling platform for trade-off analysis in complex socio-ecological and livelihood systems in Uganda and Viet Nam
narrative: A combination of modeling approaches and tools that link actor-oriented system redesign with quantitative analyses of scenarios across different scales: global, national, landscape, communities, and farm households. By performing these analyses , complex interactions between biophysical and socio-economic spheres are explored and drivers like climate change, disease outbreaks, shifts in consumer demand or scaling of innovations are assessed and their possible impacts on ecosystems and livelihoods can be quantified.

title: Genetic Gain Estimates for sweetpotato in 5 climate zone by modified demonstration trials for a time period of 15-20 years
narrative: In 2019/20, CIP-HQ re-analyzed the genetic gain (GG) trials (modified demo trials) across breeding platforms for four climatic zones. The current GG for storage root yield range from 0.5% (West African Breeding Platform) to 2.5% (Amazon Basin, Peru Program). For foliage yield, the annual GG ranges from -1.9% (West African Program) to 1.2% (Southern African Program). For root beta-carotene content, the GG range from 1.0% (Southern African Breeding Platform) to 6.0% (West African Breeding Platform).

title: Magnitude genetic gains in hybrid populations estimated by Best Linear Unbiased Prediction (BLUP) and breeding values for parental selections
narrative: Three Orange-Fleshed Sweetpotato (OFSP) hybrid populations (H1) were developed at CIP-HQ: (i) wide-adaptation and earliness (WAE) at 90 days, normal 120 days harvest, (ii) none sweetness after cooking (NSSP), and (iii) high iron (HiFe). The H1 populations were evaluated with parents and founder clones. The root yield genetic gain was remarkable 118.8, 81.5, 132.4, 97.1% in H1 WAE for early and normal harvest, H1 NSSP, and H1 HiFe, respectively.

title: Three Virus-Resistant Potato Varieties in Georgia
narrative: Three varieties introduced from the International Potato Center (CIP), and registered in Georgia under local names (‘Javakheturi’, ‘Meskhuri’, and ‘Meskhuri Tsiteli’) are being evaluated as to its conditions for virus resistance and the level of degeneration.

title: Strategic research priority assessment toolkit to support investment and research portfolio decisions
narrative: Support investment and research portfolio decisions by determining the expected impact adoption of agricultural technologies generate in terms of economic benefits, poverty reduction, food security, and nutrition and health.

title: Set of tools to assess gender inequalities in access to and benefits derived from the cassava seed system in Tanzania
narrative: Set of tools for the identification of barriers and opportunities for women in the cassava seed system. It helps researchers and development practitioners identify and address bottlenecks to foster women's engagement and participation as Cassava Seed Entrepreneurs (CSEs) with the BEST Cassava Project

title: Good agricultural practices and numeracy training programs for potato farms in Kenya
narrative: Four modules on Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) and three module numeracy training programs on potato learning farms covering. These trainings are related to planting, hilling, disease and pest management, and harvesting.

title: Ambient ware potato storage technology in Uganda
narrative: Farmers in Uganda typically use light stores or light rooms in the house for potato storage. However, these are suitable only for storing seed potato because light promotes sprouting. The innovation consists of 8MT capacity improved stores that are dark and allow temperature control by taking advantage of the cool air at night.

title: A public-private partnership to speed up potato breeding in Viet Nam
narrative: To speed up the breeding and selection processes and ensure the adoption of developed varieties by strengthening the seed value chain, a public–private partnership has been established between International Potato Center and HZPC.

title: Development of genome-editing tool for yam in Sub-Saharan Africa
narrative: CRISPR/Cas9-based genome-editing system and validation of its efficacy by targeting the phytoene desaturase gene (DrPDS) in a West African farmer-preferred Dioscorea rotundata accession Amola.

title: A tunnel system for rapid propagation of disease-free planting material piloted in the Lao People's Democratic Republic
narrative: Tunnel system was develop as complementary action on cassava seed system. It provides an area with an environment with high humidity and temperature to promote sprouting of single bud planted and speed up the propagation rate (80-100X). To build a tunnel it needs PVC, clear greenhouse plastic, foggers and in the middle a sand cage to grown mini-cutting. Four tunnels conform one set in the infrastructure

title: Distinctness, Uniformity, Stability (DUS) and Value for Cultivation and Use (VCU) test protocols for the homologation of new potato varieties in Cameroon
narrative: The Ministry in charge of agriculture, through the regulatory department for seed and agricultural products, and in close collaboration with the CGIAR, developed potato DUS and VCU test protocols. These protocols are essential because they will help register for the first-time potato varieties in the country's permanent catalogue.

title: Orange-Fleshed Sweetpotato (OFSP) elite cross dissemination
narrative: Elite-crosses from CIP Hybrid-Breeding programs are conducted at CIP-HQ and CIP-Uganda. Genetic gains with (81.5 to 132.4% for storage root yield as well as product profile-specific quality and resistance improvements can be disseminated by elite-crosses via true seed rapidly to partners, within the same year as the elite true seed is produced. The innovation is currently emphasizing South, East and South-West Africa, Central Asia and Latin America.

title: Construction of Polyethylene glycol (PEG) mediated genetic transformation and gene knockout system in Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense Tropical Race 4
narrative: Fusarium wilt of banana, caused by Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. cubense tropic race 4 (Foc TR4), is a typical vascular and soil-borne disease which has significantly threatened the sustainable development of banana industry. In order to reveal the infection process and pathogenesis of Foc TR4, the young mycelia (66.7 mg/mL ) of wild-type strain of Foc TR4 (WT-Foc TR4) cultured for 18-20 h were lysed with enzyme mixture for protoplast formation, which consisted of 25 mg/mL driselase, 0.4 mg/mL chitinase, 15 mg/mL lysing enzyme and 1.2 mol/L potassium chloride. The resulted protoplasts of 2×107 cells/mL were used to test the efficiency of transformation mediated by polyethylene glycol, and up to 9 transformants per microgram of DNA were obtained. AmCyan, RFP and YFP genes were stably transferred into the WT-Foc TR4, separately, using the protoplast transformation system. The gene FoOCH1 encoding α-1, 6-mannosyltransferase in the WT-Foc TR4 was knocked out using the split-marker recombination technology. The genetic transformation and gene knockout system in this pathogen lays a foundation for the study of functional genomics and plant-pathogen interactions.

title: Packaging materials and storage conditions suitable for high carotenoid plantain flour in Uganda
narrative: The proposed innovation is based on( i) establishing the right packaging materials and storage periods for high carotenoid plantain flour,(ii) the use of a 1-MCP, an ethylene inhibitor, to extend the postharvest storage of matooke and (iii) the 8MT capacity improved stores that are dark and allow temperature control by taking advantage of the cool air at night.

title: Open-source thermal image processing software for improving irrigation management in potato crops
narrative: Development of an open-source thermal image processing software for improving irrigation management in potato crops (Solanum tuberosum L.). Unraveling eco-physiological mechanisms in potatoes under different irrigation methods through a preliminary field evaluation.

title: Mid-density marker panel for potato genomic selection
narrative: Diversity Array Technology (DArT) is a molecular marker technology that allows a high-throughput and cost-effective genotyping of target species without necessarily relying on prior genome sequence information. After two rounds of marker selection (based essentially on solcap markers) and primer design, a set of around 2000 DArTag markers. Those markers are ready for use in breeding programs. A scientific publication is being drafted.

title: Cassava population improvement through genomic selection
narrative: Traditional cassava breeding cycles using phenotype-based selection can take more than five years, limiting the rate of genetic gain and breeders’ ability to respond to new challenges. Shifting to genotype-based selection (Genomic Selection, GS) has the potential to overcome this limitation. Breeders can select superior clones using Genomic Estimated Breeding Values (GEBV) after only two years, which more than doubles the number of breeding cycles feasible.

title: A comprehensive cassava genome-wide association study catalogue for molecular breeding
narrative: A comprehensive catalogue of major loci underlying 14 traits, including biotic stress, root quality, plant architecture were published in Plant Molecular Biology (2020). This most comprehensive genome-wide association study in cassava using a large population of more than 5000 clones genotyped at more than 100K genomic SNPs each. Cassava researchers and breeders can now refer to this resource to guide their efforts in molecular breeding in the crop.

title: High-yielding Late-Blight Resistant Potato in Peru
narrative: Starting in 2011, 30,000 genotypes have been assessed to select those with high yields and good agronomic and commercial characters such as skin color, flesh color, tuber shape and eyes depth, plant vigor, uniformity of tubers. After seven years of evaluation and selection, 18 clones that showed phenotypic stability for selected traits have been identified. To date, two clones have been selected as promising for new varieties in Peru.

title: ICT4BXW: Prototype App to Combat Banana Diseases in Rwanda
narrative: It is a prototype app to combat banana diseases through digital innovation.  The app registers farmer users, locates them geographically and provides support for diagnosis, management, and implementation of agronomic practices for banana farming.

title: GreenPhylDB v5: a comparative pangenomic database for plant genomes
narrative: GreenPhylDBv5 introduces the concept of comparative pangenomics by harnessing multiple genome sequences by species. We created 19 pangenes and processed them with other species still relying on one genome. In total, 46 plant species were considered to build gene families and predict their homologous relationships through phylogenetic-based analyses. In addition, since the previous publication, we rejuvenated the website and included a new set of original tools including protein-domain combination, tree topologies searches and a section

title: Banana Genome Hub: a centralized database of genetic and genomic data for banana
narrative: The Banana Genome Hub (BGH) is a community website that federates genomic data on banana which developed by Cirad and the Alliance of Bioversity International and CIAT supported by the South Green Bioinformatics platform. The BGH is based on Drupal and Tripal and related modules to facilitate the integration between various systems (Jbrowse, Galaxy, Gigwa) for plant genome analysis

title: Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEL): a flexible, multi-center and multi-CRP online platform for integrated management, planning, monitoring and reporting of projects and activities, knowledge management and sharing
narrative: Monitoring, Evaluation and Learning (MEL) is an integrated and adaptable online platform for projects, activities and knowledge management, performance measurement, communication and dissemination of research findings. Its multifaceted and modular structure allows customization and remodelling to meet ever-changing demands. Currently, MEL is adopted by three CGIAR-CRPs, five CGIAR-Centers, and recently by the CGIAR Excellence in Agronomy 2030 (EiA) initiative and by the Partnership for Research and Innovation in the Mediterranean Area (PRIMA).

title: Doubled Haploids for faster and more efficient breeding in cassava
narrative: First report of putative haploid inducers (HI) in cassava, developed through gene editing, and based on the well-characterized maize’s HI principle of mutating genes that impair pollen tube development.  This effort will continue provided proper funding be available.

title: Mobile phone technology for increasing banana productivity among smallholder farmers in Uganda
narrative: The phone technology was developed based on the 321 Viamo service, that offers the right agricultural information at the right time in rural and remote areas. To raise awareness and ensure adoption, the technology leverages on Interactive Voice Response (IVR) providing advice to farmers in local languages via audio recordings. The technology was evaluated in Uganda with respect to farmer awareness and use. Smallholder farmers who adopt the technology effectively diagnose and manage banana diseases.

title: Ground penetrating radar for estimating root bulking rate in cassava in Nigeria and Colombia
narrative: The ability to image and quantify subsurface root structure would allow breeders to classify root traits for rapid selection and allow agronomists  to derive effective cultivation practices, without using destructive root harvesting approaches.
